column2: Brayton Ives was yesterday elected President of the Metropolitan Trust Company to fill a vacancy created by the death last July of Thomas Hillhouse. Mr. Ives was the sole choice of the Trustees. No financier is better known in the railroad and money world. His most recent positions of note were as President of the Western National Bank and of the Northern Pacific Railroad.

Postmaster Van Cott received yesterday morning from the department at Washington an official notice, saying that, in view of the deficit which would ensue for the present fiscal year, if some restrictive measures were not taken the Post Offices of the larger cities would be asked to save $120,000 by curtailing delivery expenses before June 30, 1898.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Prof. George Maccloskie, Professor of Biology at Princeton University, an extensive writer on scientific subjects, when questioned as to his opinion concerning Prof. Schenk's discoveries concerning the possibility of sex selection, said that he had been expecting something of the kind for some time.

Mrs. Morgan J. Willard of New York recently read a paper before the Woman's League, of which she is an officer, on the subject of "Woman's Greatest Troubles." After enumerating them in order, and intelligently treating the subjects of "Unrequited Affection," "Lack of Appreciation," "Loss of Friends," "Poverty," etc., she continued:

The Bureau of Statistics has just published its December bulletin of domestic exports, covering about 98 per cent. of the exports of the articles named. It includes breadstuffs, cotton, mineral oils, and provisions. The following table gives the figures for the calendar years 1896 and 1897 for these various classes of exports:

The chief topic among the advocates and opponents of an underground rapid transit railroad yesterday was the letter sent the day before to the Rapid Transit Commissioners by President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, in which, speaking for the Directors of the company, he apparently withdrew from any further consideration of the construction of the road.

PRINCETON, Jan. 13. -- The Princeton University Football Team met last night behind closed doors. This was the final act of the investigation started last Fall to locate the responsibility for the wretched physical condition which the men were in when they met Yale.

Henry M. Denton has sold through H.H. Johnson to J.L. Osborne the plot, southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, 100 by 102.2. A building loan of $180,000 is made by Mr. Denton in connection with the sale, and it is said that the buyer will erect two seven-story apartment houses on the plot.

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- At the moment this dispatch is filed it is reported that an important engagement has taken place between the Spaniards and the insurgents under Gen. Rabi, in the District of Manzanillo. It is further reported that the insurgents lost 300 men killed, and the Spaniards are said to have lost 140 men, killed or wounded.

As the audiences grow bigger daily in Carnegie Hall, Mr. Moody warms up and speaks with more and more of his old-time fervor. The meetings are becoming more like revivals, and hundreds rise in the auditorium and galleries at the morning and afternoon meetings to ask the prayers of the congregation and of the evangelist.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- It has been an eventful day. The excitement began with the earliest morning newspaper containing M. Zola's letter. This sold like wildfire. There was a similar rush for the announcement of the arrest of Col. Picquart.

William L. Trenholm, President of the American Surety Company since 1889, has parted with his stock in the company, and will retire from the Presidency and from the Board of Directors on Jan. 18, when the term for which he was elected expires. He will retire at the same time from the State Trust Company, of which he is Vice President.

Many new features were introduced at the Fourth Annual Sportsmen's Exposition, which began at Madison Square Garden last night. The amphitheatre was beautifully decorated, and viewed from the gallery the place resembled a small village. The space was taken up by log cabins and booths of every description.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Jan. 13. -- Russell B. Harrison who returned here to-day from Chicago, was asked about his connection with the causes that led to the removal of Cashier Donaghoe, of the National State Bank, and the subsequent bringing of a surety company's agent and a detective here to compel the ex-cashier to make good the $5,000 he paid on Mr. Harrison's worthless check.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The House today in Committee of the Whole approved the -Agricultural Appropriation bill, but when the bill was reported to the House those who are opposed to the printing of another edition of the "Horse Book" secured an adjournment before the bill was put to a vote on its passage.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13. -- Senator Hanna was received in this city this afternoon upon his return from Columbus with an ovation far greater than any which had been accorded a public man in this city in a decade. Long before the hour of the train's arrival thousands gathered upon the streets and began to line the sidewalks.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Democrats were taken somewhat by surprise last night by the request of Messrs. Aldridge and Adams for an investigation of the canal scandal, but they declare to-day that, from the point of view of political advantage, the matter could not have taken a happier course for them.

HONOLULU, Jan. 6. -- President Sanford B. Dole leaves for Washington by the steamship Peru Jan. 8 for the purpose of consulting with the Administration there on the subject of the annexation of these islands to the greater republic.

Edward Goodman of 106 West Eighty-sixth Street committed suicide yesterday evening by shooting himself in the head. Goodman was a manufacturer of cloaks and suits at 35 East Twelfth Street, and it was on the third floor, where he had his establishment, that he took his life.
BERLIN, Jan. 13. -- The North German Gazette will prominently reprint this important article from The East Asiatic Correspondence to-morrow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The President to-day sent these nominations to the Senate:

The resolution introduced by Commissioner of Bridges Shea at the meeting of the Board of Public Improvements on Wednesday, that he be authorized to investigate and report on the necessity for building an all-railroad bridge between the Boroughs of Brooklyn and Manhattan, was the subject of much discussion yesterday among men conversant with bridge and tunnel construction.

-- That station agent down in Oklahoma who invented the story about an Indian uprising, and who startled the whole country with his descriptions of wholesale slaughter, may be something more than a gifted descendant of ANANIAS. His yarn wasn't true, but it was perfectly credible, and one can only wonder that the Seminoles did not pursue exactly the course of action which the station agent detailed.

BOSTON, Jan. 13. -- Helen Keller, the deaf, dumb, and blind girl from Alabama, who spent many years of her young life in the Perkins Institution for the Blind, and whose brilliant mind has given to scientists a wonderfully interesting study, has been removed by her mother from Gilman's School in Cambridge, where she has been preparing herself for entrance into Radcliff College.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 13. -- Prof. Nordenskjold, the arctic explorer, has informed the Swedish Academy of Science that the Foreign Office has received intelligence that several persons worthy of credence saw Prof. Andree's balloon early in August in British Columbia, seven miles north of Quesnelle Lake, in the District of Cariboo.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The Senate was in session only fifteen minutes to-day. Following the introduction of bills, a brief discussion took place over the necessity of a rule requiring morn explicit descriptions in the titles of bills amending the Greater New York charter. The rule was adopted, and the Senate adjourned.

The Executive Committee of the Democratic Honest Money League, at a meeting held at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, adopted resolutions indorsing the recent report of the Monetary Commission to the Indianapolis Monetary Convention. The committee consists of James S. Johnson, John J. Pulleyn, Francis C. Travers, Major John D. Keiley, Col. J.E. Bloom, Henry J. Sayers, Francis R. Pemberton, John Crane, John J. Rooney, and others.

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 13. -- The War Department has practically abandoned the proposed relief expedition to the Klondike. A telegram was received here to-day from Vancouver, the headquarters of Brig. Gen. Merriam, Department of the Columbia, instructing Quartermaster W.W. Robinson not to purchase supplies here pending further instructions.

I am no controversialist, but last Sunday's sermon by the Rev. Heber Newton awakes in me the spirit of protest. He talked, in reported correctly, of an "impossible Bible," and said, in effect, that the world demands a new religion. No, my dear Sir, it is not a new religion that we require, but to live up to the old.

I see by the papers that a bill is to be drafted and presented to the Legislature empowering the establishment of outdoor gymnasiums for Greater New York. This is as it should be. Nothing could be more salutary in any community. But it is also proposed to establish these gymnasiums and playgrounds "in all the parks and employ competent public instructors."

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Harry Collier Mix, who eloped from Cambridge, Mass., and were married at Buffalo, are here at the residence of the groom's brother-in-law, H.G. Wilson. Mr. Mix was a postgraduate student at Harvard, and is well known here. He and his wife are now trying to have a former marriage annulled on the ground of forgery of her father's name by Frank Fiske Farwell, the first bridegroom.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Senate did not make great progress with the Hawaiian annexation treaty to-day. Several speeches were delivered, but in each instance the speaker announced that to-day's remarks were merely preliminary to what he should say before the close of the debate. Those who spoke were Senators Stewart, Frye, and Morgan.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 13. -- Gov. Leslie M. Shaw was inaugurated to-day. In the course of his address he said:

Frederick Von Steenberg, an engineer, made a complaint at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon to the effect that two policemen on duty at the Boiler Inspection Bureau had tried to extort money from him when he tried to get his certificate as an engineer renewed. Deputy Chief Cortright gave Von Steenberg two marked bills, and told him to pay the two policemen.

Members of the Nineteenth Century Club and their guests met at Sherry's, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, last night to hear Joseph Jefferson deliver a dramatic discourse and Frank Damrosch give his views on music in America. So many were attracted thither that the seating capacity of the ballroom was inadequate, and many stood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The hearing of the Monetary Commission in behalf of its bill for currency reform was resumed before the Banking and Currency Committee of the House to-day. Mr. T.J. Bush of Alabama, who was heard yesterday, urged the case of redemption under the plan of the commission.

At the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday afternoon, when the question of appropriations for libraries came up, Mayor Van Wyck asked Deputy Controller Levey whether any of the money went to the Public Library. "It does not," replied Mr. Levey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- In a few days the Treasury Department will make known the details of the arrangement recently concluded with Mr. Sifton, Canadian Minister of the Interior, respecting the transportation of gold seekers and freight to the Klondike.

A number of important changes in The Jockey Club rules of racing, under which all of the metropolitan race track meetings are held, were made yesterday at the annual meeting of The Jockey Club in the club's office, 173 Fifth Avenue. James R. Keene presided, the Chairman, August Belmont, being unable to attend.

NEWARK, Jan. 13. -- The Newark and South Orange Railroad Company and the North Jersey Traction Company have consolidated. That much was admitted by the interested parties to-day, but they declined to discuss the details. The company proposes to extend its lines into every county in North Jersey and make connections between every town, city, and village in the territory.

On the bulletin board of the Democratic Club last night there were posted for membership the names of four United States Senators -- John L. Mitchell of Wisconsin, Richard R. Kenney of Delaware, Alexander S. Clay of Georgia, and John W. Daniel of Virginia. They were proposed by Senator Edward Murphy and seconded by Richard Croker.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The trial of Richard Arthur Prince, the super who stabbed and killed William Terriss, the well-known actor, at the stage entrance of the Adelphi Theatre on Dec. 16 last, was held to-day at the Old Bailey, (Central Criminal Court.) Justice Channell presided in his scarlet robes of office.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 13. -- Judge Goff of the United States District Court to-day heard preliminary arguments in the case of the Republic of Colombia against the Cauca Company, composed of New York capitalists and incorporated under the laws of West Virginia. According to statements made, the Cauca Company secured a railway franchise from the republic and the road was built from Buena Venture to Cali and projected to Manizales, in Colombia.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- "Mile-a-minute" Anderson, famous for his bicycle rides behind steam engines, will appear in Chicago Decoration Day and again seek to beat the minute mark. In a letter received from him to-day by C.C. Ingraham, Anderson says:

HAVANA, Jan. 13. -- About noon to-day a crowd gathered in front of the offices of El Diario de la Marina shouting, "Death to the Diario." Gen. Arolas used the regular troops to restore order and to compel the dispersal of the crowd, which kept up a continuous shouting on the streets near Central Park.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Mr. Laimbeer has introduced in the Assembly a bill to amend the Greater New York charter relative to the powers and organization of the Board of Health. It provides that the Mayor shall appoint four Health Commissioners, instead of three, as at present, who shall hold office for four instead of six years.

Eight men were arrested in Syracuse Wednesday on the complaint of detectives employed by the New York Central Railroad, who accused them of violating Section 616 of the Criminal Code, which makes it unlawful for any person not an authorized agent to sell railroad tickets. They are also charged with a violation of Section 619, which declares it a crime, punishable with five years' imprisonment, to conspire to sell passage tickets.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- This afternoon the Senate Cities Committee held its first meeting, Chairman Stranahan presiding. Senator Cantor appeared to argue in favor of the amendment of Section 937 of the Greater New York Charter.
MADRID, Jan. 13. -- Gen. Augusta will succeed the late Gen. Munoz as Captain General of Puerto Rico.

At the meeting of the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen, to be held in St. Louis the second week in February, a reconciliation with the "outlaw" racing element of the Pacific Coast will be broached, and it is the opinion of many of the delegates that thereafter peace and harmony will be established between the seceders' and the parent body.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Mr. Laimbeer has introduced in the Assembly a bill to amend the Greater New York charter relative to the powers and organization of the Board of Health. It provides that the Mayor shall appoint four Health Commissioners, instead of three, as at present, who shall hold office for four instead of six years.

Eight men were arrested in Syracuse Wednesday on the complaint of detectives employed by the New York Central Railroad, who accused them of violating Section 616 of the Criminal Code, which makes it unlawful for any person not an authorized agent to sell railroad tickets. They are also charged with a violation of Section 619, which declares it a crime, punishable with five years' imprisonment, to conspire to sell passage tickets.

The trial of ESTERHAZY was undertaken almost avowedly as a means of quieting public opinion. There has for years been an increasing doubt whether the sentence of Capt. DREYFUS was just. His trial proceeded upon an assumption that somebody in the French Army had sold military secrets to a foreign power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- Late this afternoon the first news of the day came to the State Department from Consul General Lee, who telegraphed that everything was very quiet in Havana to-day, and that there was no cause for apprehension of trouble.

Readers of Prof. WOOLSEY'S article in yesterday's TIMES about the international aspects of Germany's performance in China must have been impressed by the conviction that professors of international law have their uses. The questions raised by that performance have been discussed fully by the press, and not unintelligently.

" The Dingley Boom" was the subject of an ironical address by Thomas G. Shearman, delivered last night before the Brooklyn Democratic Club, at 201 Montague Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Shearman began by asking, as a conundrum, what was the difference between the Grover Cleveland panic and the "Bill" McKinley boom, and indicated that the answer of the average citizen would be "I don't see any."

The first joint meeting of the various Local Board's of Improvements of the Borough of Brooklyn was held yesterday in the City Hall. The committee appointed to investigate the feasibility of Alderman Stewart's proposition to hold the several board meetings simultaneously brought in a favorable report on the ground that it would expedite business and bring in closer harmony the several boards of the borough.

TRENTON, Jan. 13. -- Vice Chancellor Reed has filed an opinion refusing to set aside the Oklahoma divorce granted to Frank A. Magowan from his wife, Mary Magowan. The Vice Chancellor says that there was no proof before the Court of Chancery that Magowan was not a legal resident of Oklahoma at the time he obtained this divorce there.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 13. -- At the meeting of the Yale Corporation to-day O.C. Marsh, professor of paleontology, formally presented to the university the valuable scientific collections belonging to him now deposited in the Peabody Museum.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 13. -- Representative Saunders, Democrat, of Union County, to-day introduced a resolution in the Kentucky House of Representatives questioning the Democracy of United States Senator William Lindsay, on account of his currency views, and asking him to resign. The resolution was referred to the Committee on Positions and Grievances by a viva voce vote, which disposes of it finally.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The hearing of the suit of Mr. Daniel Jay, a money lender, to recover from Lady Sykes, wife of Sir Tatton Sykes, the Yorkshire Baronet, the sum of 15,870 ($79,350) on the security of notes purporting to be signed by her husband was continued to-day before the Lord Chief Justice, Baron Russell of Killowen, in the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice.
The sentiment for currency reform is clearly spreading among Republicans who have heretofore been wedded to the "let-alone" policy.

At a meeting of the Sinking Fund Commissioners yesterday afternoon Mayor Van Wyck attacked the last administration for what he called its extravagance. It all began when Controller Color asked to have a resolution passed compelling the heads of the departments to submit to him estimates of the amounts needed for office rent, and he wanted this done before they took possession of their quarters.

The necessity of building a viaduct from the steep hillside at West One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street to the slope of the hill a little further to the north afforded, a few months ago, an admirable opportunity for putting up a fine monumental structure. It is but seldom that so good a chance is offered to the decorative designer.

In the death of Alfred Morrison, which occurred in England during the Christmas holidays, one of the greatest collectors of pictures, engravings, and autographs is declared to have passed away. His various collections are said to have cost him about a million sterling. The catalogue of the ancient engravings and autographs preserved at Fonthill Abbey and at his London residence in Carlton House Terrace fills six large and closely printed volumes.

In response to the letters written by the Judge Advocate General of the navy, by direction of Secretary Long, to A. T. Walsh, the contractors who completed the construction of the navy yard Dry Dock No. 3, and to their bondsmen, Augustin Walsh of the firm has written to Secretary Long denying any responsibility in the matter and inviting the Navy Department to bring suit.
The reduction of the force of carriers in the large cities, and especially in New York, is a blunder and an outrage.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Several dispatches from Consul General Lee were received at the State Department to-day and Assistant Secretary Day took the first one to the White House before the Cabinet meeting. It recited the attacks on the newspaper offices and the participation of the soldiers in the demonstrations.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14. -- Big shipments of grain were reported to-day as being scheduled to arrive here from Chicago. It is coming at a rate which is equivalent to 6 cents a bushel, though the usual rate to Philadelphia from Chicago is 10 4-10 cents per bushel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Vice President and Mrs. Hobart entertained the President and Mrs. McKinley this evening at a beautifully appointed dinner of twenty covers.

PARIS, Jan. 14. -- A number of law students, after leaving a lecture to-day, march to the office of the Aurore in procession, shouting denunciations of M. Emile Zola, who recently wrote a letter to that paper alleging irregularities and illegalities in the Esterhazy court-martial, formally accusing the Minister of War, Gen. Billot, and others of perjury and challenging the Government to prosecute him.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Jan. 14. -- W.C. Stewart, residing at the Hotel Majestic, New York, and Miss Olga Gabel, residing at the Hotel Winthrop, New York, arrived this morning, were married at noon, and started for New York on the afternoon train.
In their weekly review of trade, Messrs. R.G. Dun Co. to-day will say:

Before the British tramp steamship Ivydene cast loose her lines at Dow's Stores in Brooklyn yesterday, preparatory to sailing for foreign port, Frank Smith, the chief steward, and several of the firemen decided to settle a difference which grew out of the broth and other "grub," of which the steward was the provider and the men the consumers.

Lieut. Commander Daniel Delehanty, United States Navy, is the new Governor of the Sailors' Snug Harbor in succession to Capt. Trask, who recently resigned the office. The Board of Trustees of the Harbor made choice of him at a meeting yesterday afternoon, in its rooms in the Bank of Commerce Building.

Late yesterday afternoon the last workman made the final stroke of his varnish brush on the extension of the United Charities Building. Next week all the rooms are to be cleaned and the new occupants will begin to move in. These occupants include the Congregational Mission Boards, which have had their headquarters in the Bible House since its erection.

Commissioner of Bridges Shea still holds to his scheme for the necessity of building an all-railroad bridge across the East River in spite of the arguments of experts that it is not a necessity, and that a tunnel to answer the same purposes as a bridge could be more quickly and cheaply constructed.

In the preface to the privately printed catalogue of his library Edmund Gosse referred to the fact that he did not possess any of "the white elephants of bibliography." No one has of late written about books more interestingly than has Gosse. In his "Gossip in a Library," for example, one has literary criticism and history, but Gosse never wrote a more expressive phrase than the one just quoted.

Another large crowd visited the Sportsmen's Exposition at Madison Square Garden yesterday. In the evening large groups of interested persons crowded around the various booths and admired the exhibits. The Maine and Adirondacks camps were crowded all evening, and the guides were ever ready to relate stories of the hunt. Miss Crosby, who is known all through the Maine forests as "Fly Rod," entertained a host of sportsmen last night.

The Dock Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, received and accepted the resignation of First Assistant Engineer Andrew McC. Parker. Mr. Parker resigns to accept a position with the contracting firm of Shanly Ryan.

ITHACA, Jan. 14. -- The refusal of Yale to grant Cornell's request, contained in the latter's acceptance of Yale's challenge for a boat race, caused considerable disappointment here. In an interview to-night Prof. E.W. Huffcutt, President of the Cornell Athletic Council, said:

Monday night marks the opening of the grand opera season in this city, and on that occasion there probably will be one of the most brilliant audiences assembled in the Metropolitan Opera House since the closing of the season last year, when the operas were given under the management of Abbey Grau.

Three important facts are presented to us in this lesson. They are independent facts, not necessarily in any way connected with each other. Two of them are evidently general facts belonging to the entire time of our Lord's earthly ministry. The other is a special fact, having a definite occasion and a definite purpose.

As one who has striven through some discouragement to inculcate an appreciation of real literature in the children of our public schools. I Thank "Esteemed Contributor" for his wise words of warning directed to parents in last Saturday's REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART.

LONDON, Jan. 4, 1898. -- Literature, the new critical weekly, has now been in existence long enough for its proprietors to ascertain whether or not a new sixpenny literary weekly can possibly find a paying circulation in England. The first number of Literature had an immense sale, but this owing partly to the fact that it was the first number, and partly to Kipling's poem, "White Horses."

Company A made a rather poor showing last night in the competition for the Kemp and Clark Trophies, now in progress at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Private L.J.F. Rooney and Capt. H.W. Janssen made the best scores, each finishing his string with 46 out of a possible 50. The scores:

In talking of the general business outlook to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, President William J. Coombs of the Manufacturers' Trust Company expressed his satisfaction at the improved conditions which now exist compared with those which presented themselves at the beginning of 1897.

Great interest is manifest in the congregation of the Broadway Tabernacle, now that there is a possibility of calling a pastor, and the congregational meeting on Wednesday evening is certain to be largely attended. A majority of the members are now said to favor extending a call to the Rev. Dr. Andrew V.V. Raymond; President of Union College.

There was a lively tilt yesterday afternoon in the office of the Town Collector of Jamaica between Collector Havilad, whose term of office expired with the advent of the city, and Emil E. Bergen, Tax Collector of Jamaica Village prior to the first of the year, on one side and George Durland, Deputy Collector of Arrears for the Fourth Ward of Queens, and County Clerk John H. Sutphen on the other.

Men and women who have been seeking industriously for information concerning the part taken by ancestors of theirs in Colonial and Revolutionary times will be among the most diligent readers the State Historian of New York, Mr. Hugh Hastings, will have for his annual report just published. It is a volume of more than a thousand pages, many of which are filled with muster rolls to which there is an elaborate index.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 14. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hoar (Rep., Mass.,) presented a joint resolution proposing an amendment to the Constitution relating to the time of the inauguration of Presidents. Through a clerical error the resolution as presented placed the date when the change should go into effect in 1899. It was Mr. Hoar's intention to make the year 1901, and later he changed his resolution accordingly. The amended resolution follows:

The art season continues dull, and the week brought little new to the attention of the public. There is as yet no indication of any notable picture sales, with the single exception of that of the Stewart paintings, which is to take place early next month.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 14. -- Sir James Westland, the Finance Minister of the Council, introduced a bill to-day providing for the issue of currency notes in India against gold. Mr. Arthur, the paid Secretary of State in London, in behalf of the banks and Chambers of Commerce, indorsed the measure.

Capt. McClusky and his entire staff of detectives made a raid on alleged bucket shops in the Wall Street district yesterday afternoon. Four of these concerns were entered simultaneously, and seventeen prisoners were taken, among them a young woman, who tried hard to conceal her identity, and gave several different names and addresses.

LONDON, Jan. 14. -- It has been an open secret in theatrical circles that Sir Charles Arthur Fairlie Cunninghame, who, as announced by The Daily Mail to-day, committed suicide at the Hotel Victoria, this city, during the night of Dec. 26, had been infatuated with Marjorie Pryor, a tall, blonde chorus girl of the "In Town" company, which visited the United States under the management of George Edwardes.

In Mrs. Sherwood's "Memories of Holland House," the fact that from her portrait Lady Holland seems to have been brune in coloring, heavy featured, and once resided in Jamaica, apparently is taken as authority for the statement that she was "a half negro Jamaica woman." The Vassalls were a New England family, Richard Vassall, Lady Holland's father, married Mary, daughter of Thomas Clark of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The following fourth-class Postmasters have been appointed:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The House managers decided not to proceed with the consideration of the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill to-day, but to give the day for the consideration of private bills. This was done to avert the possibility of precipitating a sensational Cuban debate that might have taken place if an appropriation bill had been under consideration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Almost the entire four hours of the executive session of the Senate to-day were devoted to the consideration of the nomination of Joseph McKenna, now Attorney General, to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. An effort was made by Senator Allen (Pop., Neb.,) to secure a postponement for two weeks.

The serious attempts of at least two of your correspondents to excuse the book-plate collecting habit prove that the crusade against the same is well justified. On the one hand you are met by the gentleman with the "we blotting paper or flannel," while on the other, another collector, in the "upper reaches," seeks specimens from the hand of Durer, Holbein, and other masters.

Excuse these few lines, which in their own poor way must take up the cudgels for the poor sailors, fishermen, "et hoc genus omne," whom a traveler writing from Marseilles, and from the high standpoint of "an American Protestant," chooses to look down upon and in his little way throw stones at.

In a fire which occurred in the Raines law hotel kept by Thomas Roberts at 348 and 349 West Street yesterday afternoon Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Leslie, who had boarded with Roberts for about five weeks, were suffocated. The fire broke out about 4:30 o'clock in the kitchen of the hotel and an alarm was sent in.

I see in your issue of recent date that the Captain Samuel Chester Reid Memorial Association of the State of New York was formed by a number of war veterans and other patriotic citizens of the Borough of Brooklyn to assist in raising funds to erect a monument over the long-neglected grave of a National hero.

May I be permitted to make just one suggestion in regard to THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART for the new year? As a lover of books the paper is invaluable to me, with its excellent reviews of books giving glimpses of unattainable ones not otherwise to be had, adding to the enjoyment of those which are read, as well as its kindred topics treated.
Dwight L. Moody held his last weekday services at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning and afternoon. He will hold two meetings in the same hall to-morrow, one at 8 P.M. and the other at 8 P.M.

Prince Henry of Orleans, who is bent on wasting French lives and money in schemes of colonization, is however an explorer of merit. His book descriptive of his travels, "From Tonkin to India," has been translated, and is to be published shortly by the Messrs. Methuen.

The conference on practical reform of primary elections, called to meet in this city Jan. 20 and 21, will be held in the assembly rooms of the New York Board of Trade, 203 Broadway, at 10:30 A.M. The call is signed by quasi-political clubs, reform and industrial bodies, and representative men of all parties, in a dozen large cities.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- M. Pierre Louys, the author of "Aphrodite,'' is certainly the most successful young writer in France. Of "Aphrodite" more than 150 editions have been sold, and it bids fair to become a permanent favorite. It is not surprising, therefore, that M. Pierre Louys's latest volume, "Les Chansons de Bilitis," though written in quite a different style from that of "Aphrodite," should be distinctively the book of the week.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 5. -- Sir: You ask me if it is true, as reported, that I am about to marry a lady, Miss Marion Olive Hansen, who has acted as my typewriter. I answer, Yes.
Since writing about Holland House a few weeks ago several letters have reached me on that subject, one of them the following:

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Mr. Hoffman has introduced a bill in the Assembly which provides that the elevated railroads in New York City shall have no powers, privileges, or franchises, or carry on any trade or business, except as expressly granted and allowed in the special or general statute under which the companies were organized.

The riot in Havana marks another acute development of the chronic crisis of Spain. The fate of Senor SAGASTA'S well-meant scheme of autonomy has been curious. It was devised for the purpose of conciliating the insurgents and inducing them to submit to at least a nominal Spanish rule.

The time was when the name of John Arthur Roebuck was familiar in this country. During the civil war the name was something more than familiar. It was held in some scorn, at least in the North. Mr. Roebuck belonged among those Englishmen who desired to have their country recognize the independence of the Southern States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day decided to make an adverse report upon H.W. Corbett's claim to a seat in the Senate from Oregon. The vote was 4 to 3, and was cast on party lines, except that Senator Burrows (Rep.,) who was absent, was counted, upon his authority, in opposition to Mr. Corbett.

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- The Rome correspondent of The Daily Chronicle, in a startling statement this morning, quotes largely from an article in Civilta Cattolica, which, he declares, is directly inspired by the Vatican and the Pope, advocating as the solution of the eternal question between the Vatican and the Quirinal the establishment of an Italian republic.

Success in life and the causes of it form a topic of inexhaustible interest to men and women -- and especially to men. Probably there have been few books not novels more widely read in late years than Mr. Marden's "Pushing to the Front" and "Success." The former has called out a curious protest from a French writer, aimed at American success in general.

Frederick Zittel has sold for Ottinger Brothers and Korn Brothers to Egan Hallecy four lots on the north side of Thirty-fourth Street, 175 feet west of Seventh Avenue. The buyers give in payment the live eighteen-foot dwellings, 48 to 56 Edgecombe Avenue, near One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street. Egan Hallecy will erect two seven-story apartment houses on the plot just purchased.

Radical changes in the present election law are proposed by the bill introduced in the Legislature by George Wallace, Assemblyman from Queens, and referred to the committee after being read. The bill is to amend Chapter 909, Laws of 1896, known as the election laws, and entitled "An act in relation to the election, constituting Chapter 6 of the general laws."

John C. Sheehan came out yesterday with a flat-footed denial of the printed story that he, with Hugh McLaughlin, the leader of the Brooklyn Democracy, and his brother, ex-Lieut. Gov. William F. Sheehan of Erie County, had held an important conference with ex-Senator David B. Hill before the latter left the city on Wednesday.

Whenever a French political scandal seems to be upon the point of breaking out, desperate attempts are made by the persons about to be implicated to hush it up "for the honor of France." That was the form of appeal adopted when the President's son-in-law was suspected of carrying on a trade in public honors.

The decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the case of William R. Hearst against William Berri and others, which is generally known a the bridge loop injunction case, was handed down yesterday afternoon. It attracted a great deal of attention among the lawyers about the court, as there was considerable difference of opinion among some of them as to the precise meaning of the decision.

A story is going about -- a new contribution to the rapidly growing "Kiplingiana" -- that a young writer who recently sought Mr. Kipling's advice received this reply: "No man's advice is of the least benefit in our business, (and I am a very busy man.) Keep on trying until you either fail or succeed."

Henry Hahn, who was found at 3 o'clock on the morning of New Year's Day in Charles Armbruster's saloon at 312 West Forty-fourth Street, and who was then arrested by Policeman Tobin of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station, on a charge of burglary in the third degree was arraigned before Recorder Golf in the General Sessions Court yesterday.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 14. -- Crisham Winch, in the carriage and sleigh business, failed this week, and William Williams was made the assignee. The impression was that the firm had assets amounting to at least $60,000. Mr. Williams, however, reported without delay that the assets would not exceed $4,000, and that the partners, according to their statements, had no personal estate whatever.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 14. -- A development of water power for electrical transmission second only to that at Niagara Falls is contemplated by a company of New York and Pennsylvania capitalists, who have acquired control of the Chattahoochie River for sixteen miles. The purpose is to build three plants and a stone dam at each of the places.

The Brooklyn Woman's Health Protective Association listened to a talk upon the bad sanitary condition of the Brooklyn schools yesterday from the two women members of the Board of Education, Mrs. Andrew Jacobs and Mrs. Powell.

The death of Mrs. Minnie Coe of 213 Heyward Street, Brooklyn, on Thursday was caused, the doctor who attended her says, by grief and worry over the troubles in which her husband, John H. Coe, involved himself by transactions with worthless checks. Mrs. Coe was twenty-eight years old and a member of a prominent and wealthy Brooklyn family.

The Woman's Alliance of the Universalist Church met yesterday at the Prospect Heights Church, Sixth Avenue and Ninth Street, Brooklyn Borough. Mrs. Charles H. Eaton of the Borough of Manhattan presided at the business session The Rev. Alice K. Wright acted as Chairman of the literary exercises, and after an introductory address presented Miss Minna E. Conklin, who spoke of current affairs throughout the world.

" John Leighton, Jr.," by Katrina Trask, (Harper's,) is a good deal more than a clever book. The conversation in Mrs. Gray's drawing room, in which the hero and the heroine take striking parts, is, in a way, the disclosure of the motive of the book.

The purchase of the New York Athletic Club's house, at Fifty-fifth Street and Sixth Avenue, by the Democratic Club of 617 Fifth Avenue, was definitely settled upon last night at a meeting of the members of the latter club. Richard Croker bought the property last week for $190,000; the sum of $10,000 being paid at once to bind the bargain, $55,000 when the title was transferred, and $125,000 being represented by a mortgage.

The striking shirt ironers and starchers are getting ready to prevent Louis Biedermann of 15 Walker Street from carrying out his threat of taking forty Chinamen in their places to-morrow. They said they were sorry that they did not think of cutting off the Chinamen's pigtails when they attacked the Celestials on Thursday evening, but they will take scissors with them to-morrow should they decide to attack Biedermann's shop, if Chinese are employed there.

The New York University Glee, Banjo, and Mandolin Clubs start what promises to be the most successful season in their history on Thursday next. The clubs have attained excellent forum under the direction of F.J. Smith. This concert is given at the Fordham Club, and it is expected will be largely attended by the younger alumni, as well as by the undergraduates.

The past week saw the athletic season well started at Columbia. Two new eight-oared rowing machines have been set up in the temporary gymnasium in Schermerhorn Hall, and since Wednesday the Freshmen and 'Varsity crew candidates have been put through a ten-minute exercise every day on these.

The liveliest election that the members of the Sixty-ninth Regiment National Guard of New York have ever seen is promised for to-morrow night, when the Captain is to be chosen for Company D. There are two candidates in the field. Putnam Bradlee Strong, son of ex-Mayor Strong, Battalion Adjutant, and Captain Edward T. McCrystal of Company B, who announced his intention at the meeting held Friday of running against and defeating, if possible, the Adjutant.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore began yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History his Spring series of lectures, all of which are to be given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction. It is customary for the Autumn lectures to be devoted to travels in the Eastern world, while the Spring course is reserved for description and illustration of travels in America.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12. -- The annual catalogue of the Princeton Theological Seminary has just been issued, and the statistics show a total enrollment of 238 students, which is a decrease of 15 from last year. Of this number 14 are graduate students, 63 seniors, 77 middlers, 74 juniors, and 10 specials. The decrease since last year is felt in all the classes, with the exception of the middle, which shows an increase of 16.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 15. -- Parks Martin, Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, was here to-day from Spencer arranging for the organization of the new State Central Committee next Tuesday. In discussing the disposition of the Democrats in New York to drop Bryan and the radical features that marked the Presidential campaign, Mr. Martin said he did not believe the Democrats of Indiana would be influenced by any action that might be taken elsewhere.

THE noisy little switching engine with its hissing steam and volumes of black smoke is rapidly being replaced on the larger railroads for hauling and punting freight ears through the yards and along the docks by a more modern and improved electric locomotive.

The importation of American horses has so seriously interfered with the sale of native Belgian horses, the only well-paying agricultural industry in that country, that the Belgian societies interested in the breeding and sale of horses have asked the Government to take some steps to protect Belgian breeders, who cannot compete with American importers, who land cargoes weekly at Antwerp, and sell them readily.

Gen. William Booth, founder and Commander in Chief of the Salvation Army, arrived here yesterday on the steamship St. Paul, having come to make an inspection and revival tour of this continent. His limbs were terribly swollen and he was in a helpless condition. O'Neill was a sailor on the bark Pactolus, Capt. Watts, which sailed from Manilla for this port on the 5th of last September.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The monthly statement of the exports and imports, issued by the Bureau of Statistics shows that the exports of domestic merchandise for December last amounted to $123,181,743, an increase as compared with December, 1896, of over $7,000,000. For the twelve months the increase was over $93,000,000.

Lyon of St. Louis in rebuttal of the statements that commercial travelers generally are in favor of the existence of ticket scalpers.

The trouble was caused by the delay of a train during rush hours.

Corning of the old village of Rockaway Beach, which is now a part of the Borough of Queens, was subjected to a scare of startling proportions yesterday arising from his own carelessness, followed by the sudden suspicion that he had been duped. They moved from the armory at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street yesterday to the new quarters at Forty-ninth Street and Broadway. Maurice Barrymore, who is playing in "A Ward of France," which has just closed an engagement at the Columbus Theatre, received last night cable dispatches from his daughter, Ethel Barrymore, and from Lawrence Irving, a son of Sir Henry Irving, announcing their engagement. WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Immediately after the reading of The Journal in the House to-day, Representative Star (Pop., Neb.,) rose to a question of privilege to deny a publication in a local paper stating that he had acted as attorney in the pension case of Jackson W. Cheney. As a Representative, he said, he had interested himself in the case, but he had never acted as a pension attorney in his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Appropriations considering the urgent deficiency appropriation bill, decided to-day to eliminate the provision inserted by the House requiring owners of bullion to pay transportation on it from the Assay Office to the mints.

The biographical sketches make very spicy reading in many instances, and in some would cause anybody but a Chicago Alderman to crawl into the smallest kind of a hole.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15. -- According to the report given out to-day by Manager D.C. Twitchell, the total receipts of the Yale-Princeton football game were $28,396.77, and the expenditures $4,231.35. Princeton and Yale each received $12,082.71 as their share of the net receipts.

His testimony was in the nature of a refutation of the contention that the commission frequently had no eligible lists from which to supply vacancies in the various branches of the Government service.

The order of Justice George P. Andrews, allowing large additional compensation to the Commissioners for the "opening, widening, and extending of Elm Street," has aroused a keen public interest in the whole matter of street openings. PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 15. -- A jury in the United States District Court has returned a verdict of guilty in the case of Edward Kilfeather, a well-known Democratic politician and I.H. Taffe, who have been on trial for jury bribing. J.W. Walker, indicted on the same charge, had already pleaded guilty and C.S.L. Bratton had confessed to accepting a bribe from Taffe.

The first meeting of the Justices of the Municipal Court under the new charter was held in the Eighth District Court, in the Grand Opera House Building, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, yesterday afternoon. The object of the meeting was to elect the President and Secretary of the board, adopt rules to govern cases which are to come up before them, and such other matters as are not provided for in the charter.

The last number of Le Journal Officiel of France contains statistics which have moved the French people to expressions of great enthusiasm. The births in France for the year ending March, 1896, have exceeded the deaths by 93,700.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Consignments of one-hundred-dollar silver certificates are being received daily at the Treasury Department, but so far the number of counterfeits is surprisingly small. Up to this time only eighteen have been reported from all sources.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Postmaster Van Cott of New York arrived here to-day, and to-morrow will have a conference with First Assistant Postmaster General Heath regarding the proposed reduction in the number of daily mail deliveries in the residence portion of New York. With Postmaster Van Cott, were Charles S. Fairchild, Warner Miller, Benjamin F. Tracy, and James T. Sparkman.

Dwight L. Moody yesterday closed his series of meetings at Carnegie Hall. One of the clergymen who assisted the evangelist said that the week of effort had "closed in a burst of glory." Ushers who seated the people or found them standing space under the balconies or along the walls and on the stage, estimated that 8,000 persons heard Mr. Moody at the two services.

The morning session of the West Side Court was drawing to a close yesterday when the door opening into the hall which leads from the prison was suddenly thrown open and a solemn and sad-faced procession of twenty-three crap shooters, all colored, filed into the room. They were arrested in a raid made by Detectives Boyle and Maxson of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station on a crap game at 304 West Thirty-eighth Street Saturday night.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- The International Navigation Company has decided to organize a company to engage in the Klondike and Pacific Coast trade. The company will be called the Empire Transportation Company and Clement A. Griscom will be its President.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- The annual report of Controller James A. Roberts, which will be submitted to the Legislature this week, embraces an exhaustive discussion of the taxation question. He takes the position that direct taxation for the support of the State Government is unnecessary, and presents additional arguments in support of the proposed graded inheritance tax as a substitute for the annual tax on personal property, which he advocated last year.

James O'Neil, another of the scurvy-stricken crew of the bark Pactolus, died yesterday at the Hudson Street Hospital. The first death was that of a Japanese sailor named Camille, who died early Saturday at a Japanese boarding house at 126 Cherry Street, two hours after being taken there.

In The Lancet Dr. W.S. Colman has a very interesting article with diagrams, on "Color Hearing." BOSTON, Jan. 16. -- The eighty thousand or more skilled operatives employed in about seventy of the chief cotton mills of the New England States will come to-morrow under the sweeping order of a new wage scale which entails a reduction of 10 per cent. or a little over.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Jan. 16. -- Benjamin Butterworth, Commissioner of Patents, died here this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- The launching of the Japanese warship Kasagi, which is building at Cramps' shipyard, will take place on Thursday at noon. The Kasagi is the most important ship ever built in the United States for foreign account, and is the first foreign warship launched in this country since the Zobiaca, in 1878.
CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- During a fire at the Methodist Book Concern to-day someone in the crowd called out to a fireman: "Why don't you take a Bible away and read it? It might do you good."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16. -- The body of five-year-old Percy Lockyar, who is believed to have been murdered Friday night by fifteen-year-old Samuel Henderson, was found to-day in the bottom of Reddies Creek, Sixtieth and Catherine Streets.

Over a thousand members of Branch 36 of New York of the National Association of Letter Carriers held a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, to protest against the proposed dismissal of same sixty letter carriers in consequence of the deficiency in the appropriation for the service. There was also present a delegation from the Brooklyn letter carriers.

James Law, forty years old, of 132 Fifty-fourth Street. Brooklyn, went through an exciting experience late Saturday night and came near losing his life. He wanted to take a Brooklyn elevated train at Fifth Avenue and Sixteenth Street, and one came in just as he reached the station. He tore up the stairs, paid his fare, and rushed breathlessly out on the platform just as the train started.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 16. -- Miss Elizabeth Van Wyck Anderson, daughter of the late Gen. Anderson, Chief Engineer of the Northern Pacific Railroad, and niece of Mayor Van Wyck of New York, plunged into Puget Sound last night with the intention of committing suicide.

Heber Newton, rector of All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, in his midwinter course of sermons on "Christianity in Evolution," took yesterday morning for his text, "I am not come to destroy, but to fulfill." His discourse was complementary to that of the previous Sunday. He said that the question before the Churches was whether the coming religion is to be a new religion or a new Christianity.

The annual meeting of the Hebrew Technical School for Girls was held yesterday afternoon at the school headquarters, 267 Henry Street. The Board of Trustees was shown through the school, which was in operation, reports for the year were read, and officers were elected for the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Hawaiian annexation treaty will occupy the major portion of the time of the Senate this week. It appears improbable, however, that the treaty will be taken up to-morrow. There is a unanimous agreement to vote upon the Immigration bill to-morrow, and it is altogether probable that this vote will be preceded by some discussion of the merits of the bill.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- A series of short sessions with little business is anticipated in the Assembly this week. The Assembly committees have been slow in organizing, and a majority of them will not be ready to transact business until the latter part of the week.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners at their meeting yesterday afternoon received and accepted a report from the committee to which on Dec. 18 last was referred to ascertain and report whether it was practicable to obtain a bond of $15,000,000 under Section 34 of the Rapid Transit act, and, if it were deemed impracticable by the committee, to report what security could, in its opinion, be obtained from responsible bidders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Wolcott of Colorado, Chairman of the International Bimetallic Commission, discussed the work of that body for an hour and a quarter, in a speech to the Senate to-day. The galleries and floor of the chamber were crowded, many members of the House being among those present.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 17. -- There was only a five-minute session of the Carter court-martial to-day, held for the purpose of adjourning to Augusta, Ga., to take the testimony of Mason Twiggs, a former Inspector and Assistant Engineer. Mr. Twiggs is suffering from consumption and could not come to Savannah. He is expected to testify to-morrow with regard to the quality of mattresses and stone that went into the river and harbor work.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Dock Commissioner O'Brien arrived here to-day to take the first step in a proposed plan to turn the Erie Canal ever to the Federal Government. He has just returned from Washington, where he has been to look into the matter and have a bill introduced, if possible, in Congress.

ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 17. -- The Maryland General Assembly will begin at noon to-morrow to ballot for a United States Senator to succeed Arthur Pue Gorman, whose present term expires in March, 1899. That a Republican will be chosen is reasonably certain, but who the lucky man will be is a matter of the greatest uncertainty.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- If the Governor and Legislature approve of the plan suggested by the commission to reorganize the National Guard there will not be any gold-laced staff appointed by the Governor from the ranks of men who have never served as privates.

The annual report of Controller ROBERTS contains a sound and convincing exposition of the defects of our present system of taxation, with a most unwise and inadmissible suggestion of a remedy for the same. It is a mark of progress when the chief financial officer of the State of New York shows that he possesses enlightened ideas as to the absurdity of the attempt to levy a tax on personal property.

An opera first night in mid-January is a social anomaly, accustomed as are New Yorkers to the first notes of the operatic song birds at the season's opening in November. The opening, therefore, of this Winter's short opera season at the Metropolitan last evening had almost the charm of novelty.

Richter's Sons, at 627 Broadway. The increased rate of import duty on the common grade of kid gloves is declared to be the principal cause of this failure.

Experiments, involving the examination of no fewer than 1,000 students, both in their freshman and in their senior years, to ascertain with scientific exactness their physical and mental traits, have been in progress at Columbia University for three years past, and will not be completed far several years to come.

Mrs. Ella Bassett Washington, one of the nearest descendants of George Washington's family, died of pneumonia yesterday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock at her residence in the Parker apartment house, 123 West Thirty-ninth Street, after a protracted Illness.

TRENTON, N.J. Jan. 17. -- Short sessions were held to-night in both houses of the Legislature. In the House Mr. Allen of Hudson introduced an equal taxation bill similar in its provisions to the bill defeated last year and the year before.

The Post Office in Corona, Borough of Queens, was entered by burglars early yesterday morning and robbed of $100 in cash and $110 in stamps. The office safe was opened with dynamite, and the explosion not only blew it to pieces, but demolished the inside of the Post Office. Every window was broken, and part of a window frame was blown into the street.

The Hotel Association of New York City gave its nineteenth annual banquet last night at Delmonico's. Four hundred hotel keepers and guests sat down to dinner. The guests included Federal officials, Senators, Judges, municipal officers, and private citizens.

In the trial yesterday before Judge Newburger, in the General Sessions Court, of Bruno Bretschneider, manager of the Broadway Garden, charged with keeping a disorderly house, Joseph I. Ott, who was indicted with Bretschneider, admitted that he had sworn falsely when at a hearing some time ago before a referee, who had been appointed by the State Commissioner of Excise, he affirmed that the garden was a respectable place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Thomas E. Moore, the commercial agent of the United States at Weimar, announces that the German Government is about to establish a commercial high school at Magdeburg, an important manufacturing city in Prussia. The Germans have borrowed this idea from the United States, just as their idea of technical schools was successfully borrowed by us.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday afternoon considered the estimates for running expenses submitted by the heads of a number of departments and municipal officials. Among the departments for which estimates were submitted were the Mayor's Office, Municipal Assembly, (including City Clerk,) Department of Finance, borough offices, Law Department, Department of Taxes, and Bureau of Municipal Statistics.

The will of the late Julia Bedell of this city was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The petition gives the value of the personal property at $65,000, but places no value on the real property. Frederick de Peyster Foster and William Harmon Brown are named as executors.

Bradlee P. Strong, Adjutant of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, was last night elected Captain of Company D by the narrow majority of three votes over his opponent, Capt. McCrystal. The vote stood 23 to 20. Five members of the company did not vote. There was some display of feeling when the result was announced, and Col. Smith ordered one of Capt. McCrystal's supporters from the room.

Society, ablaze with jewels, and in gay apparel, met at Mrs. William Astor's late last night, after the crowds that helped initiate the season at the Metropolitan Opera House had seen the curtain fall on the last act and started on their various ways, for the most important private dance thus for this season.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Assemblyman T.P. Sullivan to-night introduced in the Assembly his bill of last year, requiring persons or associations doing business as private bankers in cities of the first class to file bonds for the security of depositors. Cecilia Lehunte, a school teacher twenty years old, fell from the roof of her residence, at 13 St. Mark's Place, yesterday and was instantly killed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Secretary Alger was able to sit up for a short time to-day, and is said to be otherwise in improved condition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- This was District of Columbia day in the House, but only three bills of local importance were passed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Wolcott has spoken, but the country has not learned from him nor from any of his associates on the Bimetallic Commission where the instructions were obtained that justified the Commissioners in offering to "reopen" the mints of the United States to the free coinage of silver at the ratio of 15 1/2 to 1.

The Merchants' Association has addressed a letter to the Postmaster General at Washington protesting against the proposed curtailment of the free delivery system in New York and the other trade centres. It is proposed further to send a letter on this subject to each member of both houses of Congress, as well as to the President and members of the Cabinet.

A Parisian newspaper has published the official report, made to the court-martial which condemned Capt. DREYFUS, on the evidence submitted in the case. The report seems to answer to what, in our military procedure, would be the summing up of the Judge Advocate. The Judge Advocate is not in theory a prosecuting officer, but an adviser of the court.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 17. -- The following bills of general interest were introduced to-night in the Senate:

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Both Houses of the Legislature held brief sessions this evening. The Senate passed three bills introduced by Mr. Nussbaum, bearing upon the project for the erection of a union passenger station in this city, and also Mr. Ellsworth's bill appropriating $27,500 for the contingent expenses of the Legislature.

Mrs. Louisa Lukes, who was arrested in the Manhattan Hotel on Sunday for not paying a bill of $33 which she had contracted, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday and found herself in fresh trouble.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -Senator Parsons tonight introduced a bill providing for uniform ordinances in the different municipalities for the government of bicycling. It stipulates the ordinances which such municipalities may enact. They may provide that bicycles shall have lamps which can be seen 200 feet ahead; but this shall not be required if the rider is not going faster than six miles an hour if he has a bell signal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Postmaster Van Cott of New York was an early visitor at Postmaster General Gary's office to-day and conferred with the Postmaster General, the First Assistant, Mr. Heath, and Chairman Loud of the House Post Office Committee concerning the proposed cut in mail deliveries to four per day in the residential sections of the large cities.

BOSTON, Jan. 17. -- The United States has purchased of the Battery Heights Land Company of Hull 347,748 square feet of land on Battery Heights, formerly known as Cushing Hill, Hull, and commanding a view of the ocean.

PARIS, Jan. 17. -- A free anti-Dreyfus and anti-Semite meeting to-night at the Tivoli Vauxhall produced extraordinary scenes. The neighborhood was paraded by the police, mounted and on foot, and the rapidly growing crowd increased the excitement. At 9 o'clock, on the opening of the meeting, the hall was a seething sea of humanity, crowding every part, gesticulating, shouting, "A bas Zola!" "Vive Parmee!" and "Vive la revolution sociale!"

Runk, against the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, involving the question whether the heirs of a man who commits suicide when in sound mind can recover on an insurance policy. The Court held that they could not.

The decision of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board in the case against the persons concerned in the track shortage at the six days' race lays the brunt of discipline on Amos G. Batchelder, who is the official handicapper of the New York League of American Wheelmen State Division, and was one of the referees at the race.

A good bit of detective work was done by the Headquarters men in Brooklyn during the past four days. WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Senator Morgan occupied the attention of the Senate during the entire time of the executive session to-day in the presentation of his views on the subject of the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Senate Committee on Finance voted to-day to report to the Senate the Teller resolution declaring for the payment of the National bonds in silver as well as gold, the resolution practically being the same as the Stanley Matthews resolution adopted by the Senate years ago.

PRAGUE, Jan. 18. -- The Bohemian Diet to-day was again the scene of turbulence. Dr. Wolff, on arriving, announced that a German student had been assaulted in the street, whereupon all the Germans rose and violently demanded satisfaction, calling upon Gov. Coudenhove to resign, on the ground that he is incapable of governing Bohemia.

" Economy" was Mayor Van Wyck's watchword at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment. "The cost of administering the affairs of the new city," he said, "should not be any greater than was the cost last year of running the governments of the municipalities and towns that are now a part of Greater New York."
The attendance at the Sportsmen's Exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night was the largest since the show began, about 4,000 persons being present.

Affairs of Wertheimer Co., importers of kid gloves at 610 to 614 Broadway, who made an assignment on Monday, are expected to show no important development until the arrival of Mr. Warnier of J. Warnier P. David from Paris on Saturday or Monday next.

While chasing an underground trolley car down Madison Avenue, Frederick H. Lincoln, one of the youngest and most active of the Police Bicycle Corps, was thrown from his wheel and instantly killed at Sixty-third Street and Madison Avenue, at 8:50 last evening. Julius Herschberg of 157 East Seventy-ninth Street, with whom Lincoln was in collision, was badly injured, and is under his doctor's care and the supervision of the police at his home.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 18. -- The Maryland General Asssembly began, at 11:30 o'clock this morning, to ballot for a United States Senator to succeed Arthur Pue Gorman, whose term will expire in March, 1899.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- The annual meeting of the State Bar Association opened this evening in the Assembly Chamber. President Edward G. Whitaker in his annual address advocated the biennial sessions of the Legislature as a means of reducing the amount of legislation which finds its way to the statute books of the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Cuba had a hearing in the House to-day, and for a time it looked as if parliamentary precedents would be set aside and a resolution recognizing the insurgents as belligerents would be attached as a rider to the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill.

ALBANY, Jan 18. -- The Legislature will be called upon to consider two bills relating to imprisonment for debt, both of which are in the interest of the poorer classes of the City of New York. One of these measures is intended to relieve poor debtors from imprisonment in certain cases, and the other is to enable workingmen to put their employers in jail in default of payment of their wages.
Hall J. How Co. have sold for Mr. Helen R. Russell to a builder for improvement the plot southwest corner of Madison Avenue and One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 100 by 110.

The twenty-first annual meeting of the Jewelers' League was held in Masonic Hall, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, last evening. The annual reports of officers and of the Executive Committee were presented, and an election was held for a President for one year, and for two Vice Presidents, three members of the Executive Committee, and three members of the Advisory Committee for two years.

President Feitner of the Department of Taxes and Assessments was very much incensed yesterday when some one called his attention to a card which has been sent to lawyers by former Tax Commissioner Theodore Sutro, and another sent broadcast among taxpayers by a law firm the name of which Mr. Feitner refuses to make public.

The draft of a bill for the general amendment of the jury laws, so far as they affect the large cities of this State, and intended to remedy defects and hardships which, in the opinion of business men, now exist, is being prepared, and will be submitted to the New York Legislature during the present session.

The Municipal Assembly met for the third time at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The work in the Council proceeded smoothly on the whole, but in the Board of Aldermen there was some trouble, owing to a greater or less disregard of the rules of procedure that had been adopted at the previous session.

Mr. WOLCOTT has made his long-promised and carefully prepared speech on his experience as a bimetallic petitioner in Europe. He is by far the most capable man in the silver party, and the leader of the faction that still retains connection with the Republican Party. He was Chairman of Mr. McKINLEY'S commission, and is credited with guiding if not wholly dictating its action.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 18. -- The Liverpool Chamber of Commerce gave a banquet this evening to the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies. Lord Strathcona and Mount Royal was also present.

The Salvation Army, after fighting in the courts for a year, has at last succeeded in establishing its right to hold open air meetings with cornet accompaniment in the streets of Greenport, L.I., although there is an ordinance against it. The fight began in the Justice's court of Southold, and went through the County Court of Suffolk County up to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn.

Richard V. Harnett Co. sold, yesterday, at the New York Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, 10 shares Lawyers' Title Insurance Company, $100 each, at 155 per cent., and 50 shares Norfolk and South ern Railroad Company, $100 each, at 62 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- United States Senator William Mason of Chicago was the victim of an unpleasant affair in the office of the Hotel Johnson this evening, when he was assaulted by the clerk, after some words over securing a room for the wife of one of Senator Mason's Chicago friends, who was passing through the city.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Both houses of the Legislature held brief sessions to-day, and adjourned until to-morrow. In the Assembly, Senator Ellsworth's bill, appropriating $27,500 for contingent expenses of the Legislature, passed by the upper house last night, was read, progressed to second and third reading, and finally passed, being the first measure of the session to get through both Senate and Assembly.

Six people were rescued from a burning building at 250 Adams Street, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, by Fireman John Silk of Truck No. 3, who has rescued or assisted in the rescue of fifteen other persons since he became a fireman. The building is two stories high, and the lower part is occupied by Vincent Villani, a papier-mache manufacturer.

The Social Reform Club, at its meeting at 28 East Fourth Street, last night, received a report of a special committee on industrial insurance, and afterward discussed the subject of "Direct Primaries." President Charles H. Spahr presided.

Contrary to expectation, owing to the length of time the jury had remained out, John J. Hannigan the policeman of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station who has been on trial before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, on the charge of assault in the first degree for shooting Charles McNally, seventeen years old, was convicted yesterday of assault in the second degree.

The Charity Organization Society, at its regular monthly conference yesterday morning, in the Fourth Presbyterian Church, corner Fourth Avenue and East Twenty-second Street, discussed the work that will be taken up by the National Conference of Charities and Corrections, to be held in this city May 18.

The scandal in the construction of the large timber dry dock at the Navy Yard, officially known as No. 3, continues to grow, and from present appearances there promises to be a lively and interesting time when the engineers are brought before the court to answer the many questions which are now being prepared.

In an opinion written by General Appraiser George H. Tichenor the Board of Customs yesterday overruled the protest of Charles P. Coles of San Francisco in a case which involved an uncommon contention. The protest was against the assessment of duty at 67 cents per ton upon an importation described in the invoice as "Abercrave large double-screened anthracite coals."

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Interest in the second day of the great contest of the cotton industry of New England centred almost entirely in the strike at New Bedford. The disturbances in that city yesterday afternoon and last evening led to the belief that a similar demonstration might be attempted to-day, but nothing of the kind occurred.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Jan. 18. -- The Senate committee to-night began its investigation into the charges of bribery made by Representative Otis during the recent Senatorial contest. The members of the House committee appointed to investigate the same charges were invited to be present, but they did not participate officially, and there will be two separate investigations.

Elizabeth Marbury, the American representative of the Sir Augustus Harris estate, was most emphatic yesterday, when spoken to regarding the production of "The Telephone Girl" in London this Spring by the Lederer McClellan Company. She said that she was thoroughly familiar with the law, and is quite confident this firm cannot make the production.

About one hundred trap-shooting enthusiasts assembled at the grounds of the Cobweb Gun Club to witness the Bronx Borough Handicap at live birds, which was decided yesterday afternoon at Baychester. Among the experts who participated were Capt. "Jack" Brewer, Fred Gilbert, Aaron Woodruff, Thomas Morfey, Ferdinand Van Dyke, and Frank Class.

Sir MICHAEL HICKSBEACH goes even further than Mr. BALFOUR, since he says plainly that Great Britain will go to war, if necessary, to prevent the exclusive occupation of any Chinese ports by any one European power.

According to the financial statement of the State Commissioner of Excise, the receipts for liquor tax certificates, after deducting County Treasurers' fees and the expenses of the Excise Department, amounted last year to $12,205,524, of which one-third, $4,068,508, went to the State Treasury and the other two-thirds, $8,137,016, was retained by the counties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- According to information obtained from Senators, the discussion on the Hawaiian annexation treaty in executive session only moderately reflects the efforts being made outside the Senate to promote support for that convention. It is admitted by its supporters that there is no assurance that the treaty will be ratified, but every effort that can be put forth is being exerted to overcome the opposition.

Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S scheme of a grant outright in favor of the British West Indies does not seem to find much favor in Great Britain. It was not to be expected that it would. For half a century Englishmen have been trained to regard any interference with commercial and industrial competition as a kind of immorality.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- The Quigg Primary Election bill, the provisions of which have already been outlined in these dispatches, was introduced in the Senate by Mr. Ford this morning, and referred to the Committee on Judiciary. This committee also has before it the Brush and Pavey bills on the same subject.

PARIS, Jan. 19. -- There were renewed police precautions to-day to prevent disturbances. The bridges from the Latin Quarter were guarded by police, and the residences of MM. Mathieu Dreyfus and Emile Zola were patrolled. A small mob of students assembled outside the Law School, with the usual cries; but the police prevented a serious demonstration.

The fifteenth annual ball of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum Society was given last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and was one of the most successful ever given by the society. A considerable sum was netted, and the proceeds in part will be appropriated for a technical school in the institution.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- A bill to authorize the Secretary of the Treasury under certain conditions to purchase the Kansas Pacific Division of the Union Pacific Railroad was introduced in the House today by Mr. Fleming of Georgia, a member of the Pacific Railroads Committee, to which the bill is referred.

The principle of the measure is sound enough, as we have frequently argued, but the scope it will have is relatively limited.
