The forty-fifth annual meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers was begun yesterday morning in the new house of the society, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street. Benjamin M. Harrod of New Orleans, the President, opened the meeting with a short address of welcome to the members.

PAULSBOROUGH, N.J., Jan. 19. -- The residence of Congressman Loudenslager, on the river front, was entered by burglars last night and ransacked. The burglars packed up for removal nearly a wagonload of goods, including the Congressman's clothing, a lot of shoes, bric-a-brac, and valuables.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- One office which the Legislature will be called on to fill this Winter is that of State Superintendent of Pubic Instruction. The election does not occur until Feb. 10, but Superintendent Charles R. Skinner is already conducting a quiet canvass for re-election, and the attention of the legislators is being thereby attracted to the subject.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19. -- At the annual meeting of the Franklin Institute, held in this city this evening, a paper on "Tests of the Synchronograph on the Telegraph Lines of the British Government," was read. The paper was a report to the Postmaster General. It was made by Albert C. Crehore, Assistant Professor of Physics at Dartmouth College, and Lieut. George O. Squier, U.S.A.

Formerly there was no School Board in Richmond, the schools on Staten Island being under the supervision of the Union Free School District Board, a State body.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chancellor of the Exchequer, speaking at Bristol this evening, ridiculed the notion of providing granaries as had been suggested in some quarters. He said he was convinced the British Navy was strong enough to hold its own, and in any war England would have many friends ready to supply corn.
LONDON, Jan. 19. -- The Very Rev. Henry George Liddell, the former Dean of Christ Church, Oxford, died here to-day. He was born in 1811, and was at one time Chaplain to the Prince Consort.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 19. -- Capt. Murphy, who was on trial in the United States District Court charged with filibustering in connection with the steamer Laurada, was to-day declared not guilty by the jury.

SOUTHPORT, N.C., Jan. 19. -- Cadet Wilde, in an open boat, with a crew of five men, from the revenue cutter Morrill, arrived here at 10 o'clock to-night after a null of twenty miles through the darkness and rain.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- President Ripley of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe has written a letter to the editor of a Kansas Populist paper, replying to a communication published in that paper, citing the number of people killed by the railroads of the United States as a reason why the railroads should be put under Government control.

HAVANA, (via Key West, Fla.,) Jan. 19. -- Since Saturday the rioters have been quiet, with the exception of a dynamite bomb exploded in the Plaza de Colon, which did no harm. The rumors that the volunteers would revolt against the Government have had no foundation. Nevertheless, on Saturday and Sunday several Generals arrived here from Matanzas Province and the outlying portions Havana Province with additional reinforcements.

Wheeler, a cattle dealer, of 540 Bergen Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- A spirited debate was precipitated in the Senate to-day by the introduction of a resolution by Mr. Hoar of Massachusetts providing for an inquiry by the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads concerning the recent order of the Postmaster General, reducing the force of letter carriers in several cities of the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Senator Morgan continued his speech in advocacy of the ratification of the Hawaiian annexation treaty in the executive session of the Senate to-day. WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- All day long the question of granting belligerent rights to the Cuban insurgents was argued in the House, but as on yesterday, the minority, hurled itself against a stone wall.

Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott has increased hopes that the reduction in the delivery service which was ordered last week will be set aside, and that New York will not be made by Congress to suffer for the shortcomings of the Post Offices of other cities. The orders of the department last week were that $24,000 be saved in the carrier service of the New York office before July 30.

Notwithstanding the fact that the town of Newtown does not exist any longer, and is only part of the Borough of Queens, undertakers are still compelled to pay $1 for every burial permit issued in the town.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Hallet Kilbourn, one of the oldest and best-known business and newspaper men of Washington, to-morrow will be examined in lunacy proceedings with a view to his confinement in an asylum.

The Amherst Alumni of the City of New York held their annual dinner last evening at Delmonico's, Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue. William Ives Washburn, President of the Alumni, presided, and at the end of the dinner introduced Professor Olds of the College, who spoke in the place of President Gates, who was unavoidably absent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The currency hearing before the House Committee on Banking and Currency continued to-day, ex-Secretary Fairchild being heard through the morning, with the understanding that Secretary Gage would resume at 2 o'clock. The inquiries of Mr. Fairchild were along the line of developing the degree of success with which the Monetary Commission bill could be put into practical operation.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- The Japanese warship Kasagi was launched at Cramps' shipyard at 12:57 P.M. to-day. The programme was carried out as previously announced, but the exercises were marred by a heavy rainstorm. Miss Helen Long, daughter of the Secretary of the Navy, christened the ship, but, instead of breaking a bottle of champagne on the prow, she released six doves from a basket as the vessel began to slide down the ways.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- James McDonald, believed to be the ringleader of the trio of alleged forgers whom Detectives Kane and Duffy arrested at 1,223 Wabash Avenue last Friday night, is said to have carried on his operations in nearly every large city in the United States.

In the Central Presbyterian Church, at 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, Miss Elizabeth Van Valzah Wilson, daughter of the late Rev. Dr. and Mrs. J.D. Wilson, was married to John Alden Philbrick. The officiating clergyman was the Rev. Dr. Wilton Merle Smith, pastor of the church.

Mr. CARL SCHURZ makes an excellent point, in the current number of Harper's Weekly, upon Hawaiian annexation. He calls attention anew to the fact, which has been called attention to before, that weare the "chartered libertine" of civilized nations, and are permitted to do things which would not be permitted to any other power.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senate has under consideration a nomination that may be rejected, with some embarrassment to the Postmaster General, and possibly with annoyance to the President, where there might have been neither. The Postmaster at Fort Monroe, appointed by President Cleveland, has served the term for which he was chosen, and it had become necessary to name some one to succeed him.
CAIRO, Jan. 20. -- The Dervishes made a raid yesterday north of Atbara. They were repulsed with the loss of five men killed.

We gave the other day the opinions of four Senators that nothing would be done for currency reform in the Senate. These Senators were one fairly sound money Republican, one silver Republican, one silver Democrat, and one gold Democrat. In ordinary circumstances their adverse judgment must be taken as conclusive.

To escape punishment at the hands of his father for having spent nearly $8, representing two weeks' wages, in treating a number of other boys to drinks and theatre tickets, Irving A. Taylor, the fourteen-year-old son of Irving C. Taylor, a coffee roaster of 570 Evergreen Avenue, Williamsburg, tied a handkerchief tightly over his nose and mouth, laid himself down in a doorway, and concocted a story that he had been robbed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Spanish Minister received a cablegram from Gen. Blanco, confirming the preceding dispatch and giving the details as there stated. Gen. Blanco says the form of presentation was of such a dignified character as will serve as a model for those to follow. The cable continues:

Many wheelmen of the greater city are desirous of having the National League of American Wheelmen meet held in New York in 1899, and the consuls of the local league division have taken up the matter. The privilege of holding the meet has always given rise to lively contention, as it is considered of great benefit to business and real estate.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Senator Guy said to-day that he was not surprised at the action of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in turning down the item of $500,000 for the Grand Concourse. He thought the board did exactly the right thing, he said, and he explained that its action was in harmony with his bill now before the Senate establishing a commission to superintend the construction of the concourse and approach.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- William Brookfield of New York appeared at the Capitol this morning just as the legislators were assembling. He went to the office of State Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn, where he remained for a short time, going from there to the Governor's office accompanied by Mr. Payn.

SANTA FE, New Mexico, Jan. 20 -- Articles of incorporation have been filed with the Territorial Secretary of the White Oaks and Kansas City Railway. The incorporators are J.A. Eddy, W.A. Hawkins, H.A. Connor, C.L. Christie, and W.H. Austin. The Directors are C.D. Simpson, Scranton, Penn; B.S. Harmon and G.C.W. Lowry, New York; John A. Eddy, Denver; C.B. Eddy, W.A. Hawkins, Max Frost, New Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- President McKinley's policy toward Cuba and Spain, as announced by Mr. Hitt yesterday in the House, at first creating excitement, now causes only conjecture. Those persons who hope to see the Administration intervene to stop the war in Cuba, assumed at the outset that a war was near at hand.

The Tammany Government is well advised in making the very utmost of any mistakes that may have been made by its predecessor. Mayor VAN WYCK on Wednesday had two occasions to criticise the action of the previous administration. He availed himself of both to the full, and it must be said that upon each occasion he appeared to be in the right.
ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Senator Cantor to-day introduced two bills drafted by the Canalboat Owners' Association for the protection of the commerce of the State and of the canals.

When the action taken by the congregation of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Wednesday was reported to the Rev. Dr. John Hall, he expressed himself as much pleased. He declined to say if the resolutions adopted and petitions presented would induce him to reconsider his decision to resign from the pastorate, and said there would be time enough to reply to the committee when they waited upon him officially.
The twenty-ninth annual dinner of Sorosis took place last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, and more than one hundred members and their guests sat down at the small tables in the Astor Gallery.

HAVANA, Jan. 20. -- The Spanish authorities report that the insurgent Gen. Juan Masso Parra, with the forces under his command, Lieut. Cols. Augustine Feria and Jose Carmen Hernandez, Majors Feliciano Quesada, Saturnino Leon, and Victorano Gomez, with six other officers and 110 privates, well armed and well supplied with ammunition, have surrendered at Fomento to the Spanish Gen. Aguirro and Senor Marcos Garcia, Governor of Santa Clara Province.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 20. -- Ex-United States Marshal Neely and deputies began to-day levying on the real estate of the Leavenworth, Kansas and Western Railroad, formerly the Old Kansas Central Railway, to satisfy a deficiency judgment held when the rolling stock and roadbed were sold in November last to satisfy the mortgage of the Union Trust Company of New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The proposition for biennial sessions of the Legislature is to receive serious consideration at the hands of the present body. Gov. Black, who has urged the change in both of his annual messages, is actively furthering the movement to have the project submitted to the people, and the whole Executive influence will be exerted to put it through this session.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- The long-continued controversies which have been fought in the courts of Delaware, New York, and Massachusetts from time to time over the control of the Bay State Gas Company and gas companies absorbed by it, all of which are in this immediate vicinity, are at an end to all appearances.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- At a lengthy executive session of the Senate Finance Committee to-day Assemblyman Nixon's Canal Investigation bill was discussed informally. The impression seemed to prevail among the Republican Senators, and was expressed by several of them, that the bill was crudely drawn, and would have to be amended in some particulars before it would be acceptable to the Senate.

Prof. Willis B. Moore, Chief of the United States Weather Bureau at Washington, was the speaker of the evening at the Drawing Room Club, which held its regular monthly meeting last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He spoke on "Air and Storm Phenomena," and prefaced his remarks by explaining the utility of the Weather Bureau. He said in part:
As was announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES about a month ago, the art collections of Mr. Charles A. Dana will be sold by auction next month.

BOSTON, Jan. 20. -- The sum total of today's new features in the textile troubles was the shutting down of the Cabot mill at Brunswick, Me., because of desertion of help in sympathy with striking weavers, and the announcement that a small mill of the Social Manufacturing Company at Woonsocket, R.I., would shut down for a few days for lack of orders.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Assemblyman John A. Weekes, Jr., went to New York this afternoon to attend a conference on primary election reform to be held at the City Club to-morrow evening. Messrs. Seligsberg and Laimbeer will go to the metropolis to-morrow for the same purpose.

A perplexing problem has presented itself to the Chinese residents of this city. They have not been able to make up their minds whether their New Year's celebration should begin to-day or to-morrow. The Chinese Minister at Washington has issued a proclamation declaring that to-morrow shall be celebrated instead of to-day, and that the Chinese residents in this country have for the past forty-eight years begun celebrating a day too soon.

The National Primary Election Reform Conference met in the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation at 10:30 A.M. yesterday. There were present about fifty delegates, and it was apparent that the Committee on Arrangements had succeeded in bringing together a body of men representing all sections and nearly all the States.

One of the heaviest fogs of the Winter settled down over the city early yesterday morning, and hung over it like a heavy. drab mantle throughout the day. It grew thicker and darker as the day wore on, until at noon it was impossible to see more than a short distance. The mist was accompanied by a drizzling rain, which increased to a violent shower at 10 o'clock, followed at noon by a thunder storm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) introduced a resolution directing the Secretary of the Interior to send to the Senate the full and explicit charges made against Mrs. M.E. Roberts, who recently was dismissed from the Pension Bureau.
ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Senator Ellsworth to-day introduced his so-called "Anti-Cartoon bill." It is not, however, strictly an Anti-Cartoon bill, but rather a libel measure.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 20. -- Orders have been received at Esquimault by Rear Admiral Palliser from the Admiralty instructing him to have every vessel in his fleet ready to start for China on forty-eight hours' notice.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Assemblyman Brennan of Kings to-day introduced a bill providing for a new bridge over the East River, to be erected by a commission composed of Benjamin F. Tracy, Frederick A. Schroeder, William Berri, Silas B. Dutcher, Hugh J. Grant, Seth L. Keeney, and the Mayor and Controller of the City of New York.

NEWPORT, Jan. 20. -- The engagement of Miss Blanche Tuckerman of this city, granddaughter of Joseph Tuckerman, whose villa faces Touro Park on Mill Street, near Bellevue Avenue, to M.A. Cherettier, a well-known banker of Paris, has been announced.

Another Spanish officer upon whom was imposed the task of seducing Cuban soldiers from their allegiance has met the fate of Col. RUIZ, but for some rather mysterious reason his death does not create a ripple of excitement, and even the Spanish authorities do not lift their hands in horror. Yet Capt. PUGA seems to have been just as much of a "herald" as RUIZ was.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Arthur W. Pinero's new four-act comedietta "Trelawny of the 'Wells'" was produced this evening at the Court Theatre. It is a brilliant play, mirthful and fantastic from first to last, brimming with close observation of character and wit and fully sustaining its author's reputation.

Mayor Van Wyck, at yesterday's meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment gave warning to the heads of the departments that he would not permit the least extravagance in the administration of the affairs of the new city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senators who to-day supported the motion to take up the Stanley Matthews resolution to pay the bonds of the United States in silver do not expect to see the resolution passed by the House.

District Attorney Gardiner received yesterday a letter from a woman in England, who signed herself Maria Statham, saying that her daughter, Emily, had been married in 1881 to a man whom the writer believed to be Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor now in the Tombs, pending the carrying out of a sentence of six months in the penitentiary for assaulting his wife, the daughter of Peter De Lacy.

I have read from your issue of the 17th inst. the article entitled "The Publication of the Pension List," and, as a veteran of the late war, I hereby desire to express my thanks for the position you have taken upon this important question.

The most important captures of green goods men that have been made in a long time were effected yesterday under the leadership of Anthony Comstock of the Society for the Suppression of Vice. One arrest was that of John Reedy, Postmaster, Tax Collector, telegraph operator, and station agent of the New York and Putnam Railroad at Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Senator Morgan concluded his four days' speech to the Senate in executive session to-day on the Hawaiian treaty. He spoke for almost four hours, and when he finished there were not more than half a dozen Senators present. He discussed, among other questions, the character of the present Government of Hawaii.

Russell Sturges addressed the American Society of Civil Engineers last evening on "New Relations Between Engineering and Architecture." The address was delivered in the new house of the society, 220 West Fifty-seventh Street, at the concluding session of the forty-fifth annual meeting. Vice President E.P. North presided and introduced the speaker.

Under the direction of the Princeton Club of New York the Princeton alumni had their annual dinner last night at Delmonico's. Graduates of the university representing nearly every State in the Union and classes as far back as 1843 were among the 300 who sat at the fourteen tables in the big banquet hall.

The Cologne Gazette's statement of Germany's Chinese policy fortunately comes concurrently with the announcement of the arrival of two good British men-of-war at Kiao-Chau. It behooves the United States to take more than a general interest in this matter, for the law expounded at Berlin is not the law that has been insisted upon at Washington.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- In the Court of Appeals this afternoon Joseph H. Choate argued on behalf of Norman S. Dike, receiver of Field, Lindley, Wiecher Co., to set aside as fraudulent against creditors the transfer of $130,921 by Edward M. Field, a son of Cyrus Field. Mr. Field was charged with wrecking the firm and later was confined in an asylum.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Miss Anna Hughes, a member of the American Volunteers, who acts as private secretary to Commander Ballington Booth, was felled from behind by a man while on the way to her home from the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad station in Orange on Thursday evening of last week.

The third concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was one of the most delightful entertainments which that delightfully entertaining organization has ever given here. It was attended by a large audience, which, according to a time-dishonored custom, spent most of its enthusiasm upon the solo features.
James Kyle Sons have sold the five-story flat, 312 East Forty-fourth Street, 25 by 85 by 100; also, the three-story dwelling, with two-story brick building at the rear, 25 by 100.

The new Republican County Committee met last night, in the United Charities Building, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue, and adjourned without organizing, to meet on the evening of Feb. 3. Congressman Quigg called the committee to order, and Charles H. Murray was made temporary Chairman. When the roll was ca-tied a contest vas announced in the Sixth -sembly District.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 20. -- The interesting budget statement just made by M. de Witte, the Russian Minister of Finance, shows an actual deficit of over 106,000,000 rubles, which is covered by the free balance in the Treasury.

The meeting held last night at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn for the purpose of protesting against the reduction of the mail-carrying service was a decided success. The big building was crowded long before the meeting was called to order. A large number of the letter carriers attached to the Brooklyn Post Office were in attendance.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- The Minister of the Interior, M. Barthou, at a Cabinet meeting to-day informed his colleagues of the measures taken to prevent street demonstrations. He added that the proposed demonstration on Sunday will be prohibited.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The third annual report of the State Commission of Prisons was presented to the Legislature to-day. The total number of prisoners in the penal institutions under its jurisdiction on Oct. 1, 1897, was as follows: State prisons, (Including female prison,) 3,203; New York State Reformatory, 1,525; House of Refuge for Women, 408; penitentiaries, 3,768; jails, 4,366. Total, 13,270.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Democrats in the House to-day continued their efforts to secure a vote on the Senate resolution recognizing the Cuban insurgents as belligerents. They came no nearer success than they had come the two previous days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The resolution offered yesterday by Mr. Hoar Mass.) inquiring of the Postmaster General what action was necessary to maintain the excellence of the postal free delivery service was agreed to in the Senate to-day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Street railway interests of Illinois, banded together at the Great Northern Hotel on Jan. 5 as a State Association, have prepared a bill for submission to the Legislature, which will, if passed, make the duration of every street railway franchise in the State ninety-nine years.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 20. -- The General Assembly of Maryland in joint session to-day took three ballots for a United States Senator without result. They were as follows:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, via Galveston, Tex., Jan. 20. -- The Nicaraguan Congress today declared illegal the change of the name of the Bank of Nicaragua to the London Bank of Central America, and the proposal to change the domicile of the institution from Nicaragua to London. Congress restricts the bank to its banking privileges under its charter.

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 20. -- The expected advance in rates to Alaska has been announced. The several transportation companies who control nearly all the business have agreed on an increase of $10 to the passenger rate between Puget Sound points and Dyea and Skaguay, and a proportionate increase to Juneau and other southeastern Alaska points.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Teller resolution, providing that Government bonds may be paid in standard silver dollars, was taken up in the Senate to-day, on motion of Mr. Vest, (Dem., Mo.) Mr. Vest's motion antagonized a previous motion by Mr. Lodge, (Rep., Mass.,) that the Senate go into executive session.

The Von Funcke story told in The Pall Mall Gazette is surely a colored, theatrical light cast on a familiar tableau. The mistress stealing from her paramour his secret is a descendant of Delilah. One version is in Robert Browning's poem, "The Confessional." The Von Funcke tale more nearly resembles one told of Gen. Washington while in this region during the Revolution --fully related in a pamphlet dear to collectors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Assistant Secretary Vanderlip has decided to require local Inspectors of Hulls and their assistants and local Inspectors of Boilers and their assistants to pass a civil service examination to test their fitness to hold the positions they now occupy.

-- All the English ship-certifying societies -- Lloyd's, the Bureau Veritas, and the British Corporation -- have been notified by the President of the English Board of Trade that they will soon be asked to send representatives to a meeting at which the much discussed Winter load-line rule will be again considered. It is evident, therefore, that the prospects are good for some change in the existing regulations.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 21. -- The famous Hillmon insurance case was settled to-day, so far as the claim against the New York Life Insurance Company is concerned. Hillmon was insured in this company for $10,000, but upon what basis the compromise was made cannot be ascertained, as the attorneys on both sides refuse to talk.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- The Asen Wheelmen of New York City were incorporated to-day. In the certificate it is stated that the club is formed to "teach its members not to abuse the pleasures of cycling, and not to carry it to an excess; for it is well known that improper cycling is injurious to individuals, and hence may become a public nuisance."

Charts of the human body, culture tubes, disease charts of the city, and other scientific paraphernalia in the room of the Household Economic Association, in the Industrial Building, in Lexington Avenue, yesterday marked the progress which the association is making in its thorough study of the subject of domestic science and healthful living.

Ever since you so increased the already great value of your paper by adding THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART to the Saturday issue I have been in the habit of constantly clipping therefrom articles too valuable to throw away, with the wish to keep them in my scrapbook. But, alas! several times from their very number I have given up the task and tried to keep the papers themselves.

The knowledge has come to me of how one poor, book-loving woman collects another bits of literature for her children, and the plan seems so well worth following by others that I beg a few moments of your valuable time to relate it.

The Society of Colonial Wars of the State of New York held its sixth annual banquet last night at Delmonico's. The attendance Was the largest in the history of the organization. Frederic J. De Peyster, Governor General of the society, acted as toastmaster and introduced the speakers.

The delegates to the National Primary Election Reform Conference spent a busy day yesterday. They held long morning and afternoon sessions, listening to and discussing more than a dozen speeches and papers, and attended a reception at the City Club at night, when they heard and made still more speeches.
PARIS, Jan. 21. -- During the debate in the Chamber of Deputies to-day on the estimates of the Department of Public Worship, M. Berard denounced the "dangers of clericalism."

That was a wonderfully graphic and picturesque expression that fell from the lids of Mr. JAMES W. BOYLE, the Vice President of the new East River Bridge Commission, as he seated himself in the presiding officer's chair of that body. The old Commissioners had just been removed in a lump by the Mayor, but they did not know it.

In justification of the seemingly large increase in the appropriation demanded by the Police Board, which called for over $13,000,000, President York yesterday made a statement as to the needs of his department, and declared that as a matter of fact the appropriation asked for was little in excess of the total appropriated last year for the territory embraced in the new city.

RUTLAND, Jan. 21. -- Luther Swift of North Pawlet, some twenty-five miles from this city, drove to Granville two days ago, and was on the sleigh in front of a flouring mill when a 6 o'clock whistle sounded.

Yesterday's stock market was weak in the first hours of business, strong later, and then weak again at the close. Fluctuations in most stocks were, however, within comparatively narrow limits. Professional sales for both accounts kept the market under pressure, but in only a few stocks was this selling productive of declines of consequence.
Mayor VAN WYCK is making friends and gaining the confidence of the public by his stern censorship of the department estimates.

Mr. Henry Norman's "The Real Japan" and "The Far East" are to appear in new editions. The work on Japan will be enlarged and the late naval and military development of the country presented. Mr. Norman is now at work with a new volume, the title of which is "The Near East," which will be ready this Spring.

Dartmouth College graduates from all sections of New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and Connecticut met at Delmonicos last night at the thirty-fourth annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association of New York. It was distinctly a gathering of alumni, and nearly four-fifths of the total members were present.

ALBANY, Jan 21. -- Senator Wilcox to-day introduced the codification and revision of the State prisons law prepared by the Statutory Revision Commission. The bill proposes little radical change in existing laws except to provide uniform methods of government for all penitentiaries, to provide for the release on parole of prisoners transferred from the Elmira Reformatory, and to make more explicit the powers of the prison commission.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- At 12:30 o'clock to-day, two Italian laborers, whose names are not known at present, were killed by an explosion of dynamite in the canal three-quarters of a mile west of Canastota. The explosion was so severe that windows were broken in Canastota.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 21. -- About 500 skilled mechanics employed by the Globe Iron Works Company in its shipyard refused to work with non-union men to-day and walked out. Senator Hanna is one of the chief owners of the company. All the men employed at the Globe Shipyard are union men.
At the Sportsmen's Exposition, in Madison Square Garden, the most interest now is centred in the shooting and bowling tournaments.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Attorney General McKenna to be Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- H. Morgenstein, a New York traveling man, was found dead to-day in his room at the Palmer House. Heart failure is said to have been the cause of death. He registered at the hotel a week ago. He said he represented a New York clothing house, and carried with him a stock of samples. A day after his arrival he complained of feeling ill.

The distinctive term in the popular criticism of Browning's works is "obscurity." The verdict has been brought in. "Yea, verily, he is obscure," and the pedants call the quality the master's virtue, and the superficial call it his crime. Coleridge's definition runs thus: "An author is obscure when his conceptions are dim and imperfect, and his language incorrect, inappropriate, or involved."

At the meeting of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall, which met for organization yesterday afternoon at the Wigwam in Fourteenth Street, the organization through Richard Croker put itself on record as opposed to any form of loot, either by extravagance in the administration of the city's affairs or in the establishment of sinecures for the members of the organization.

Perhaps no more original and suggestive criticism of modern fiction has lately been made chart the one contained in the address of Mr. A.J. Balfour, published in your SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART for Jan. 8. I refer to his observation that the novelists have made little attempt to show the natural development of character through life.

" The Story of Christ," by Elizabeth Stuart Phelps, adds one to the long list of the many melancholy failures which have resulted from the attempt to do the impossible. The old legend of the artist's effort to paint in the face of Christ, in which he failed and failed, until at last, while he slept, an angel filled in the empty place on the canvas, ought to warn people against this vain undertaking.

PARIS, Jan. 21. -- The Minister of Commerce, M. Boucher, to-day received a deputation representing the manufacturers and business men of several departments, who urged that protective duties be imposed upon oils and oil seeds. M. Graux, President of the Customs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies, the spokesman of the party, said America was swamping the European markets with cheap oil seed, thus causing a big break in the prices of industrial securities.

SING SING, Jan. 21. -- Clinton S. Arnold, who some time ago purchased Mount Murray, just south of Sing Sing Prison, thinks he has discovered a valuable silver and copper mine on the north side of the hill. He was informed by some of the old inhabitants that about sixty years ago there was a silver mine on the hill, but the opening had been gradually filled up.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Judge Dallas in the United States Circuit Court to-day ordered a non-suit in the case of Charles H. Despeaux against the Pennsylvania Railroad Company for alleged discrimination in rates for carrying oil in 1881, 1882, and 1883. The plaintiff is the surviving member of the firm of Fenaille Despeaux, oil refiners in France, which firm purchased its crude oil in the United States.

William Brookfield, leader of the new movement to contest with Senator Platt and his friends the control of the party in the State, returned yesterday from Albany, where he had been to confer with Gov. Black with regard to the proposed primary election law and the general political situation.

The British declarations and demonstrations in respect to China have already had one good effect. They have forced Russia into showing her hand. The English offer, if it has been made, of negotiating the Chinese loan, has for its purpose not to but China under special obligations to England so much as to relieve her of special obligations to Russia.

Mayor Van Wyck criticised most of the budgets brought before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday afternoon Coroner Fitzpatrick, for his associates, informed the board that it did not know anything about the needs of the Coroners. "You'll find out that we do when we get through with the budgets," said the Mayor.

NEWARK, Jan. 21. -- John F. Steinbrenner, President of the Chapin-Hall Lumber Company, died this morning at his home, 108 Mount Pleasant Avenue, from the effects of an overdose of laudanum. Mr. Steinbrenner was found unconscious by a servant, who notified the family. Dr. Floyd McEwen was called and efforts were made to counteract the effects of the poison, but Mr. Steinbrenner died at 9 o'clock.

Not a few bankers deprecate the step taken by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank in reducing loans on real estate mortgages to 4 per cent. A well-known bank President, who declined to have his name used, characterized the action as an error of judgment, tending to unsettle loans and banks, and asserted that there was no necessity for it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The stormy scenes of the previous few days in the House were followed by comparative quiet to-day. Under the rules this was a private bill day, but on motion of Mr. Cannon, Chairman of the Committee on Appropriations, the House considered the Senate amendments to the Urgency Deficiency Appropriation bill. With the close of its first twelve months the Free Circulating Library for the Blind has issued a report of its operations. From a collection of 500 volumes, fairly representing literature's wide range of subject and of form, it reports that its patrons choose relatively few books of fiction; that more interest is shown in poetry, and that religious works are in large demand.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 21. -- Richard J. Halloran, a policeman, was fatally shot with his own pistol an hour after midnight to-day by Miss Nellie Mangan, who then, it is alleged, turned the pistol on herself and put a bullet in her brain. The shooting followed a quarrel, during which Miss Mangan begged Halloran to marry her.

HAVANA, Jan. 21. -- According to information from Spanish sources, Gen. Castellano, being aware that the insurgent Government was established at Esperanza, in buildings constructed by the insurgents, seventeen leagues from Puerto Principe, at the extreme west end of the Cubitas ridge, proceeded in that direction with 2,200 infantry, 400 cavalry, and two field cannon.
PARIS, Jan. 21. -- M. Ernest Bazin, the inventor of the roller steamer, is dead.

The Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution held a special meeting last night at the Windsor Hotel to consider amendments to the Constitution, principal among which were two designed to do away with the system of making nominations through a committee, and substituting, instead, the plan of having nominations made direct, at the annual meetings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Senate today referred to the Committee on Civil Service and Retrenchment the resolution of Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) asking the Secretary of the Interior for papers concerning the dismissal from the Pension Office of Mrs. M.E. Roberts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Bishop W.E. McLaren of the Episcopal Church, has resigned the Deanship of the Western Theological Seminary, a place which he has filled since the establishment of the seminary in 1854. The position was left vacant and the position of warden created with practically the same duties.

Mathieu Dreyfus, the brother of the convicted officer, ex-Capt. Dreyfus, has absolutely collapsed. That is astounding about the whole business is that on such a slender thread so many presumably intelligent people should have sought to hang so weighty an accusation.

He was followed by Paul E. Twiggs, who had been an Inspector under Capt. Carter. This witness gave testimony similar to that already heard.

In one case a thirty-three-pound weight fell fifteen inches and produced a permanent compression of 0.1658 inch in a copper cylinder, the time consumed in producing the compression being 0.0030317 of a second.

TALNI, British India, between Amrasti and Nagpur, Jan. 22. -- The observations of the eclipse of the sun by E.W. Maunder and C.T.H. Waites were most successful. The sky was perfectly clear and light. During the middle of the totality it equaled a full moon. The general shape of the sun's corona was the same as in the eclipses of 1886 and 1896.

The klipspringer, or klipbok, as it is often called by the Colonists, seems, like the chamois of Europe, to be created for no other purpose than to complete and adorn a mountain landscape. Although smaller than its distant cousin of the snowy Alps, the klipspringer yields neither to it nor to any other mountain dweller in the world in the ease with which it can get about the most difficult and dangerous rocks and precipices.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 22. -- The managers of the vaudeville theatres of the circuit of which the Star Theatre of this city is a member, decided at a meeting last night to stand by the "road managers" with whom they have been doing business for years. This action was taken when communications were read from two New York syndicates, which offered to book them for forty weeks each year.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 22. -- Isaac Schwartz, the President, was ejected from the Bes a Medrush Hagudel Synagogue after he had made a stormy protest against Rabbi Lavine to-day.

A representation of "Adelaide," a touching and beautiful drama dealing with the romance which inspired Beethoven's immortal love song, is to be given on Tuesday afternoon, Feb. 1, at the Fifth Avenue Theatre for the benefit of the New York Kindergarten and Camp Mission Kindergarten Associations.

LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Business houses have had their American business hampered by the recent erratic arrivals of the mails. Complaints in past times were made against the British Post Office, it being claimed that mails were sent by British subsidized lines instead of by the fastest vessels, when more than one mail steamer was sailing on the same day.

In celebration of its twenty-two years of usefulness, the Legal Aid Society gave a dinner at Delmonico's last night to 150 of its members and friends. It is intended that a similar function be held annually. The object of the dinner was to demonstrate the scope of its charities in the past and the desirability of its continuance and further extension in the future.

Freedom of speech is not one of the benefits enjoyed by the German people under the rule of William II. If there were any doubt upon this matter it would be set at rest by the very interesting statistics which have recently been published as to the number of prosecutions for lese-majeste. Since the young Emperor took the control of affairs into his own hands proceedings for offenses against his "consecrated person" have increased enormously.

Three matches were decided by the members of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club at the Armory last night. The Class Match, the conditions of which are seven shots standing and seven shots prone, all scores having the same numerical value, to constitute a class, was productive of some excellent shooting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- In the House to-day Mr. Hitt, Chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, submitted a privileged report from his committee recommending the passage of a resolution of inquiry, requesting the State Department, if not incompatible with the public interest, to transmit to the House all information in its possession relative to the military execution of Col. Ruiz, a Spanish envoy to the insurgent camp of Aranguren.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Senator Cullom to-day introduced a bill for the amendment of the inter-State commerce law. The bill is intended to cover the defects of the present law as indicated by the courts. It gives the Inter-State Commerce Commission authority to prohibit any railroad company or other common carrier from charging more for a long than a short haul over the same line.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 22. -- Several hundred residents of the towns of Oyster Bay and North Hempstead, and that part of the town of Hempstead outside of New York, held an enthusiastic meeting in Allen's Hotel this afternoon. The object was to take steps toward the formation of a new county on Long Island.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22. -- The annual junior promenade will be held this year on the evening of Feb. 11. The Casino will be handsomely decorated, a New York orchestra has been engaged, and a caterer from Philadelphia will furnish the refreshments. Among those who will act as patronesses is Mrs. Grover Cleveland.

THe success of M. Chartran in painting portraits over here has been heard of in France and several other French painters have resolved that he shall not be alone to gather the spoil from les rastaqouieres of America and from the ordinary millionaires of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- In the House to-day, Mr. Bailey, the Democratic leader, created something of a flurry by rising to a question of personal privilege, in connection with his controversy with Speaker Reed at the close of the Cuban debate last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. McCall of Massachusetts introduced a joint resolution in the House to-day appropriating $163,000 to meet the deficiency in the free delivery service of the Post Office Department for the current fiscal year. The appropriation is to be immediately available, and is intended to offset the threatened reduction in the number of letter carriers and deliveries in many cities.

The scientific collections presented to Yale University last week by O.C. Marsh, Professor of Paleontology at that seat of learning, are pronounced by him to be "in many respects the most extensive and valuable in this country." Prof. Marsh's aim since 1866 has been to build at Yale a department of paleontology that should be a school of original research as well as one of instruction.

In Germany the productive area is equal to no more than eight acres per farming hand; in the Western States it is sixty-two acres. Once more there is a revival of the proposition to remove the United States Mint from Philadelphia to this city. At various times during the past century there have been attacks upon the policy that maintains the mint in the city which was once the capital of the Republic. For obvious reasons, chiefly those relating to the expense of a removal, the project has never been authorized by Congress.

Two deaths occurred on the voyage of the steamship Campania, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, and both bodies were buried at sea. Early on Tuesday morning Mrs. Maud Burrows, thirty-eight years old, of Nottingahm, England, died from syncope. The same day, shortly after noon, she was buried at sea.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 22. -- Astelle, who was one of the most valuable brood mares in Kentucky, has died at the home of her owner, J. Breckinridge Viley, and August Belmont's Sultana is now the last living daughter of Lexington. Astelle was out of Mary Churchill, whose sire was Alex Churchill.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- Civil service in Chicago has received a backset, and the rejoicing which followed the Supreme Court's decision sustaining the validity of the law has been turned into mourning. Chief Justice Phillips, one of the dissenting Judges when the law was upheld, has issued a writ of error to the United States Supreme Court as a supersedeas.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 22. -- The Maryland Legislature in joint session to-day took another ballot for a United States Senator, which resulted as follows: McComas, 46; Shaw, 16; Findlay, 8; Shryock, 2; Gorman, 46. Total, 118. Necessary to a choice, 57.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22. -- San Francisco gossip centres upon the Klondike excitement, the Golden Jubilee parade week's festivities, and the recent bloodless warfare in the social world.

The proposition to establish a Board of International Records was urged several months ago, but the League of American Wheelmen manifested considerable apathy toward the movement, in spite of the general approval accorded the project by racing men and numerous league members.

HAVANA, Jan. 23. -- The official Gazette publishes the autonomical Government's manifesto. This declares that the Government confines itself to the task of preparing a new government policy, with and for the people, on conditions that will insure stability and thus remedy radical public evils, autonomy being the settlement and reparation inaugurated by the fatherland.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- There is promise of plenty of excitement in the Assembly this week to make up for the previous inaction of this body of the Legislature. The trouble will arise over the canal investigation question, and in the battle over it the Democrats will endeavor to show that they have strength enough to make themselves felt throughout the session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Private letters from Indianapolis indicate that the business men's convention which will be held in that city Tuesday and Wednesday of this week will be attended by a larger number than was present at the convention of a year ago. The purpose of the convention is to indorse the report of the Monetary Commission, which provides a comprehensive plan for a reform of the currency.

The bill which Mr. GAGE has had introduced into Congress to give authority for the coinage of fractional silver coins is, perhaps, not of prime importance, but it is a sensible and practical measure which should be passed promptly.

Louis Dietz, proprietor of the Metropolitan Park and hotel at Flushing and Metropolitan Avenues, East Williamsburg, was instantly killed early yesterday morning by a live and detached electric light wire in front of his hotel.

Seven Indians of the wildest Western variety created excitement in Brooklyn yesterday, although their designs were of the most peaceful and even pious description. Four of them, Big Casino, Crazy Bear, Spotted Bull, and Hailstones-in-His-Stomach, were Cheyennes, and the other three, Three Crows, Bull Tail, and Pawnee Killer, were Sioux.

SKAGUAY, Alaska, Jan. 7. -- Thirty persons have arrived here during the last week from the Klondike mining region. They say there is food enough at Dawson to last until the Yukon River is open and navigation is resumed. Supplies must be received by that time, though, if suffering is to be averted.

Capt. The Russian Students' Society of New York, which is composed of Russian students in American colleges and Russians who are graduates of American or Russian colleges, held an anniversary celebration last night to commemorate the foundation of the University of Moscow. The celebration was held at the headquarters of the society at 220 Henry Street.

Democrats were reticent yesterday about the outcome of Richard Croker's visit to Hugh McLaughlin on Friday. This much, however, is known: Mr. Croker did not succeed in getting the Brooklyn leader to recede from the position that he has taken with regard to the distribution of municipal patronage.

ALGIERS, Jan. 23. -- Anti-Jewish riots were renewed here to-day. The mob invaded the Jewish quarter and pillaged the shops in the Rue Babazoum, driving the Jewish merchants into the streets. A squadron of Chasseurs was ordered to the scene, and charged the mob with drawn swords, but the mob re-formed further on, cheering for the army.

An Armenian reception carried out in all its Oriental details, was given Saturday night by Mr. and Mrs. Gullabi Gulbenkian to a large number of their compatriots and several Americans, at their apartments, in the San Remo, Seventy-fifth Street and Central Park West. The Rev. Dr. John Hall, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, announced yesterday morning that in obedience to the will of the congregation as expressed at the congregational meeting last Wednesday night he would continue to be pastor, withdrawing the resignation which he had offered.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- President Sanford B. Dole of Hawaii and his party arrived in Chicago about 8 o'clock this morning.

Watson, Jr., twenty years old, of Rochester, N.H. The circumstances and the stories of the eye witnesses indicate that the shooting was accidental, but Coroner Bausch, who has charge of the case, has some suspicion that the exact truth has not been told.

This announcement was supplemented by the statement from a confidant of Richard Croker that Mr. Croker had said that the bill sure to pass the Legislature. CINCINNATI, Jan. 22. -- Before the Legislative Committee that is investigating charges of bribery against Senator Hanna, Allen O. Myers, Jr., clerk at the Gibson House, testified yesterday that he overheard Boyce, the man alleged to have attempted to bribe Representative Otis, talking to Columbus and arranged to have Boyce use the telephone in the private office on the second floor while Miss Jacobs, stenographer, and himself listened at the telephone down stairs.

SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 23. -- Masons all over the world agree that George Fleming is one of the greatest swindlers of modern times. Fleming is now in the State Penitentiary. He has confessed to have systematically swindled Masons of high degree the world over.
ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Factory Inspector Daniel O'Leary has completed the twelfth annual report of his department. Various matters of interest to working people are discussed in the report.

PARIS, Jan. 23. -- It is agreed on all sides that Saturday's scene in the Chamber of Deputies was almost without precedent, except the recent disturbances in the Austrian Reichsrath. Curiously enough, Count Badoni, the former Austrian Premier, witnessed it.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- Dispatches from New York printed here to-day tell how a man calling himself Epps and professing to be a son of the English cocoa manufacturer, has taken in a number of New Yorkers, including members of the Appleton Publishing Company and the Century Company, by borrowing money of them and not paying his debts.

PARIS, Jan. 23. -- In anticipation of the prohibited anti-Dreyfus demonstration today, under the direction of the Organizing Committee of the anti-Dreyfus meeting at the Tivoli Vauxhall last Monday night, stringent measures were taken by the authorities to preserve order. The Place de la Concorde and the Gardens of the Tuileries were held by detachments of cavalry and infantry and large forces of police.

Gen. Shryock drew out of the fight to-day and declared himself unequivocally for Judge McComas's election.

ALGIERS, Jan. 24. -- Further rioting occurred here at 9 o'clock this morning, when it was learned that a Jew had stabbed a Spaniard. A mob gathered, attacked and looted the Jewish stores. Governor-General Lepine personally intervened in order to induce the rioters to desist from further disorderly conduct.

Billot, will prohibit all officers from testifying at the trial of Emile Zola, who is to be prosecuted by the French Government for bringing serious charges against high officials in connection with the Dreyfus case. Gen. Billot himself will attend the trail in full uniform to make the "necessary defense of the army's honor."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 24. -- After taking twenty ballots to-night, the Democratic caucus called to nominate a candidate for the United States Senate adjourned until to-morrow night. Gould to President Alexander El Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission explaining the willingness of the Manhattan Railway Company to make certain extensions of its elevated system was discussed at a meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners in their office at 257 Broadway yesterday afternoon.

As the speeches were limited to five minutes each, many members participated, and partisan spirit kept the interest keyed up to a high pitch.

Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, was indicted for perjury by the Grand Jury yesterday. He will be arraigned to-day to plead to the indictment before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions.

William J. King appeared before Recorder Goff, in General Sessions, yesterday, and pleaded guilty to burglary, first degree, first offense. He made this plea on advice of his counsel, Glanvil McIntyre. The Recorder then sentenced the defendant to three years in State prison.

MADRID, Jan. 25. -- Admiral Chacon, the Admiral of the fleet, arrived here to-day and had a long conference with Admiral Bermejo, the Minister of Marine. He asserted that the recent evolutions had demonstrated the perfect condition of the fleet.
Horace S. Ely Co. have sold, for Isaac H. Bailey, the three-story dwelling 124 East Twenty-eighth Street, 20 by 98.9.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- A bill embodying the Democratic plan for the proposed canal investigation was submitted to the Senate Finance Committee to-day by Senator Cantor.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 25. -- The small two-masted filibustering steamer Tillie of New York was abandoned at sea last Sunday afternoon while off Barnegat. CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- January wheat sold at $1 to-day. The price was bid up 5 cents in as many minutes by brokers acting for the Leiter crowd, who, it was believed, took this method of advancing the price of May. January closed at 97 1/2, an advance of 2 1/2 cents. May closed at 3/8 cents advance after many erratic fluctuations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Spanish Minister, Senor Dupuy de Lome, had little to add to-day to the Cuban status. He expressed much satisfaction with the present condition of affairs, all his advices indicating quiet at Havana and a hopeful outlook. The Minister received a long letter from Secretary General Congosto, reviewing recent events.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 25. -- M. WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Two dispatches were received at the State Department this afternoon. One from Consul General Lee said that the Maine had arrived at 11 o'clock and that all was quiet in Havana. The other was from Capt. Sigsbee and merely said, "Maine arrived."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- In the Senate to-day there was a heated, almost acrimonious discussion of the financial question. For nearly four hours the Teller resolution, providing that Government bonds may be paid in silver, was under consideration. The sharpest colloquy at times was indulged in between the advocates and the opponents of the resolution, the debate often approaching bitterness.

Davis, providing that no corporation shall charge a greater price for gas than the lowest price charged by such corporation for lighting any other private dwelling or business establishment within the same city. The American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers commenced its fourth annual meeting at 12 West Thirty-first Street yesterday. A session was held in the morning, one in the afternoon, and another last night. It is intended to continue in this order throughout to-day and to-morrow.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 25. -- The Democratic caucus to-night took twenty ballots for a candidate for the United States Senate and adjourned without breaking the dead-lock. Congressman McMillin gained one vote on the first ballot, and Gov. Taylor gained two votes on the third ballot from Turley. On the next ballot Gov. NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 25. -- The old freight steamer Tillie was well known at this port. The bill, in addition to increasing the number of Justices, makes radical changes in the tenure of office of the clerks and assistant clerks and materially reduces the salaries of the latter.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- The inter-State joint convention of bituminous coal operators and miners came to an end at 10 o'clock to-night. The miners were jubilant over the results of their ten days' session, for it means to nearly 200,000 soft coal miners an advance of 10 cents per ton and a uniform day of eight hours at uniform day wages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A substantial addition to the relief fund being collected for the Cuban sufferers at the State Department was received to-day through Senator Hoar, who handed to Secretary Sherman a check for $6,014 sent him by George H. Lyman of Boston, the trustee for a public collection in that city.

By the confession of Alexander Ciaramello his cousin, Angelo Carbone, now in the death chamber at Sing Sing Prison, convicted of the murder of Natalio Brogno, has in all probability been saved from the electric chair. He was sentenced to be executed in the week beginning Feb. 7, but the case had been appealed, and a stay would probably have been granted.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Rev. E.D. Bailey, chief clerk of the Examiners' Office, Civil Service Commission, submitted some sensational testimony at to-day's session of the Senate civil service investigating committee. It was a sequel to the charges he made Monday of intimidation and interference by the commission with his testimony.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Lord George Hamilton, Secretary of State for India, speaking this evening at Chiswick, said he thought that during the course of the next twelve months the Government might take steps to establish a gold standard for India.

Wall Street was most agreeably surprised in the preliminary annual statement for 1897 issued yesterday by the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. It showed less shrinkage in gross receipts than had been anticipated, while net earnings were larger than had been foreshadowed, showing an actual increase of over $420,000, despite all the discouraging conditions that have prevailed in the coal trade.

A number of men within the last few weeks have been defrauding several firms in the dry goods district, and now that the swindlers have disappeared, their victims are making themselves known. The swindlers obtained goods worth several thousand dollars. The principal in the operations called himself Joseph H. Snyder, and represented himself as an export commission merchant, with offices in the Chesebrough Building, State and Bridge Streets.

WASHINGTON Jan. 26. -- All the advices received by the State Department and Navy Department from Cuba to-day were satisfactory. Gen. Lee at 2 o'clock reported that all was quiet and order prevailed in Havana. At about the same hour a cablegram came to the Navy Department from Capt. Sigsbee of the Maine, saying that general interest was manifested on the arrival of the Maine in Havana Harbor, but there had been no demonstration.

It was learned yesterday that the coal barge Yonkers bound from Newport News, Va., to Providence, in tow of the tug Walter A. Luckenbach, had parted her towline last Sunday morning, and it was thought that she had sunk with four men on board. The Luckenbach had in tow the Yonkers and the barge Halycon.

HONOLULU, Jan. 18. -- One of the most radical bills ever brought before a Hawaiian Legislature will be introduced at the coming session, which opens on the 6th of next month. It is to do away with a contract labor law, which has been in force for many years. It is learned that the American planters will favor the bill, but it is anticipated that planters of other nationalties will make a fight.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Pending the appointment of a joint special committee from the Judiciary Committees of both houses to consider the Primary Election bills already introduced, no legislative action is expected in the matter. The friends of primary reform are not inactive in the meantime, however.
Shall we ever obtain a sound and adequate currency system for the United States? If so, when?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- There was a sharp debate in the House to-day due to the failure of the Senate to place in the Urgent Deficiency bill an appropriation for the continuation of the mail carrier service until July 1.

Evidence of a plethora of unemployed money was furnished yesterday in the following letter, addressed to Lester B. Howe, Superintendent of the Produce Exchange, by C.H. Patterson, cashier of the Fourth National Bank, which was bulletined at the Exchange:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The day in the Senate was given up to further consideration of the Teller resolution providing that Government bonds may be redeemed in silver.
