There is a curious misapprehension in regard to the amount of freight money annually paid to foreigners for the transportation of American commerce. For the last ten years it has been estimated in round numbers at $200,000,000, although it is almost needless to say that if that was the approximately correct figure in 1888, it should be considerably larger now.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 31. -- L.S. Miller left on this afternoon. Northern Pacific train for Seattle, and will at once enter upon the duties of General Manager of the Seattle and International Railroad, recently acquired by the Northern Pacific Railroad Company, and formerly known as the Seattle, Lake Shore and Eastern.

Original and increase applications for pensions all come to be considered, at a certain stage before allowance or rejection, by local boards of medical examiners. These examiners ought to be competent physicians, qualified by skill and experience to judge between pretense and fact when upon their decision depends the paying or withholding of money taken from the people to meet the increasing pension appropriations.

President PATTON'S sermon at Princeton on Sunday, reported at some length in yesterday's TIMES, may be fairly taken as an official reply, upon the part of the university, to the unofficial and irresponsible clamor that has been recently raised against it. To some it may seem that this clamor was so senseless that it might have been allowed to "foam itself away."

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Both houses of the Legislature reconvened this evening. No business of importance was transacted in the Senate. In the Assembly the special order was Mr. Nixon's bill to amend the legislative law in relation to the number of copies of bills to be printed, the measure being on the order of second reading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The House of Representatives to-day buried the Teller resolution declaring the bonds of the United States payable in silver, under an adverse majority of fifty votes. The Republicans were solidly arrayed in opposition, with two exceptions, Mr. Linney of North Carolina, who voted with the Democrats and Populists, and Mr. White of North Carolina, the only colored member of the House, who answered "present" when his name was called.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 31. -- Counsel for the defense in the Carter court-martial today made a determined effort to keep out all evidence relative to the contracts entered into by the accused previous to 1896-7. The Judge Advocate placed A.J. Twiggs of Augusta on the stand to recite a conversation held in 1891 with one of the Gaynors about the work done in the Savannah River, near Augusta, during that year.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 1 -- Not since the trials of the Molly Maguires has a case excited so much interest in the coal regions as that of Sheriff Martin and his eighty-two Deputies, which began in the Luzorne County court to-day. Long before he court was called to order the court room was crowded, and it was found necessary to close the doors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The House devoted most of the session to-day to the District of Columbia. Appropriation bill; the bill had not been disposed of when the House adjourned. Some politics were injected into the debate just at the close.

The Board of Education of the City of New York ceased to exist at midnight of Monday night. Its members met yesterday as the School Board of the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx and effected an organization to continue until Feb. 9, when a permanent organization will be effected under the statute.
Do the Democrats from the East desire an issue on which they are bound to be beaten and deserve to be?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Gen. Merriam, under instructions from Acting Secretary of War Meiklejohn, yesterday opened at Seattle the dispatches brought by Special Messenger Wells from Capt. Ray, the department's representative in the Klondike, and forwarded an abstract of them to the War Department by telegraph.

The old building at 64 and 66 Nassau Street was visited twice yesterday afternoon by fire. The first was at 5:18 o'clock, and did about $5,000 damage. The second was about an hour later, and involved a loss of $30,000, drove out two families at the risk of their lives, and gave the firemen a two hours' fight before it was subdued.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 1. -- The Alvord House, the principal hotel of this city, was destroyed by a fire which was discovered at 7 o'clock this morning. Six lives are supposed to have been lost, and several persons were injured by jumping from windows to escape from the burning building.

Louis Alfred Balensi, who is charged in Paris with having swindled the late Max Lebaudy out of millions of francs, and who was indicted in this city, under the name of William H. Bellwood, for swindling Marcus Co., the Union Square jewelers, out of $6,000 worth of diamonds, was called to the stand to testify in his own defense, before Judge Newburger, in the General Sessions Court, yesterday.

Members of the Unity Republican Club Brooklyn, have not yet recovered from a "beefsteak dinner" in which they participated on Saturday night. Pendry and some of his friends in the club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- John W. Griggs, late Governor of New Jersey, who took the oath of office last evening as Attorney General, assumed charge of his new office this morning.

SARATOGA, Feb. 1. -- The worst blizzard Saratoga and the Adirondacks have suffered since March, 1888, raged from early last evening until late this afternoon, and the indications to-night are that the storm will be intensified before morning, as the mercury is lowering and the wind is developing into a gale.

The Board of Health is making a hard fight against the bill introduced in the Legislature by Senator Brush curtailing its powers. It is rumored that several prominent members of the Medical Society of the County of New York, which was responsible for the bill, are now strongly opposed to it, and some of those who were its strongest advocates in the society have entirely changed their views regarding it.
The Municipal Assembly met yesterday and disposed of considerable routine business.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 1. -- The greatest storm known here since 1851 swept the shores of Cape Ann last night and early this morning, causing heavy loss of life and about $200,000 damage. Over a dozen vessels are ashore near here, at least four more are lost, and many others have been badly damaged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Theodore Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, was before the Senate Committee on Civil Service to-day. Speaking of his practical experience, Mr. Roosevelt said that he had found that the civil service system had worked inconceivable improvement. He had observed this both in his position as Police Commissioner in New York and as Assistant Secretary of the Navy.

A meeting of the Directors of the Pan-American Exposition Company was held in the Transportation Club in the Manhattan Hotel yesterday afternoon. The President, John M. Brinker of Buffalo, presided, and submitted an elaborate outline of the departmental organization for the exposition. It is proposed to establish a large industrial exposition on Cayuga Island, in Niagara River, just above the Falls and invest it with some new and original features.
HAVANA, Feb. 1. -- A skirmish between the Spaniards and the insurgents has taken place, it is announced, at the central plantation of Constancia, Province of Santa Clara.

There were contests all along the line last night at the Democratic primaries, in Brooklyn, and the opponents of the Willoughby Street organization won a few victories. In the main, however, the organization was successful. Police Commissioner York's lieutenant was badly defeated, but well-informed politicians deny that this is a personal defeat for York.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The Republican bill providing for an investigation of the canal improvement expenditures by a commission to be appointed by the Governor was considered by the Senate to-day in Committee of the Whole and advanced to a third reading. Several Senators were absent, and Senator Cantor for that reason asked that the bill be laid over until to-morrow, but the majority denied his request.

Clarence True, the architect and builder, is planning the improvement of property along Riverside Drive recently purchased by him on a scale which makes the operation one of special significance and one which will doubtless prove of far-reaching effect.

BLACKFOOT, Idaho, Feb. 1. -- Ex-Senator Dubois, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Silver Republican Party, left for the East to-night at the request of silver leaders to confer with them for the purpose of uniting all silver forces.

The orchestral concert last night in Anton Seidi's series at Chickering Hall was made more than usually interesting by the reappearance here of Franz Rummel, the eminent pianist. This is Mr. Rummel's fourth visit to America. He came here first in 1879, and his last visit was four years ago. He is a Londoner by birth, a German by descent, and has an American wife, who is the daughter of Prof. Morse, the famous electrician.

The conference called by the Democracy of Thomas Jefferson, of which Henry George was the leader in the last election until his death, met in the hall of the Charities Building last night and agreed upon a plan of organization.
There are several things worthy of special note in the burial of the Teller resolution in the House on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The monthly comparative statement of the Government receipts and expenditures shows that for the month of January the receipts aggregated $37,333,628 and the expenditures $36,696,711, leaving a surplus for the month of $636,917.
ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The following bills of interest to New York City were introduced to-day.

We are surprised that the Rapid Transit Commission failed to include the speed of trains in the list of subjects as to which it invited the Manhattan Company to give specific assurances in its application for authority to extend and improve its system. As speed was not mentioned in Mr. ORR's letter, Mr. GOULD was justified in making no reference to it in his reply.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Senator Elkins's prediction concerning the filling of the office of Fish Commissioner has been verified. The President to-day nominated George M. Bowers of Martinsburg, West Va., to be Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries in place of Commissioner J.J. Brice.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 1. -- The Democratic caucus on the first ballot to-night nominated for Senator, Thomas B. Turley of Memphis to succeed himself and to fill out the unexpired term of Isham G. Harris. The ballot stood, Turley, 46; McMillan, 43; Taylor, 1. The joint convention of the two houses of the Legislature will elect Mr. Turley Senator to-morrow at noon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Senate today, in executive session, resumed consideration of the Hawaiian annexation treaty. As soon as the treaty was put before the Senate Mr. Thurston (Rep., Neb.,) made a motion for postponement of further consideration of it until March 1. The motion was voted down without much discussion and without a roll call

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- A man giving the name of Jacob Luthardt called at the Central Police Station this afternoon and announced himself as prepared to accept the twenty-thousand-dollar reward which Police Inspector Michael Schaack offered for the production of Mrs. Louisa Luetgert, wife of the alleged wife murderer.

Eight days ago Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Brown, of 246 Terhune Avenue, Jersey City, had ten children, nine sons and one daughter. The oldest was sixteen, and the youngest an infant. Now the girl and three of the boys are dead. Two other boys are ill, but will recover. The disease that made this havoc was diphtheria.

The consolidation of the Tradesmen's National Bank, in the Wool Exchange Building, and the Clinton Bank, at 87 Hudson Street, was announced yesterday. The officers of the Clinton Bank have transferred the interests of their bank to the Tradesmen's, in the belief that it will be a benefit for all concerned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Orders have been given by Secretary Long to have the big armored cruiser Brooklyn make a cruise through the West Indies, and especially among the Windward Islands, St. Thomas, and Santa Cruz.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- An elaborate dinner was given this evening at the White House in honor of President Dole of Hawaii. The decorations were extremely beautiful. The party was much too large to be accommodated in the State dining room, and the table was laid in the corridor behind the great stained glass screen.

Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave the musicale of the season for the most fashionable set of society at their home, 840 Fifth Avenue, last night. It may in fact be said to have taken place in 842 Fifth Avenue, Mrs. William Astor's half of the house, as well, for the big double mansion was thrown open for the occasion.

Capt. RAY'S report on the condition of affairs in the Klondike, as telegraphed in outline from Seattle, is more depressing than that of Major RUCKER, sent in some weeks ago. It is possible that the telegraphed abstract does not do justice to the report itself. Undoubtedly the most valuable and authentic news from the Klondike is that which THE TIMES printed ten days ago from its correspondent at Dawson.

I have been a constant reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES since its beginning, and have felt a strong desire for some time to express my feelings in respect to its present management, so incomparably superior to that at any period in its history.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Richard Mansfield gave an extempore talk at the Kent Theatre, University of Chicago, to-day, before the Graduate Club and its invited guests. Afterward a reception was given him at the residence of Prof. and Mrs. Judson. Mr. Mansfield severely condemned music halls and cheap theatres. He deplored the lack of a great American playwright, and appealed to the rising generation to devote their minds to the writing of great plays.

The jury in the case of Louis Alfred Balensi returned to the courtroom of General Sessions at 12:30 o'clock this morning, and the foreman told Judge Newburger that it was impossible for them to agree. They were discharged.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Statements that Gov. Morton after his retirement from office had requested Gov. Black to reappoint as Inspector General of the State Gen. McLewee of New York City, who was removed from that position by Gov. Morton because he had criticised in his annual report certain members of the staff of the Commander in Chief, is officially denied in this city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Berlin cable announcing that Germany had closed her ports against American fruits attracted much attention to-day among Senators and members of the House of Representatives.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 2. -- The anti-Quay movement in the Republican Party received an impetus here to-day at a conference held in the Bourse, at which there were present about 400 representative business and party men from all sections of the State. Gen. W.H. Kountz of Somerset County was chosen permanent Chairman.
HAVANA, (via Key West, Fla.,) Feb. 2. -- Spanish military operations continue entirely paralyzed, the season most favorable for movements against the insurgents thus being lost.
SEATTLE, Jan. 2. -- A double murder and lynching have stamped Port Valdes, the town at the mouth of the Copper River, as the most lawless camp on the shores of Alaska.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2. -- The contract for the construction of tunnel 5,700 feet in length on the line of the San Joaquin Valley Railroad has been awarded to Foley Brothers Muir of St. Paul, Minn. The tunnel will enable the Valley Road to reach its terminus at Port Richmond, on San Francisco Bay.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The second card reception of the season was held at the Executive Mansion this evening. Two thousand guests were in attendance. The diplomatic corps were received first, being especially invited to meet President and Mrs. Dole, who were placed between Mrs. McKinley and Mrs. Hobart in the receiving line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Senator White (Dem., Cal.,) continued his speech in opposition to the Hawaiian annexation treaty in the executive session of the Senate to-day amid many interruptions and much crossfire.

The eighth annual banquet of the Society of the Alumni of the City (Charity) Hospital was held last night in the ballroom of the Hotel Savoy. One hundred and twenty-five members and guests of the society sat around the tables, Dr. Brooks Wells, the retiring President, presiding.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- A bill to enable an official who has won a suit to oust him from office or convict him of a crime to recover costs from the county has been introduced in the Assembly by Mr. Oliver.

Yesterday it was colder than on any previous day this season. At 8 o'clock in the morning the thermometer in the Weather Bureau registered 4.8 degrees. New York at that hour was just emerging from the outskirts of the storm centring in the vicinity of Boston, and rivaling the blizzard of 1888.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- The magnitude and severity of the Winter hurricane, which on Monday night and Tuesday morning made a record for itself in Eastern Massachusetts and in Rhode Island, was realized more fully with to-day's revival of business and communication with the outside world after many hours of practically complete isolation.

The Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners, through their attorneys, E.M. Shepard and A.B. Boardman, filed a notice yesterday that they would ask the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for a reargument of some of the questions in the papers and briefs of the counsel upon the motion to confirm the reports of the three Commissioners appointed by the court.

A change made by the new tariff act in the cotton cloth schedule has provoked an earnest controversy between customs officers and importers of Scotch hollands, which are used in the manufacture of window shades. A protest filed by the Pinney, Casse Lackey Company occupied the attention of the Customs Board of Classification yesterday forenoon and afternoon.

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- Dr. S.C. Bartlett, former President of Dartmouth College, appeared before the Genealogical Society today on behalf of his relative, Miss Elizabeth G. Hoyt of Belmont, and asked the society to return to Miss Hoyt the "Breeches Bible," which was presented by her to the Genealogical Society twelve ears ago.

Wagner's "Der Fliegende Hollander" was brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The audience was one of moderate size, and also of moderate enthusiasm. It cannot be said that the lack of enthusiasm was unreasonable. There were some genuine and striking merits in the performance, but there were also some equally genuine and striking defects, and these, no doubt, had a decidedly depressing effect on the audience.

Mr. and Mrs. Elbridge T. Gerry gave a cotillion last night at their home, 2 East Sixty-first Street, to which 250 persons had been invited. It was not so important an affair as several previous dances of the month, but derived interest from the fact of its being restricted mainly to the exclusive set. The guests numbered about 150, and sixty couples danced in the cotillion.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- The Prussian Minister of Finance, Dr. Miquel, issued a decree yesterday, which goes into effect immediately, prohibiting the importation of every kind of American fresh fruit. The decree has been sent to all the German ports and frontier stations, excepting Bavaria, Saxony, and Wurtemberg.

DETROIT, Feb. 2. -- Gov. Pingree took steps to-day toward bringing suit to compel the Michigan Central to carry all passengers at 2 cents per mile. He demanded a ticket to Ypsilanti at the legal two-cent rate, and then paid the full three-cent fare under protest.

It is not in Buffalo and Rochester and other cities, where work is scarce and workers are too many, that the craze is most virulent. It is the villages that are sending out the largest proportionate number of gold seekers.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The closing moments of a very dull session in the Senate to-day were enlivened by Senator McCarren's statement upon a question of personal privilege. Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, who had been absent for several days, came in near the close of the session and assumed the chair.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- A wave of indignation has swept over the press throughout the country at Lord Salisbury's alleged backdown at Ta-lien-wan. Conservatives no less than Liberals bewail the supposed retreat from an unassailable position, on the ground that Great Britain, supported by the United States and Japan, might safely have defied Russia.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 2. -- George Westinghouse, Jr., in a circular letter issued to the stockholders of the Philadelphia Gas Company, asks the latter to place their stock at his option for disposal. In the circular he states that he will not accept less than forty dollars a share, and that he will not accept any less for any one else's stock than he will for his own.

BOSTON, Feb. 3. -- Boston to-day has resumed her normal condition as far as street car and steam railway traffic is concerned. But as far as the general aspect of the city is concerned, it still appears storm-bound. Excepting a few of the downtown thoroughfares, the streets are piled high with snow.

District Attorney Martin made a motion that the jury be taken to Lattimer to view the scene of the shooting. The court denied the motion, saying the jury should be able to get an idea of the situation from the map.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- The Massachusetts Savings Bank Commissioners to-day placed the Framingham Savings Bank under an injunction to prevent it from doing business until further action can be taken. The action followed the arrest of William H. Bird, former cashier of the bank, who in the Framingham Court, to-day, was held under $20,000 bail for the Grand Jury on a charge of misappropriating $9,000 of the bank's funds.

Business in Wall Street was less active than for some time past. But little more than 300,000 shares of stock were traded in, and the market was not as broad as heretofore. Richard Le Gallienne, poet, critic, and writer of short stories, is at the Waldorf-Astoria with his beautiful Danish wife. They arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Teutonic. PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- The announcement was made to-day in connection with the annual exhibition of the Academy of Fine Arts that the Temple gold medals have been awarded to Wilton Lockwood of Boston for his picture, "The Violinist," and to Edward F. Rook of Newport, R.I., for one entitled "Pearl Clouds, Moonlight." Mr. Lockwood's picture recently received third prize at the exhibition in the Carnegie Art Gallery at Pittsburg.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Grable and Mrs. J.M. Latimer, the latter the mother of Mrs. Grable, are occupying a handsome suite of rooms at the Planters' Hotel. The party arrived here on Tuesday. The Grables are registered from New York City and Mrs. Latimer from New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Japan has been removed as an element in the opposition to the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands by the United States. This result has been attained by an agreement between this Government and Japan, as represented by Minister Toru Hoshi, which, by practically settling the status of the Japanese in Hawaii, removes the only substantial difference that has existed between the two Governments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The monthly statement of the Bureau of Statistics shows that the importation of wool into the Ports of Boston, New York, and Philadelphia during December amounted to 17,768,627 pounds, an increase over the November imports of over 7,500,000 pounds, and an increase over October of over 10,600,000 pounds.

The Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners held a special meeting yesterday at 3 P.M., to consider the plan for rapid transit proposed by the Manhattan Railway Company. Underground systems were not discussed, and the commission devoted itself to an examination of the elevated, or overhead, system proposed by George J. Gould.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 3. -- Several months ago the Pittsburg and Western Railroad decided that the business of Clarion, Penn., was insufficient to justify the repairing of a bridge, and the town was abandoned. The residents had to cross the Clarion River and then go a mile and a half to the railroad terminal.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- The parade of decorated sleighs and floats which took place here to-day was the grandest spectacle ever seen in the Adirondacks and was witnessed by about 2,000 persons. The air was filled with the sound of bells, trumpets, and bugles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A brief cablegram from Ambassador White at Berlin that came to the Department of State last evening conveyed the first official information as to the decree of exclusion of American fruit from Prussia.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 3. -- Eight of the sixteen men who went adrift yesterday on an ice floe in Trinity Bay reached land to-night, badly frostbitten. It is believed that the others have been saved.

The conservatism of the people of India is very marked in their reluctance to use their own tea. India produces annually about 137,000,000 pounds of tea. Of this, 132,000,000 is exported, no less than 124,000,000 going to the United Kingdom. Only 5,000,000 pounds, therefore, remain in India for the consumption of 300,000,000 people; while the United Kingdom, with only about 40,000,000 people, takes 124,000,000 pounds.

Mr. Lawrence takes in part payment the five-story flat 466 Amsterdam Avenue, 27 by 90 by 100, and the plot at the southwest corner of the Boulevard and One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 100.11 by 75.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- It was expected that the resolutions censuring United States Senator Murphy for supporting the Teller silver resolution would be considered in both houses of the Legislature to-night. In the Assembly, however, Mr. Weekes, who introduced the resolution in that body, announced that he would call it up at some future day.
COLUMBUS, Ind., Feb. 7. -- George Fry, a well-known farmer, residing near this city, prayed fervently for death yesterday afternoon, and died a few minutes after, concluding his prayer.

Mrs. Sarah A.B. Tappen, the wife of Frederick D. Tappen, President of the Gallatin National Bank, was examined as a witness in supplementary proceedings on Saturday in the office of her counsel, Lord, Day Lord, at 120 Broadway, in an effort to obtain from her knowledge touching the ability of her daughter, Mrs. Ellen T. Adams, to pay a judgment of $10,590.64, obtained against her and her husband.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- It was a day of considerable emotion, but scanty progress, M. Scheurer-Kestner and M. Mathieu Dreyfus were conspicuous in court, and in the audience were several notabilities and many ladies, especially actresses, most of whom were provided with sandwiches and bottles of wine.
PARIS, Feb. 7. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Francois Deloncle, Deputy for Castellane, raised a debate on the Government's foreign policy.
Plymouth Church listened last night to addresses by Thomas G. Shearman and the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott, denouncing the scheme for the annexation of Hawaii.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day I notice an article headed "Tibbetts's Revolt and Doom," which goes on to say, among other things, that the "Governor" has already selected his successor in the Senate.
The Austrian Consul has asked the aid of the immigration authorities in detaining a fugitive from justice. The original request comes from the Austrian military authorities at Cracow.
Voorhees Floyd, in conjunction with J.J. Phillips Co., have sold for Gustave H. Gossler the four-and-a-half-story brick and limestone front dwelling 7 West Sixty- ninth Street, 20 by 60 by 100.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 8. -- Before the trial of Sheriff Martin and his deputies was resumed to-day Judge Woodward stated that he had received an anonymous letter stating that if he did not do certain things something would happen, and a threat was made.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 8. -- William W. Thomas, American Minister to Sweden and Norway for the third time, was received by King Oscar to-day in special audience for the purpose of presenting his credentials from the President.
TRENTON, Feb. 8. -- The Senate to-day passed Senator Ketcham's bill authorizing the further issuing of $1,500,000 of bonds by Essex County to complete its park system.

Whether the tardiness in removing the snow from the city's streets is due to the lack of executive ability of the Street Cleaning Department or to the inefficiency of the force and the materials at that department's command, is an open question.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Mrs. Place lived here fourteen years ago. She was then Mrs. Savcole. A year or so after taking up her residence in this city a son was born. While the child was still an infant the father went away, deserting the mother and child. The child was named Harry. Mrs. Savcole, finding it necessary to go out and earn her living by sewing, placed him in an orphan asylum.

The introduction of the Cuban intervention resolutions in the Senate yesterday gave Wall Street a nervous, feverish stock market. The professional traders worked themselves into a frenzy of fear and sold stocks all over the room. Several of the more important outside operators took the bear side and led the traders in their attacks upon various stocks.

An action has been brought in North Dakota, through H.G. Voss, State's Attorney for North Dakota, and senior member of the law firm of Hoggatt, Carruthers H.G. Voss, for the annulment of the marriage of Mrs. Naomi Hollister, nee Volse, and Charles A. Hollister of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

Mrs. Martha Place, who killed her seventeen-year-old stepdaughter, Ida, on Monday, at her home, 598 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, and later made a murderous assault with an axe upon her husband and then attempted to commit suicide, recovered sufficiently yesterday to be able to leave St. Mary's Hospital in charge of the police.

A murder is supposed to have been committed in or about New York which, in many particulars, bears a close resemblance to the crime of which William Guldensuppe was the victim in June last. The trunk of an unknown man with remnants of a leg and skull was found floating in the river at the foot of Roosevelt Street, yesterday morning, at 10:30 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Wheat to-day was helped by the best cash trade in two weeks, May closing at an advance of 1 2/3 cents. It was lower at the start, May opening at 94 5/8, as compared with yesterday's closing price of 94 7/8, but soon after the opening a good demand developed and from a condition of dullness the market took on quite a degree of activity.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The first of the series of amendments to the Greater New York charter affecting the Municipal Court to get through either branch of the Legislature is Senator Wray's bill, relating to the qualifications of Justices, which passed the Senate to-day.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 8. -- The annual meeting of the American Cereal Company, which will be held in this city to-morrow, will bring to an end a most bitter factional fight, which has existed for some time among the stockholders of the Oatmeal Trust. Both sides have been sending letters to the individual stockholders, and have been conducting a vigorous campaign to secure control of the company's affairs.
The Merchants' Association has a fight on its hands in which it should be reinforced by every business organization in the city.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Three Cuban resolutions were introduced in the Senate to-day.

Arthur W. Sherman, for many years cashier of the Gallatin National Bank of 34 Wall Street, died at 9:30 o'clock last evening at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, after being in bed only a day. At the bedside were his brothers, William A. Sherman and Frederick Sherman; a married sister, residing in Orange, and Theodore Baldwin, an intimate friend of the family.

The forthcoming report of the Regents of the University of the State of New York will contain a new feature in the form of an "educational map." It is a sketch or outline map of the State, 16 by 22 inches, upon which is indicated the location of each institution composing the university. The map also divides the State into the nine geographic divisions which are used in classifying local history in the State Library.

The social event of yesterday, and one that has excited considerable anticipation since its announcement, a few weeks ago, was the ball given at Delmonico's by Miss Josephine W. Drexel, daughter of Mrs. Joseph W. Drexel of 103 Madison Avenue. About 500 invitations had been issued for the affair, and some 350 fashionable people met in the large ballroom of the Forty-fourth Street building.

Every Winter, for years more numerous than the oldest New Yorker can pretend to remember, the beginning of the sun's northward journey has been the signal for turning the sidewalk about our City Hall Park into a river of dirty water by day and an icy mantrap by night, this alternation continuing until Spring is well advanced.

Complaints come from many parts of the city of the condition of streets which have not been touched by the snow contractors. It is a fact that while in part of New York there is no visible evidence that there has ever been a snowstorm, in other parts there is no visible evidence that there has ever been a Street Cleaning Department or an attempt to haul snow.

The Tuesday Evening Club, an institution of the season which fills a rather novel niche among social functions, convened for the third time last night at the home of ex-Gov. and Mrs. Levi P. Morton, 681 Fifth Avenue. Mme. Nordica, who sang with Sig. Campanari at the previous meeting, held at Mrs. J.J. Astor's, was among the audience at the Morton house, and so were Miss Lydia Eustis, Reginald de Koven, and Alexander Harrison.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 8. -- Chris Von der Ahe, the manager of the St. Louis baseball team, was taken into custody here last night by Detective Nicholas Bendel of Pittsburg upon an order of arrest obtained by Pitcher Mark E. Baldwin, who some time ago secured a judgment against the local magnate for $2,500.

The Church Club of New York held its eleventh annual dinner last night at Sherry's, Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. About 150 members and guests were present, and the banquet hall was handsomely decorated for the occasion. Ferns, potted palms, and garlands of carnations were wound around the table of honor and scattered throughout the hall.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Mattie M. Place is a sister of Peter D. Garrettson of 318 Seaman Street, this city, a baggage master on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Mr. Garrettson, when seen this afternoon, said that his sister, when twenty-three years old, was thrown from a sleigh and struck upon her head.

At the meeting of the Municipal Assembly yesterday a resolution was adopted by the City Council that a thorough investigation be made of the alleged frauds in connection with the recent expenditures for improving the canals. The resolution was sent to the Board of Aldermen for concurrent action. The Aldermen approved it after a brief argument.

Group 8 of the New York State Bankers' Association had its second annual banquet last night at the Hotel Manhattan. Covers were laid for 200 members and guests in the ladies' gallery, which was specially decorated for the occasion with flowers and the National colors and State and city arms. Thomas L. James presided and acted as toastmaster.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The House today considered the contested-election case of William F. Aldrich vs. Thomas S. Plowman, from the Fourth Alabama District. Mr. Plowman, the sitting member, is a Democrat, and Mr. Aldrich was the Populist and Republican candidate. The majority of the committee reported unanimously in favor of unseating Mr. Plowman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Many persons, mostly newspaper men, called at the Spanish Legation to-night to question Minister de Lome about the letter made public by the Cuban Junta in New York, but all were met with the announcement that Se+/-or de Lome was out, and would not return till very late.

The Board of Managers of the J. Hood Wright Memorial Hospital has issued its annual report for 1897. It shows a remarkable advance in the successful treatment of the hospital's patients and in the widening of its field of work.

BERLIN, Feb.8. -- Herr Richter, The Radical leader, referring to the Chinese question, said he regarded the acquisition of Kiao-Chau as much more useful than hoisting flags in Africa. Germany ought to preach none but a free-trade gospel in China, thus forming a natural community of interests with Great Britain.

A decision in the much-discussed brandy cherry case was handed down by the Customs Board of Classification yesterday, in favor of the importers. This case has been watched with much interest by importers in different parts of the country, because the final settlement of the point at issue will affect a large number of similar cases.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 8. -- The arrest of Chris Von Der Ahe in St. Louis was made at the instigation of W.A. Nimick, former President of the Pittsburg Baseball Club, who went on Von Der Ahe's bond when the latter was arrested in this city on the charge preferred by Pitcher Mark Baldwin.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The fourth session of the fourteenth Parliament of Queen Victoria, and the twenty-sixth of the United Kingdom was opened, by commission, at 2 o'clock this afternoon, with the customary ceremonies.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Another proposed charter amendment received what will probably prove its quietus at the hands of the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon. Senator McCarren brought up his bill allowing the Police Board to commute theatrical licenses, when issued for less than a year, for $150 for a theatre in Brooklyn and $50 in Richmond and Queens, $100 for a concert room in Brooklyn and $50 in Richmond and Queens.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Attorney Harmon, who is Adolph L. Luetgert's attorney, has now spoken for four days and has announced that he will speak for four more. The court and jury are showing signs of great fatigue, and Judge Gary has reprimanded Harmon on innumerable occasions, but seems unable to bring him to time.

L.C. King Co., the firm composed of Louis C. King and George C.D. Todd, importers of drugs, shellacs, chemicals, and East India products, at 171 Front Street, made an assignment yesterday to Samuel Victor Constant of Constant Coghill, giving preferences to Brown Brothers Co. for money advanced and merchandise delivered to the assignors, the amount being undetermined, and to Retta R. The fight against the department stores in Buffalo has assumed a curious shape. A course of four conferences on "The Contemporary Drama" was begun last evening before the Comparative Literature Society in the Carnegie Lyceum. Prof. Charles Sprague-Smith introduced the speakers. The opening address was delivered by Prof. Adolphe Cohn of Columbia University.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- A call was issued today for a meeting of the State Board of Canvassers to be held in this city Feb. 15. The amended return was filed by the County Board of Canvassers pursuant to an order issued by the Supreme Court.

Voltz of Buffalo and Assistant Appraiser Hamill of this city were present, as also were the following Drug Examiners: L.A. Kelly of Philadelphia, Erastus Hopkins of Boston, Edward Blum of Detroit, H.R. Watts of Baltimore, Ferdinand Ott of Cincinnati, and J.W. O'Brien of St. Louis.

After two days of discussion, the Rules Committee of the biennial congress of the National Trotting Association ended its labors yesterday, and reported the amended rules, which will govern trotting on all tracks in the National Trotting Association for the next two years. The congress was held at the Murray Hill Hotel, and delegates from all sections of the country, from Maine to California, were present.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Adolph L. Luetgert was to-night convicted of the murder of his wife, and sentenced to imprisonment in the penitentiary for the term of his natural life. Announced speeches were delivered by Mr. Cannon (Silver Rep., Utah,) and Mr. Mason (Rep., Ill.,) in advocacy of the adoption of resolutions which they presented to the Senate yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- The Overseers of Harvard College held a special meeting to-day, and voted to postpone until March 2 the consideration of the numerous petitions received from the alumni that the board defer definite action in regard to extending the right to vote for Overseers to graduates of the professional schools.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 9. -- Judge A. Heaton Robinson of Middletown, who purchased the property of the insolvent Meriden, Waterbury and Connecticut River Railroad two years ago for $180,000, and who last week refused an offer of $300,000 for it, after having sold all the rolling stock, will have to pay a town tax on $40,000 of the railroad property in Waterbury.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- A small sensation was created here to-day by John McMasters's resignation as football and baseball trainer. He has trained the Tigers for seven years, and turned out four championship teams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The publication in the morning newspapers of what purported to be an autograph letter, written by Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister, to his friend, Senor Canalejas, criticising the President with the utmost freedom, probably will be followed by Minister de Lome's departure from the United States.

Much comment has lately been made on the fact that large amounts of money are at present lying unused in many banking institutions. Although in some quarters it is reasoned that this indicates a lack of business demand for currency, in the majority of instances it is reported that notwithstanding the amounts remaining in the banks there is at present an increase rather than a falling off in the commercial requirements for funds.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9. -- The entire day to-day was devoted by the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen to the discussion of good roads. A number of papers on the various branches of highway improvements were read by delegates prominently engaged in the furtherance of the work, and the meeting was one of intense interest.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The Nussbaum Bankruptcy bill was the subject of a lengthy and exhaustive discussion before the Judiciary Committees of the Assembly and Senate in joint session this afternoon.

The friends of ex-President HARRISON in Indiana have won a victory in the preliminary organization of the Republican Party at which all good citizens may rejoice. Their avowed purpose is to force the currency issue to the front in the elections of next Fall, and they are prepared to take more advanced ground on that question than ever before.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 9. -- Miss Helen Gould, who has more than once shown her friendship for Rutgers College, has accepted an invitation to act as a member of The Reception Committee and as a patroness of the junior promenade, which takes place in the Ballantine Gymnasium on Feb. 18.

I read with great interest your able editorial of yesterday morning. You call attention to our not being admitted to a full understanding of the game of Lord Salisbury, which suggests that it is not safe to tie up to English statesmanship. Indeed, I do not believe in having any alliances whatever.

The illustrations to the serial stories of the Revolution by Henry Cabot Lodge and of the American Navy in the Revolution by Capt. A.T. Mahan, now running in Scribner's Magazine, have attracted wide attention. The publishers of the magazine recently conceived the idea of exhibiting the original drawings and paintings for these illustrations in the principal American cities and they are now on exhibition at the Avery Galleries, 368 Fifth Avenue.

There is a pathetic story of an erring woman's struggles to redeem herself in the eyes of her son behind a meagre police return at Brooklyn Police Headquarters announcing the suicide of Mrs. Annie Coates, aged thirty-nine, of 55 Pennsylvania Avenue.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- A radical change in the methods of speculative dealings by certain agents and brokers is proposed in a bill introduced to-day in the Senate by Mr. Finn, as follows:

CLEVELAND, Feb 10. -- The Senate Bribery Investigating Committee will make a report finding United States Senator Hanna guilty of attempting to bribe Representative John C. Otis of Cincinnati "through his (Hanna's) duly authorized agents."

During a fusillade of bullets sent after a gang of fleeing burglars by a force of detectives from the Eldridge Street Police Station at Lewis and Broome Streets early yesterday morning Jacob Levy, twenty-seven years old, of 87 Allen Street, one of the burglars, was shot in the hand. He was captured, as were also two other members of the gang.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Collector Bidwell has been in Washington for the purpose of awakening interest in the proposition to erect a new Custom House. He has talked over the matter with Secretary Gage and his assistants, and has convinced them that it is advisable to take steps to assure to New York a new Custom House building within three years.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 10. -- A special dispatch from Chicago brings the news that a Chicago contract is on its way to Springfield directed to Thomas Everett Burns.

A correspondent of THE TIMES in the paper of to-day refers to the snow problem and says there is fame and fortune to the person who invents a process of melting snow as it lies in the streets. This is doubtless true, but there is a certain difficulty in the way which is quite as serious an obstacle to overcome as is the law of gravitation to any flight except that of the imagination.

MADRID, Feb. 10. -- At a meeting of the Spanish Cabinet, held to-day under the Presidency of the Queen Regent, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senor Gullon, read a dispatch from Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister at Washington, saying that the published letter to Senor Canalejas was written by him, and that his position, consequently, had become untenable, and he begged the Government to accept his resignation.

MADRID, Feb. 11. -- The papers all discuss the de Lome incident this morning and the possible successor of the retiring Minister at Washington. La Correspondencia de Espanol mentions Senor Muruaga but but says it is believed that nothing has as yet been decided. El Heraldo de Madrid deplores the incident, but remarks:

The citizens interested in the movement for a three-day celebration on and after May 4, the anniversary of the passage of the Greater New York Charter, met again yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and formed themselves into a general committee, with a prospective membership of 1,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- In the Assembly today Mr. Maher introduced a bill providing that all individuals, companies, or corporations using underground passages or manholes in cities of the first class shall place in all manhole covers an automatic safety gas valve to prevent accumulation or explosion of gas in all such subways.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- In view of the apparent disposition of the Canadian authorities to prevent the United States troops from accompanying the relief expedition into the gold country, a brief review of the correspondence that has so far taken place between the two Governments may be in order.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 10. -- It is now known that eleven persons were killed by the explosions last night of ammonia and whisky in the cold storage plant of the Chautauqua Lake Ice Company, a six-story building occupying most of the block bounded by Pike Street and Mulberry Alley and Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The bill providing for an investigation of the canal improvement expenditures by a commission to be appointed by the Governor, which was passed by the Assembly last week, went through the Senate to-day by a vote of 30 to 10. The vote was on party lines, except that Senator Malby, Republican, voted with the Democrats against the bill.

The railways of the Central Passenger Association, which opposed and prevented the granting of excursion rates to the Merchants' Association of New York, have reconsidered their action, and the vote to grant these rates (one-third discount on a round trip) has been made unanimous. Unfortunately this action is so late that the Merchants' Association cannot make full use of the advantages thus finally secured for the first excursion it had planned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The State Department this morning gave out for publication a statement concerning the cablegram sent yesterday to Gen. Woodford, the Minister to Madrid, in reference to the de Lome letter. The statement is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Unofficial persons express regret that the President did not send his passports to Mr. de Lome before giving him an opportunity to offer his resignation to his Government. As he is no longer an officer, it is held that he cannot be dealt with officially.

The New York Jewelers' Association had its twenty-third annual banquet last night at Delmonico's. Nearly 200 members and guests were present. In the absence of President George Mr. Shiebler, kept at home by sickness, Vice President F.H. Larter presided and acted as toastmaster. The guests included J. Franklin Ford, President W.F. King of the Merchants Association, W.D. Bynum, the Rev. Dr. Kittredge, F. W. Wurster, and W.P. Williams.

Josiah Quincy, Mayor of Boston, and other persons of note addressed more than four hundred members and friends of the Nineteenth Century Club last night at Sherry's, on the subject, "Is the Growing Demand for Public Control of Franchises Justified?" Mayor Quincy visited New York solely at the invitation of the club, and the event was almost equivalent to a reception in his honor.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- A delegation from New York City composed of Charles E. Hibbard, Abraham Gruber, Alfred R. Page, Charles K. Lexow, and Abraham Lewis called on Gov. Black to-day to urge the propriety of amending the Raines law. The Governor heard them, but gave them no satisfaction.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 10. -- "Baron" Harden-Hickey, better known as the "Prince of Trinidad," was found dead at the Pierson Hotel, in this city, to-day. Servants in the hotel discovered the body at noon and the indications were that the Baron had died during the night from drugs taken with suicidal intent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- When inquiries were made at the Spanish Legation to-day as to how the letter reached the hands of the Cuban Junta, it was said that the statements made by the junta as to Senor Canalejas receiving the letter were absolutely false. Private inquiries, it was stated, had been made through a New York gentleman, which had disclosed that Canalejas never saw the letter.

HAVANA, Feb. 10. -- La Lucha, commenting upon the de Lome affair, says: "At various times during past years we have said that Senor Dupuy de Lome is not the man Spain needs at this moment in Washington. In spite of this, the most prominent Madrid politicians have not thought so."

The Central Passenger Association has reconsidered a recent decision and will offer excursion rates to out-of-town merchants and buyers coming to New York between Feb. 21 and 27 and March 14 and 20. This is a victory for the Merchants' Association, which had planned the excursions in order that New York jobbers might reach new fields and gain business which has heretofore gone to other cities.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- According to a special dispatch from Paris, Mme. Dreyfus is so seriously ill, owing to worry, that she is unable to appear on the witness stand and, in any case, she refuses to furnish any further testimony.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 10. -- The Cincinnati "Ripper" bill, prepared by Representative Swain, acting under Mr. Hanna's orders, came before the House and was defeated overwhelmingly. The bill was to oust the Cox Republicans now in control in Cincinnati and put in a new board of officers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- There was considerable bitterness shown in the House today between the majority and the minority, for which the Democratic leader, Mr. Bailey, was chiefly responsible.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Gov. Black and Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast to-day issued a general order naming Major Charles Francis Roe of New York as Major General and giving him command of the entire guard as one division. They also divided the present First Brigade into two parts, making a new First and a new Fifth Brigade.

The evidence for the State in the Noonan-Simpson bribery case at Jersey City before Judges Lippincott and Hudspeth closed yesterday. Only four witnesses were called. Two were reporters and one a lawyer's clerk, who were cited merely to corroborate certain unimportant statements made by previous witnesses. The fourth witness was County Clerk John Fisher, who was called to prove that Nicodine Boczkowski had been indicted at the September Term.

It may be laid down as a rule, without exception, that no person who is in the enjoyment of vigorous health ever contracts consumption. The vitality must be lowered before this dreadful disease can find an abiding place. A weak constitution may be inherited, and the fact that consumption existed in progenitors is evidence of the transmission of a lowered vitality, but the germ that produces the disease is never transmitted by heredity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Senate today took up the Indian Appropriation bill. As it passed the House the bill carried $7,517,454. As reported to the Senate it carried $7,665,527, an increase of $148,073. The bill as proposed by the Senate Committee carries about $10,000 less than the appropriation for the current year.

Protests have been filed with the Board of United States General Appraisers by Leon Hirsch of this city, Isaacs, Vought Co., Custom House brokers, and others against the action of the local Custom House authorities in assessing duties on watches and watch movements. Questions of general importance to the trade are involved in these cases, which are to have a hearing before the Board of Classification to-day.

Guatemala would show herself to be unlike the other Spanish-American republics if her constitutional Government were not occasionally tempered by dictatorships and assassinations, and certainly the fate of BARRIOS, who has of late been sending a good many of his political enemies to the executioner, can excite neither surprise nor very much pity.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 19. -- The first witness called to the stand in the Lattimer murder case when court convened this morning was Morris Engleman of West Hazleton. Engleman said that on the day of the shooting of the striking miners by Sheriff Martin and has Deputies he was on the read and near the Deputies at the time the strikers were entering Lattimer.
Jesse C. Bennett has sold, for Andrew J. Kirwin, Jr., the plot on the west side of the Boulevard, 69 feet south of One Hundred and Fifth Street, 33 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- In view of the news from Madrid of tile acceptance of the resignation of the Spanish Minister, it may' be stated that our Government is not di-. posed to split hairs over the mthod of th offending linister's retirement. In other words, it is not concerned as to whetherhe resigns or is recalled, so long as h leaves the capital

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 10. -- Isaac B. Potter was re-elected to-day President of the League of American Wheelmen. Out of 325 votes cast in the convention 212 were for Potter and 107 for Gideon; the remaining votes were scattered.

OTTAWA, Feb. 10. -- Canada is engaged in an elaborate scheme of militia defense. At the annual meeting of the Dominion Artillery Association to-day the Governor General, the Minister of Militia, Gen. Montgomery Moore, commanding the imperial forces in Canada, and Gen. Gascogne, commanding the Canadian militia, were present.

The first meeting this season of the popular Midwinter Club attracted about 200 persons to Sherry's last night, to enjoy an interesting programme and have something to eat afterward. The guests did not begin to arrive till about 9 o'clock. They met in the small ball-room down stairs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The following statement was made to-day to the Secretary of State by the German Ambassador:

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 10. -- The annual junior promenade, the leading social event of the college midyear, will occur to-morrow evening, in the Casino. The building has been elaborately decorated in pink and green and every arrangement has been made for a great occasion. It is expected that over 100 couples will be present, and among these will be society people of New York and Philadelphia.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- In the House of Commons to-day, the motion of Michael Davitt, moved as an amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne at the reassembling of Parliament, calling attention to the distress in Ireland and the failure of the potato crop, was rejected by 235 to 153 votes.

George W. Palmer, Dr. G.P. Griffin, Thomas W. Marlow, W.P. Jones, and F.W. Kingsland, representing the Seventeenth Ward Board of Trade of Brooklyn and a citizens' association of Long Island City, called upon Mayor Van Wyck yesterday to ask his countenance for the construction of a new bridge over Newtown Creek at Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, and Vernom Avenue, Long Island City.
The Legislature is considering several propositions for public parks in New York.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- Because of the long debate on Senator Murphy's silver vote the expected joint meeting of the Assembly and Senate Judiciary Committees, to consider the question of primary reform, was not held to-day. This puts the whole matter off until next week, blocks the Black harmony programme, and makes it a little less likely that the Legislature will be able to adjourn by April 1, as the Governor wishes it to do.

Justice Chase, in the Supreme Court, yesterday heard argument and reserved decision upon a demurrer interposed by Elias C. Benedict, one of the defendants, to the complaint of William J. Logan in his suit against William Rockefeller, John G. Moore, Henry H. Rogers, and the other members of the syndicate which arranged to consolidate the various Brooklyn gas companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Navy is learning that little torpedo boats are dangerous craft for cruising along the Atlantic coast during the stormy Winter season. The last sufferer is the Foote, that has arrived at Norfolk to repair her shaft. She came north from Port Royal, S.C., using only one propeller, the other shaft being broken.

It is comic to consider the centre of Germany's "sphere of influence" in China. As our readers know, it is the murder by unauthorized Chinamen of two German missionaries, who, contrary to the custom of their nation, had got themselves disliked. It was in vain that official China apologized, beheaded some carnal Chinamen, and pretended to remove a Viceroy.

ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- The Assembly to-day, by a vote of 79 to 63, adopted a resolution censuring United States Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., for supporting the Teller free silver resolution. Mr. Seligsberg, National Democrat, of New York, voted with the Republicans in the affirmative. The resolution adopted was a substitute offered by Mr. Weekes for the one previously introduced by him.

It must be supposed that the announcement of Japan's intention to retain Wei-Hai-Wei permanently marks the end of the crisis in the Far East. A month ago it looked as if that crisis could not be passed without war. Germany and Russia had taken up positions in China, with a view to their own aggrandizement, which England could not permit to be maintained without grievous injury, if not ruin, to her Chinese trade.

There was a meeting at the Chamber of Commerce, in Nassau Street, yesterday afternoon, of the local committee of 100 which has been appointed for the purpose of arranging for the National Conference of Charities and Correction, which is to be held in this city from May 18 to 24. The committee was appointed by William R. Stewart, President of the conference.

Wall Street decided yesterday to look upon the De Lome incident as ended, and upon the relations between the United States and the Spanish Government as no more strained than before the publication of the Spanish Minister's unfortunate letter. The announcement of De Dome's resignation brought about a decided change in the sentiment of the Street.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 10. -- Results at Oakland:

Spain has not taken the right view or the right action in the case of Minister DE LOME. In hastily accepting his resignation she protects him from something worse, as Gen. GRANT protected BELKNAP from investigation by allowing him to resign. As Mr. DE LOME is now no Minister, but is in the situation of any other Spanish subject temporarily residing in the United States, the Government has nothing further to do with him.

The policy of the United States regarding Cuba is by no means the vague and indeterminate thing that many of our Congressmen seem to think. By the consistent action of the Executive since the present rebellion broke out, through the terms of two Presidents of opposite views as to domestic questions, that policy has been carefully and deliberately developed and pursued.

The session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church held a regular meeting last night, which was presided over by the Rev. Dr. John Hall as Moderator. Of the twelve Elders of the church who are now in the city, four were present at the meeting, and the resignations of the other eight were presented to it.

Argument was heard before Justice Pryor in the Supreme Court yesterday on a motion for a writ of mandamus requiring the reinstatement of Dr. Charles B. Kelsey as Professor of Surgery in the Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, whence he was removed by the Board of Directors Jan. 27 last.

Alexander E. Orr, President of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, received a reply yesterday to the letter he wrote to George J. Gould on Feb. 4. Mr. Gould's communication is dated Feb. 9, and says:

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Confirmation of the news that the Leiter clique had contracted to move a large amount of its wheat holdings abroad was the overshadowing influence in wheat to-day. It made a strong and active market, and, helped by firm cables, resulted in an advance of nearly a cent in the May option. Wheat was not alone in the buoyancy.

President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway expects to have the electric cars of the Fourth and Madison Avenue line running down to the intersection of Centre Street and Park Row by the first of next month. The tracks equipped with the underground trolley system have practically been completed between Astor Place and Brooklyn Bridge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Senator Frye, from the Committee on Commerce, to-day reported to the Senate and secured the passage of a bill amending the navigation laws in important particulars affecting the coasting trade of this country. The bill is of general application, but it is intended especially to prevent Canadian vessels from securing an undue share of the carrying business between Alaskan and other American ports.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Neither the Chinese nor the Japanese Legation here has received notice of Japan's purpose to hold Wei-Hai-Wei. It is stated at the latter that Wei-Hai-Wei is now occupied by the Japanese under the terms of the peace settlement, by which this strong point is to remain in the possession of Japan until the full indemnity is paid.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The examination of M. Trarieux, the former Minister of Justice, was completed at to-day's session of the Assizes Court of the Seine, before which M. Zola and M. Perreux, manager of the Aurore, are being tried, at the instigation of the Government, the former for writing and the latter for printing a letter reflecting upon the Esterhazy court-martial.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The St. James's Gazette commenting upon the De Lome incident, says:

The writers and readers of newspapers have had their amusement over the preposterous "coronation" of an ill-advised young woman of this city. The performance has no doubt been ridiculous enough from one point of view. From another it it is fitted to excite melancholy rather than mirth.

The Morgue was thronged yesterday by curious people, many of whom volunteered their services in an attempt to identify the mutilated body found at the foot of Roosevelt Street on Tuesday. But the police are not much nearer to a solution of the mystery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The War Department to-day made public the advices received from Capt. P.H. Ray of the Eighth Infantry, who was sent to Alaska to report on conditions in the mining country. The reports embrace a period running from Oct. 3 to Nov. 3, and are dated from Circle City and Fort Yukon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11. -- A special from San Jose de Guatemala says civil strife and bloodshed have followed the killing of Barrios. Before the body of the late ruler had found sepulture the factions were flying at each other's throats, and as a result Gen. Marroquin, the chief supporter of Prospero Morales, one of the aspirants to the Presidency, is dead, and his forces are seeking safety in flight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The third of the card receptions at the White House tonight, which was given especially to the Army and Navy, was attended by over 2,000 persons. Senor Du Bosc, Charge d'Affaires ad Interim of the Spanish Legation, was among the guests.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- There were the usual crowds about the Assizes Court of the Seine to-day when the fifth day of the trial of MM. Zola and Perreux commenced. M. Zola and Col. Picquart were greeted with hostile cries on their arrival. The court was thronged, and the proceedings opened with the recall of Gen. Pellieux.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 11. -- The man who committed suicide by inhaling gas in his room at the Merchants' Hotel in Albany was undoubtedly Dr. J.C. Condict, a young dentist who disappeared from his home in New Brunswick last Saturday. Dr. Condict left Saturday afternoon while a number of patients were waiting for him in his office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Fourth-class Postmasters for New York offices were appointed to-day as follows: East Corning, Frank Frost; Haskinsville, Zina C. Bowen; Maynard, Mary E. Horn; Nineveh Junction, N.B. Williams; North Salem, Benjamin R. Lobdell; Pekin, W.E. Beaber; Plains, William H. Sylyea; Preble, J.T. Crofoot; Scottsburg, Jesse Roberts; South Glens Falls, L.D. Palmer; Summitville, Samuel A. Adams; Webster, George G. Mason.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Indian Appropriation bill was passed by the Senate to-day, after being amended to some extent. The most important amendment to the bill was that offered by Mr. Pettigrew, (S. Rep., S.D.,) which, if finally enacted, will restore the free-homestead law so far as it relates to Indian lands ceded to the United States, for which the settlers have been obliged to pay the purchase price paid to the Indians.

-- One would like to think that it was only an attempt on the Orient's part to get even with the Occident when a prominent New York Chinaman, in stating his objections to the demagogic Eagan bill, said that his countrymen, for some time after arriving in America, cannot see enough difference between American faces to enable them to tell one of us from another.

STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 11. -- James Parker, Superintendent of the Almshouse at the Stamford town farm, was murdered this morning by Mrs. Bridget Drought, an old woman who for many years has been an inmate of the almshouse. Mrs. Drought is about sixty-five years of age, and is of a quarrelsome disposition, though she has been considered harmless.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- The Senate Committee on Appropriations to-day completed consideration of the Fortification Appropriation bill. The committee decided to recommend increases which more than double the figures of the bill as it passed the House. The exact amount carried is $9,052,494, as against $4,144,912 carried by the bill as it passed the House.

MADRID, Feb. 11. -- United States Minister Woodford gave a banquet this evening to the Diplomatic Corps. Senor Gullon, the Foreign Minister, and Senor Moret, the Colonial Minister, were present. Senor Gullon, questioned by newspaper men on the subject, said that Senor Dupuy de Lome's successor would soon be nominated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 11. -- Among the passengers on the steamship Mariposa, which arrived here yesterday from Australian ports, were fifty miners, who are on their way to the Yukon gold fields. They say that at least 5,090 people will leave Australia for the gold fields during the next few months.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- In the House of Commons to-day Mr. John Redmond, the Parnellite leader, moved an amendment to the address in reply to the speech from the throne at the opening of Parliament. It was to the effect that "while the House regards with satisfaction the proposed bill for the reform of local government in Ireland, the measure will nowise meet the demand for an independent Irish Parliament."
MADRID, Feb. 11. -- The Premier, Senor Sagasta, said to a correspondent:

The thirteenth annual exhibition of the Architectural League is now open to the public, in the building of the Fine Arts Society, in West Fifty-seventh Street. More attention has been paid this year to the decoration and arrangement of the galleries themselves, and their effect has been greatly heightened by the placing of plaster figures here and there and the adorning of flights of steps with sculpture ornamentation.

In your admirable and delightful REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, the subject "What Books Children Should Read" has already been quite earnestly and deeply discussed. To most of the readers no doubt the importance of this theme is unquestionable. But as to myself, speaking from my own experience, the question seem to be of an entirely different nature.

HAVANA, Feb. 11. -- Capt. Sigsbee, accompanied by Consul General Lee, paid an official visit to Capt. Gen Blanco to-day. They were cordially received and entertained. At 10 o'clock to-morrow morning Gen. Solano will return the visit of the American Captain and Consul General, in the name of Capt. Gen. Blanco, on board the Maine.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- "Andy" Wilson, a young man, drifted into this village a few weeks ago with money in every pocket and a bankbook under his arm. He came from New York City, where his mother, Mrs. Wilson, died a short time ago, leaving a fortune in property and money. Since that time he has lived like a King, lavishing his money upon every one for the asking.
The Noonan-Simpson bribery case was resumed yesterday before Judges Lippincott and Hudspeth in the Hudson County Oyer and Terminer Court.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 11. -- The National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen adjourned to-night. The features of the meeting, which lasted, three days, were President Isaac B. Potter's successful fight for re-election and the defeat of the proposition for local option in the matter of Sunday racing.

Not since Col. WARING accepted the Commissionership of Street Cleaning have the streets of New York been in so disgraceful a condition as they are to-day. It is eleven days since the last snow fell. For the first few days after a snowfall the Commissioner is entitled to some indulgence.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11. -- John F. Craig, a grain merchant of West Philadelphia, has disappeared, and it is learned that he has left behind him unsecured liabilities estimated at from $10,000 to $15,000. He also leaves a wife and several children in straitened circumstances. He left home on Jan. 19, and his wife says she has heard nothing of him since that date.

The first meeting of the Executive Committee of the Charter Day Celebration General Committee was held yesterday at the committee's headquarters in the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The meeting was called to order by W. D'H. Washington, Chairman of the General Committee. Col. John J. Garnett, Secretary of the General Committee, acted as Secretary.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 11. -- The Ohio Republican League Convention, which was held in this city to-day, was one of the stormiest in the history of the league. About 200 delegates, representing 72 clubs, were in attendance. The factional feeling which marked the late Senatorial contest cropped out. There were strenuous efforts to restore harmony, however, both the retiring President and the President-elect advising the members of the league to lay aside factional differences.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 11. -- An application was made to Judge Barnard here to-day for the appointment of a committee to take charge of the affairs of Abraham Smith, an inmate of the Vassar Home for Aged Men. Mr. Smith is ninety-six years old, and had long since been quite forgotten by those who knew him in his younger and better days.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Pursuant to instructions from the Acting Secretary of War, a special supplementary report has been prepared by E. Hazard Wells, who acted as agent for the War Department in bringing out Capt. Ray's dispatches. Mr. Wells has been in the Yukon country three times, has traversed interior Alaska in many directions, and has a practical knowledge of the country that is possessed by few persons.

Why the 14th of February should be celebrated as St. Valentine's Day is still vexed question. The good Bishop of that name, whose death in the third century was a very cruel one, being first beaten with clubs and then beheaded, certainly seems to have no connection with Cupid and his merry pranks.
Encouraged by the reception accorded my earlier paper on Barrie, with your permission I will have another talk with your readers anent the finest female character in fiction.

The Board of Education of the City of New York, to be organized on Monday, Feb. 21, will have among other duties the selection of a City Superintendent of Schools. The various boroughs that compose the city will still have Superintendents, known as Borough Superintendents, but the duties of the new official are well defined in the charter.

With the shadow of portentous events looming on the horizon, with the great powers watching each other on the shores of China, with the Cuban question still unsettled, and the Hawaiian problem a source of continued speculation, anything that pertains to the navy of the United States is at present a matter of peculiar interest.

The sale last week for a total of $409,790 of the collection of pictures (with a few bronzes) of the late William H. Stewart has been surpassed in the total of prices only three times in the history of picture sales in this country. In THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of Dec. 11 was given a history of New York sales, compiled from information kindly furnished for the purpose by Samuel P. Avery.

Superintendent Payn of the New York State Insurance Department yesterday issued a license to the British-American Insurance Company to do business in this State. The company starts with $200,000 capital and $100,000 net surplus.

Official tests of a new pneumatic mail tube, three and one-half miles long, were made yesterday afternoon in the presence of distinguished Post Office authorities, members of Congress, and other persons. This tube connects the General Post Office with Branch Station H, in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, and it is the second one of its kind constructed in this city.

The final performance in the Ring of the Nibelung series at the Metropolitan Opera House took place last night. Wagner's "Gotterdammerung" used to be regarded in the old days of German opera seasons as certain to attract a large audience, and that it has not yet lost its influence with this public was abundantly demonstrated by the size of the house last night.

N. Jonsson Rose, landscape gardener of the Department of Public Parks, yesterday submitted a report to the Park Commissioners calling attention to the condition of the parks and the changes necessary for their improvement.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- When the estimates for the German Embassy at Washington were presented in the Reichstag to-day a discussion arose on the general relations between Germany and the United States, during which Dr. Berth, the Freisinnige leader; Count Posadowsky, the Minister of the Interior, and others participated, Dr. Barth pointing out the great importance of American trade and how the exports of 1896 had increased 20,000,000 marks.

TACOMA, Feb. 11. -- The steamer Topeka brings news to-day that the lawless element is in supreme control in Dyea and Skaguay, and is indulging its criminal propensities without let or hindrance. Robberies and flagrant violations of laws are of almost hourly occurrence. The respectable portion is so far in the minority as to be powerless to interfere.

Even thus early a considerable number of new church projects are already announced for the Spring season. Some of these are old congregations rebuilding on new sites, but several are wholly new projects. Besides the proposed new Roman Catholic church on the west side in this city, already announced, there are two new churches contemplated in the Diocese of Long Island.

The Dock Commissioners yesterday approved plans submitted by Chief Engineer Bensel for a new pier, foot of West Thirty-fourth Street on the North River, which is to be 700 feet long and 100 feet wide. The Hamburg-American Line is an applicant for the lease of this pier, it being understood to be the company's purpose to dock its express steamers there instead of in Hoboken as at present.

Edith Lockley, the wife of Joseph Lockley, the defaulting confidential clerk of the American Estates Association of 152 Broadway, was arrested yesterday at 1 East One Hundred and Thirty-first Street by Detectives Aloncle and Casey, on the charge of having in her possession the books and papers of the association, which were stolen by her husband at the same time that he robbed his employers of $7,000 by means of raised and forged checks.

John Jay Chapman's "Emerson, and Other Essays" is to be published by Charles Scribner's Sons before long. The author has grouped together critiques on Browning, Whitman, Stevenson, Michelangelo's sonnets, and other themes. His estimate of Robert Louis Stevenson is said to be in a particularly iconoclastic vein, and is certain to arouse animated resentment from the lovers of the dead English romanticist.

With a blaze of jewels, a beauty, a richness, a variety of costumes, and an elegance of setting such as has never before combined to make it a success, the annual charity ball came and went in the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Feb. 11. -- When court opened this morning for the trial of Sheriff Martin and his deputies, who are charged with the killing of the strikers at Lattimer, the defense introduced a new feature in the cross-examination, endeavoring to show that the evidence of the witnesses was influenced by the hope of securing damages from the Government in the event of a conviction.
