WASHINGTON, March 23. -- A vivid picture of the horrors and barbarities practiced by the Spanish in Cuba was drawn in the Senate to-day by Mr. Gallinger of New Hampshire, who recently visited Cuba to study the condition of the reconcentrados and to ascertain the facts concerning the general Cuban question. It was known that Mr. Gallinger was to speak upon Cuba to-day, and long before the Senate convened the galleries were packed.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 23. -- Mrs. Donald McLean, Regent of New York City Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, to-day visited Miss C.E. Mason's school, The Castle, on the heights back of Tarrytown. Her visit was made the basis of a patriotic demonstration by the young women of the school.

About 100 tons of bacon and cornmeal were shipped to Cuba on the Ward Line steamer Orizaba, which left here yesterday. There was also sent a large quantity of miscellaneous supplies -- 300 tons in all -- destined for the relief of the starving reconcentrados collected by the Central Cuban Relief Committee of this city.

The Mayor yesterday, in his interview with the deputation of the Public Library, kindly refrained from taking his usual ground in reference to such applications. His usual ground is that it is all nonsense for anybody to have the means of learning more than he himself was taught, and that the provision of any educational facilities more than he has enjoyed is "fancy" or "new fangled."

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Navy Department to-day took steps toward utilizing ten of the seagoing revenue cutters for use along the Atlantic Coast. Capt. Shoemaker, Chief of the Revenue Cutter Service, conferred with Assistant Secretary Roosevelt during the day on the plans for turning over these cutters to the navy.
LONDON, March 24. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Daily News says:

John N. Golding has sold for E.H. Crampton to Mandelbaum Lewine, for about $100,000, the five and six story factories on a plot 103.2 by 114.6, at the southeast corner of Jefferson and Monroe Streets. This property was announced for sale at auction a few weeks ago, but was withdrawn.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 23. -- C.D. Rand, a confidential man in the employ of Russell Sage, made a hero of himself at a fire in this city last night, in which the James Reynolds Elevator Company's property and stock, valued at $60,000, were destroyed. The elevator stood by the track of the Poughkeepsie and Eastern Railroad, owned by Russell Sage, and several of Mr. Sage's freight cars were close to the elevators.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency to-day brought up the proposed general currency legislation for this session. The report of the sub-committee appointed to draft the general measure was made to the full committee by Representative McCleary of Minnesota, and it was read by sections, and led to much discussion.

Secretary Robert B. Kerr of the United States Golf Association said yesterday that notices had been sent for a meeting of the Executive Committee next Wednesday in this city. President Laurence Curtis of Boston will come to the city to attend the meeting, and all of the other members except Charles B. Macdonald of Chicago are expected to be present.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Senators Morgan, Rawlins, and Harris, of the Committee on Pacific Railroads, to-day presented a minority report on the bill providing for the settlement of the claims of the United States against the Sioux City and Pacific Railroad Company.

A statistician for whose standing as such Harper's Weekly vouches contributes to the current issue of that journal a most interesting exposition of the financial situation of Spain. By this it is made clearly to appear that it is the war in Cuba and the war in Cuba alone that makes that situation hopeless.

ALBANY, March 23. -- The Civil Service Commissioners are divided in their opinions as to the efficacy of the new civil service law, which was adopted by the last Legislature at the solicitation of Gov. Black.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Adjutant General's office is especially busy preparing maps of Cuba and Puerto Rico and of the various harbors of both islands. Long before the Maine disaster, and even before the relations between the United States and Spain had begun to grow strained, the office began the preparation of military maps of Cuba.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Army Reorganization bill was adopted unanimously to-day by the House Committee on Military Affairs and it was subsequently reported to the House. The bill was agreed on yesterday, but in view of the significance of the measure it was deemed best that the committee should also pass on the report which had been ordered prepared to insure the correct representation of the committee views.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 23. -- A regular blizzard prevails in St. Louis and vicinity, extending down into Arkansas and part of Illinois. The temperature shows a drop of 48 degrees since yesterday. The ground is covered with heavy wet snow, something unprecedented for this season of the year.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 23. -- M. Raoul Pugno, the French pianist, who left here this morning for Indianapolis, said he would conclude his American tour to-night with a concert in that city. He will sail a week from Saturday for his home in Paris. He expressed himself as delighted with America and Americans, and said he hoped that he would be able to come back next season.

The Orchestra Society of New York, organized to maintain a permanent orchestra in this city, held a meeting yesterday at the home of Dr. William H. Draper, 19 East Forty-seventh Street. Most of the members were present, and it was announced that $10,500 had been subscribed toward the carrying out of the object of the society.

In common with many another nautical man, I have heretofore been very skeptical as to "any outside agency in the explosion of the Maine"; the result, perhaps, of an old sailor's prejudice against, or perhaps his ignorance of, the very complex conditions in the "make-up" of the modern battleship; it appearing to him that sooner or later an explosion would be the natural sequence of a juxtaposition of steam, gunpowder, dynamite, and electricity.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Navy Department is besieged daily by shipbuilders and contractors who are offering to do not only what the Government wants in the way of ship construction, but a great deal more.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Carter (Rep., Mon.,) called up the bill making further provision for a civil government for Alaska and completed his speech begun yesterday.

The second day of the big pigeon-shooting tournament at the Elkwood Park traps was brought to a close by darkness last night with the Grand American Handicap, the stellar event of the meeting, about half completed. When the shooters retired at the end of the day's sport, there were only 17 straight scores out of the field of 197.

A delegation of Trustees and others interested in the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden foundations, waited on Mayor Van Wyck yesterday and asked him to help them secure from the Board of Estimate and Apportionment a bond issue for $150,000, to remove the old Forty-second Street Reservoir and to prepare the site for the library.

Three decisions were handed down by the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday. The ruling of the Collector was sustained in the case of R. D'Oench of St. Louis, who protested against the assessment of 45 per cent. ad valorem on an importation of metal candlesticks to be used for Christmas trees.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Secretary Long desires to have it understood that his action in ordering a medical board of survey for the examination of Admiral Sicard was based entirely upon the request of that officer. The department he says, has every confidence in Admiral Sicard, and would regret exceedingly his retirement from active duty.

Charles Buhrer, a bricklayer, was asphyxiated yesterday morning at the bottom of a fifty-foot well in East New York. Three men who attempted to rescue him came near meeting the same fate, and one after another were drawn from the well just in time to save their lives. The body was finally recovered by policemen.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 23. -- Senator Brush's bill, a mending the civil service law, was presented to the Senate to-night in an emasculated condition from the Committee on Judiciary. It strikes out the clause abolishing the present civil service laws and merely provides that the rules adopted by the New York City Civil Service Board shall be approved by the State board, and that removals shall only be made for cause.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Secretary Alger had with him in conference for some time to-day Gen. A.W. Greely, Chief Signal officer of the army. In the course of the conference they talked about the use of balloons in case of war. This matter Gen. Greely thinks of great importance to the army.

TRENTON, N.J., March 23. -- The afternoon session of the House was characterized by several interesting episodes. Mr. Benny (Dem., Hudson,) started the ball rolling by charging that he had been made a victim of bad faith. He desired to move a reconsideration of the vote on House Bill No. 178, passed yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., March 23. -- A large number of Captains of the National Guard were in this city to-day. They came quietly and left town in the same manner. Their mission, it is understood, was to make a personal report to Adjt. Gen. Stryker and Quarter Master Gen. Donnelly as to the condition, needs, and requirements of their men.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Navy Department has arranged for the practical withdrawal of all its naval officers at Havana and the abandonment of the wreck of the Maine. Capt. C.D. Sigsbee, Lieut. Commander Richard Wainwright, Surgeon L.G. Heneberger, Paymaster Ray, Chaplain John P. Chidwick, Chief Engineer Charles P. Howell, and Naval Cadets J.A. Holden and W.T. Cluverius, who have been in Havana with the wreck, will return very soon.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Public feeling here as to the Cuban crisis changes more rapidly than the real situation. Not that popular wish changes, but that the response to that wish, as obtained from the Administration from day to day, seems to change. To-night the impression as to the President's attitude is something different from that which prevailed yesterday.
BARCELONA, March 23. -- At the opening of the Bourse here to-day Spanish 4s were quoted at 76.10. The closing price yesterday was 76.40.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Orders issued by the Navy Department to-day bring into service as coast defense ships the eight single-turreted monitors that were used during the civil war. They have been lying for some time at the League Island Navy Yard, at Philadelphia.

Three of these are within easy striking distance of Cuban waters -- one at Port Antonio, Jamaica; another at Key West, and the third at Port Royal.

If, however, it did not come before 8 o'clock Thursday evening, Mr. Long said he probably would not receive it until Friday morning, when it would be laid before the President immediately.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24. -- The House and Senate to-day each adopted a concurrent resolution for final adjournment tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Spanish flotilla of torpedo boats and torpedo boat destroyers steamed from the Canary Islands for Puerto Rico to-day. The arrival of this news through a dispatch to the Navy Department caused excitement there and in the State and War Departments. The two latter accepted the westward movement of the flotilla as either an act of hostility or an indication of preparation for immediate war.

ALBANY, March 24. -- The Senate Cities Committee rallied to Gov. Black's support in his fight against the rapid-transit "deal" this morning, and, by a tie vote, locked up the Ellsworth bill for a new Platt-Croker Commission.

The last regular meeting of the Midwinter Club for the season, which took place last night at Sherry's, was one of the most brilliant affairs of the kind this winter. The largo ballroom was converted temporarily into a theatre, the necessary scenes having been especially painted for the improvised stage. Two plays and a monologue were given.

CHICAGO, March 24. -- George T. Nicholson has been appointed general passenger traffic manager of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway, to succeed W.F. White, deceased. The appointment is to take effect May 1.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Naval Appropriation bill was taken up in the House to-day, and an arrangement was made to close general debate at 1 o'clock to-morrow. The debate to-day was not on sensational lines, but every radical expression was cheered to the echo by the crowded galleries.

ALBANY, March 24. -- In the Committee of the Whole in the Senate to-day, Senator Pavey moved for advancement his concurrent resolution authorizing the State to dispose of the canals to the National Government.

The Naval Board on Auxiliary Cruisers yesterday thoroughly inspected two big steam yachts, John Jacob Astor's Nourmahal and M.C.D. Borden's Sovereign. It is understood that the owners have offered these vessels to the Government, either for charter or purchase, and that they will be bought within a few days.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The old single-turreted monitor Montauk has been ordered from League Island Navy Yard to Portland, Me. A suggestion was made to send a monitor to New Haven, Conn., but it remains unacted on.

The suit of Samuel Miller to annul his marriage with Ida Miller was continued yesterday before Justice Hiscock in the Supreme Court. Miller claims that he was only seventeen years old when he was married by an Alderman in the City Hall last April, and also that he was so drunk at the time that he did not remember what the Alderman said.

A special gathering of the Democratic leaders of the city is to be held at Lakewood, N.J., to-morrow and Sunday. The Tammany delegation, which will include Mr. Croker, John F. Carroll, Commissioner Murphy, and Daniel F. McMahon, a host of lesser lights, and perhaps Mayor Van Wyck, will leave the city at 3:40 o'clock this afternoon.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., March 24. -- The first great battleship ever launched from a private yard in the South kissed the waves in the James River at 10:02 o'clock this morning at the immense plant of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, and at 11:35 o'clock, a little more than an hour later, a second ship, the exact counterpart of the first one except in name, followed.

PITTSBURG, March 24. -- The worst of the freshets is over, but it is found that the loss will amount to many hundred thousand dollars. The river here is falling rapidly, but the lowlands are yet under water and thousands of workmen are idle and likely to remain so for weeks. All the railroads centring here and at Allegheny are crippled except the Pennsylvania and the Baltimore and Ohio main line east.
HAVANA, March 24. -- The mail steamer from Barcelona arrived to-night with 1,400 Spanish regulars.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- President McKinley has not yet authorized officially the announcement of a policy to be pursued by the Administration to bring the war in Cuba to an end, but Washington has been discussing to-day, with varying comments, the heads of a partial policy outlined at the White House.
ALBANY, March 24. -- When Senator Lamy's bill providing for the sanitary inspection of barbers' shops was reached in the Senate to-day Senator Martin moved to strike out the enacting clause.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 24. -- At the drill of Company E, Third Regiment, N.G. N.J., to-night, orders were given that no man leave the city without special leave obtained from the First Lieutenant. The rifles were inspected and a special field drill had. A special drill of Company C will be held to-morrow night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24. -- Pension frauds said by the investigating agent of the Pension Department to be on an extensive scale have been discovered in this city. Two arrests were made Monday, and many warrants have been sworn out against claim agents of this city and vicinity, and others charged with perjury and uttering forged checks or pension vouchers.

The closing exercises of the Harlem Evening High School, at One Hundred and Nineteenth Street and Madison Avenue, of which Edward A. Page is Principal, began last evening with a debate. This evening the work of the term will be placed on exhibition, and there will be prize speaking and the distribution of diplomas. On Monday evening at the final exercises the class in Shakespeare will entertain.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The officials of the Ordnance Bureau of the War Department have already determined on the manner in which the additional $1,000,000, which has just been allotted to that branch of the service out of the $50,000,000 emergency fund, shall be expended.

Beatrice Frost, twenty-two years old, committed suicide last night at her home, 106 Eleventh Street, Hoboken. She was a beautiful girl and popular in society. No reason is known for her action except grief for the death of her mother, who died a year ago from apoplexy. Since then she has been at times very despondent.

Dr. Tarleton H. Bean, Superintendent of the aquarium, yesterday said the report in THE NEW YORK TIMES that his resignation had been asked for was true. He received yesterday morning from George C. Clausen, President of the Park Board, a letter telling him that his resignation was wanted. It contained no charges and no explanation of the reasons for the action.

ALBANY, March 24. -- A Senator of the State denounced in open debate by a member of the Assembly for introducing an alleged lobbyist, the denunciation hailed with applause from the floor, the adjournment of the House amid great excitement, and a heated encounter between the two legislators in the chamber, were incidents of to-day's session of the Assembly which made it the most dramatic and sensational of the session.

Polhemus Brothers have sold for Charles A. Kuster, to William Shoemaker, the five-story brick fiat, with stores, 691 Eighth Avenue, 25 by 100.

Trotting and pacing stock was again in great demand yesterday at the closing of the combination sale in Madison Square Garden; but there was more at the Garden than the horses to interest the light-harness racing men. A number of owners of crack trotters and pacers were present, and most of them were endeavoring to make matches for their horses.

Loper last evening, it was voted to reduce the capital stock of the company from $725,000 to $500,000 by the surrender of $225,000 of the stock by the stockholders. Over 90 per cent. of the stockholders gave the necessary assent to-day, and the reduction will be made immediately.

WASHINGTON, March 24. -- The Navy Department is informed of the departure of the cruiser Cincinnati and the gunboats Castine and Wilmington from Port Antonio, Jamaica, last evening, but the officials decline to state where they are bound. It has been reported that they have just gone off on a short cruise, and will return to the Jamaica port.

The third day of the Inter-State Trap Shooting Association's annual tourney ended last night at the Elkwood Park traps. The last two days were devoted to the Grand American Handicap, at the close of which competition there were nine men tied for first place. They divided $3,713.75 equally, but the ownership of the silver trophy will be decided in a miss and out to-day.

BURT of the State Civil Service Commission deserves great credit for the temperate but perfectly plain judgment he has passed upon the operations of the amended civil service law, commonly known as the Black law. WASHINGTON, March 24. -- Mr. Thurston of Nebraska made his promised speech on the Cuban situation in the Senate to-day. Not before since the inauguration of President McKinley had so many people been on the Senate side of the Capitol as were there to-day. The galleries were packed with people, many of whom had arrived at the Capitol as early as 9:30 A.M. in order to obtain seats.

The sudden departure from Cuba of Miss Clara Barton, President of the Red Cross Society, gave rise to the belief freely expressed in this city yesterday that she had abandoned her relief work among the starving Cubans because of misunderstandings between the Red Cross officers and Louis Klopsch, a member of the Central Cuban Relief Committee, who has been personally assisting in the work among the reconcentrados.

The contest for the silver trophy in the Grand American Handicap, which has been attracting the attention of all the stars in the trap-shooting firmament for three days, as shot off yesterday on the No. 2 traps at Elkwood Park. Of the nine starters who faced the traps, E.D. Fulford grassed twenty-three straight, and captured the mug, along with the lion's share of the honors. His nearest opponent was G.W. Loomis of Omaha.

ALBANY, March 25. -- The statement may be accepted as final and authoritative that the Platt-Croker Rapid Transit Commission bill is dead past all hope of resurrection. Mr. Ellsworth has communicated to the Tammany Senators his decision not to attempt to have the Cities Committee discharged from consideration of the bill, and its final abandonment has been accepted by the combined Platt-Croker forces.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The stirring scene of the Fifty-first Congress, when members of the minority were charging flown the aisles protesting against the rulings of Speaker Reed, were recalled to-day in the turbulent protests made by the minority against a ruling of the Chair while the House in Committee of the Whole was considering the Naval Appropriation bill.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 25. -- Yale won the fourth annual intercollegiate debate between Yale and Princeton this evening. The scene of the contest was Alexander Hall, Princeton's spacious college auditorium, and the gathering was a notable one. Ex-President Grover Cleveland presided and William L. Wilson, one of the members of Mr. Cleveland's last Cabinet, was one of the judges.

Many years he lived abroad, where he was devoted to music, and when he was eighty he still improvised on the harmonium. In 1859 he came back to Jersey, and there wrote much of the verses published since then.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Commodore Winfield Scott Schley, at present connected with the Lighthouse Board, has been ordered to command the flying squadron at Hampton Roads, with the Brooklyn as his flagship. His command, when completely organized, probably will consist of about a dozen ships.

There is trouble among the members of Washington Heights Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, of which Mrs. Ferdinand P. Earle is regent, and it is expected that after the annual election of the chapter, on April 1, there will be many resignations.

By a remarkable feat of knife throwing "Jew Gus" contrived to kill "English Mary," the woman with whom he lived, in the back room of the Beehive saloon, southwest corner of Oliver and South Streets, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. Police and knife-throwing experts in the museums agree in the opinion that the man would probably fail to duplicate his fatal marksmanship in a thousand trials.

The convention then decided to write into the Constitution Section 5, which has aroused such fierce antagonism, and which is declared by at least ten of the leading members of the United States Senate to be unconstitutional.

KEY WEST, March 25. -- The bulletin stating that the court of inquiry had found the Maine was blown up by a submarine mine was shown here to-day. The comments of Admiral Sicard on the bulletin apparently confirm the statement in the bulletin.

The decision on the classification of imported leaf tobacco, recently made by the Board of Classification of the General Appraisers in the case of the E.H. Gate Cigar Company, is to be appealed. Assistant Secretary Howell has instructed the Collector of Customs at Key West to apply to the United States Circuit Court for a review of the case.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- Anxiety increases in the Navy Department as the Spanish torpedo flotilla draws nearer Cuban waters. The feeling at the department is as if some enemy were creeping up in the dark and no one knew when, where, or how he will strike. Ten or fourteen days must elapse before the torpedo boats and destroyers will be heard from, unless an American vessel chances to run across their path in the meantime.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- The court of inquiry appointed to investigate the cause of the Maine disaster has reported that the loss of the battleship was due to an outside explosion. The State Department, by direction of the President, has cabled United States Minister Woodford, at Madrid, to notify the Spanish Government of this conclusion.
SAVANNAH, March 25. -- Alexander E. Kastle, an expert engineer and constructor of jetties, was on the stand to-day for the defense in the Carter court-martial.

WASHINGTON, March 25. -- An agreement has been reached by the conferees on the Alaska Land bill to insert a provision allowing Canadian miners the same rights in Alaska as are given by the Canadian Government to the American miners. Canadians will not have to be naturalized to take mines in Alaska.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25. -- The Senate and House to-day passed the supplemental appropriation bill for 1898 and the general appropriation bill for 1899, the Democrats in both houses with one or two exceptions refraining from voting. The appropriation bills were amended in a few instances. An increase for stone roads from $100,000 to $150,000 was allowed, and the naval reserve allowance was increased from $10,000 to $13,600.

WATERFORD, March 25. -- The Spanish torpedo boat destroyer Audaz has arrived here with her bows stove in and her stern twisted completely round, being displaced about ten feet.

The carnival of sports held yesterday afternoon and evening in Madison Square Garden under the auspices of The New York Journal and a committee of citizens, added a considerable amount to the fund, with which a monument will be erected in memory of the sailors who were killed in the Maine explosion.

Two fires which occurred in the furniture factory of Morris Eckhardt Co., 363 and 365 Rivington Street, Thursday evening and yesterday morning almost destroyed the building, the total damage being estimated at $20,000.
Frederick Zittel has sold for Bryan L. Kennedy for $51,000 the five-story American basement dwelling, 330 West Seventy-sixth Street, 22 by 63 by 100.

The plan for erecting a home for the Royal Arcanum in Brooklyn has come to grief. On last Labor Day the cornerstone of the proposed Arcanum building was laid in Tompkins Avenue, between Jefferson Avenue and Hancock Street. The building was to be one of the most complete lodge buildings in the country.
ALBANY, March 25. -- No public reference was made in the Assembly to-day to the sensational incident which caused the House to break up in an uproar yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, March 25. -- The Oxford and Cambridge sports were postponed indefinitely to-day, on account of the bad weather prevailing. Later it was announced that the Oxford-Cambridge field sports had been postponed, on account of the weather, to the first week in July. The hope was expressed to-day that many university men would be present and that this would lead to an international match between Yale and Harrow.

HAVANA, March 25. -- El Correo to-day, in highly colored rhetoric, insists that the parallel drawn by Cuba, the New York organ of the Autonomist, between the "jingoes of the United States" and the Spaniards in Cuba is unwarranted, "because the Yankees only urge war for their own selfish greed, while the Spaniards urge it from motives of patriotism."

READING, Penn., March 25. -- Dr. Biddle of the Miners' Hospital, at Pottsville, Penn., removed twenty-nine pieces of needles from the body of Miss Jennie Fessler, a young woman who lives at Mount Carmel, Schuylkill County.

MONTREAL, March 25. -- A special cable to The Star from London, England, says: The semi-annual report of the Grank Trunk Railway, made public to-day, shows a net revenue surplus for the half year ending December, 1897, of 275,263, being an increase of 236,177 over the corresponding half year of 1896.

MANY queer-looking craft are to be seen at present moored to the docks at the League Island Navy Yard, just outside of Philadelphia. The vessels are all warships of the United States Navy, and men are kept at work on them day and night in order to get them in readiness to be placed on the active list.

BUDAPEST, March 14. -- The agrarian question is the great topic of the day in Budapest. According to the latest reports received in the Magyar capital the Counties of Szaboles, Goemor, Heves, Semplin, Csanad, and Bekes are in a state of revolution. The great majority of the inhabitants in these counties have rebelled against the local authorities.

The Richmond County Hunt Club of Staten Island honored its Master of Hounds, Erickson N. Nichols, with a dinner at the Country Club last week. It was an enjoyable affair, and befittingly acknowledged the efforts of Mr. Nichols in providing cross-country sport on the island the past season.

Mr. Alexander H. Stevens, President of the Sixth National Bank, talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the money market and business situation. LONDON, March 26. -- Elaborate precautions are taken to keep any information from reaching the press concerning Mr. Gladstone, but it is learned that his condition to-day is most critical.

MADRID, March 26. -- A General in the army, who declines to permit the use of his name, said to-day that it was incredible that the report of the American court of inquiry into the Maine disaster should attribute the destruction of the vessel to a submarine mine.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 26. -- Two young Italians, Felice Bellefato and Charles Ingrisani, were stabbed to death here last night by Giovanni Genovo and Marciano Famigletti. The murderers have escaped, but two of the accomplices have been arrested. They are Rocco Famigletti and Rafaele Pizoura, partners, who own the saloon where the murders were committed.

At a special meeting of the Ways and Means Committee recently appointed in Philadelphia to make preliminary arrangements for the annual regatta of the Nation Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which will be held under the auspices of the Philadelphia rowing organizations on the Schuylkill next July, the question of finances to defray the expenses of the regatta was amicably arranged.

ORANGE, N.J., March 26. -- James Crotty, ten year of age, of New Street, this city, died in the Memorial Hospital early to-day from the effects of carbolic acid. He was suffering from tonsilitis, and awoke before daylight. Mrs. Crotty got up to give her son some medicine, but made a mistake because of the darkness, and it is alleged gave him a teaspoonful of carbolic acid.

Rain has fallen for two nights, but a continuous downpour lasting at least ten days is necessary to insure large grain crops. The reports of the devastation wrought by the frost in the fruit-growing districts are confirmed.

NEWPORT, March 26. -- The outlook for the season here is very bright. It refuses to take us seriously, unless it be in regard to our millions, for you may appeal to the pocket of a German with more success than to his heart or his sense of justice.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., March 27. -- W.R. Addicks and A.B. Denny of the army arrived here yesterday afternoon to arrange the signal service along this coast to be used in case of war. They had just returned from a visit to all the lighthouses on the Maine coast. This morning they chartered the tug Visit to go to the Isles of Shoals to make views there.

HALIFAX, N.S., March 27. -- Details of the calamity which overwhelmed half of the crew of the sealing steamer Greenland in the ice fields were received here to-day from St. John's, N.F., which port was reached by the Greenland this afternoon. RUTLAND, Vt., March 27. -- In view of the coming agitation to secure a local option law in this State, the figures of its operation during the past year have been compiled, much to the astonishment of the general public. From 108 towns from which reports have been received, 71 have liquor agencies established by law, which have dispensed $167,156.84 worth of intoxicating liquors for "medicinal, chemical, and mechanical purposes."

The protest of Gray Brothers of New York against the customs authorities' classification of an importation of tiger skins was sustained yesterday by the Board of Classification of the General Appraisers. These tiger skins were imported on the Campania in April, 1897, and they were assessed for duty at 20 per cent. ad valorem, as dressed furs, under Paragraph 329.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Wolcott of Colorado, Chairman of the Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads, made a remarkable and caustic arraignment of the Secretary of the Treasury on account of the Secretary's alleged flippant treatment of a request made by Mr. Wolcott's committee.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 30. -- Princeton played the nine of the St. John's College at Fordham, N.Y., this afternoon, and the Tigers won by the score of 16 to 8.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- The Republican members of the Michigan delegation in the House had a conference with the President to-day, in which the Cuban policy was reviewed. The delegation comprised every Republican member from Michigan.

There has been trouble in Company H of the Ninth Regiment, and it is said that Gen. McCoskry Butt may order several members to be court-martialed. The trouble dates back a year ago to a dispute between ex-Capt. Jerome B. Silby and Lieut. Warner Sherwood Young over the preferring of charges by the latter against a member of the company.

Charles S. Kohler Brother have sold for J.H. Havens to Bennett, Sloan Co., for $95,000 cash, the five-story apartment houses, with stores, northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, 49.11 by 110.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- In sending to Congress a deficiency estimate of $8,070,872 for pensions for this year, Secretary Bliss makes an interesting statement on the general subject on pensions up to date. Secretary Bliss says:

The voice of humanity demands the independence of Cuba. The voice of reason demands restraint upon hasty action, which will plunge the country headlong into war, and bring untold-of miseries upon all classes of our people. We have a patriotic President, tried in war, and experienced in statesmanship.

PHILADELPHIA, March 30. -- The hockey team of the Montclair Athletic Club lost a very close match at the West Park Ice Palace to-night. Their opponents were the Quaker City Hockey Club, who scored 6 goals to 4 made by Montclair. Kennedy, Dobby M. Hornfeck, and Koehler scored for Montclair, and Willett and Orton shot the goals for the Quakers, the former scoring 5.
WASHINGTON, March 30. -- There was no Cuban talk in the Senate to-day, much to the disappointment of the people who had packed the galleries.

TAMPA, Fla., March 30. -- As a mark of disapproval of President McKinley's supposed peace policy, the Port Tampa Naval Reserves met last night and the members tendered their resignations. They finally decided to wait a few days for developments. If there is no change in the situation the company will disband.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 30. -- The Legislature of the State of New York to-morrow, at its final session for 1898, will make an appropriation of $1,000,000 for the use of the National Guard if it should be called into active service in the near future.

HAVANA, March 30. -- Sunday and Monday were days of decided anxiety in the political and business circles of Havana, but yesterday and to-day there has been a much quieter feeling. Without being able to give any good reason for their belief, many prominent men seem satisfied that peace is assured.
LONDON, March 31. -- The Vienna correspondent of The Standard says:

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- A vast audience, filling every seat and all the standing room in the House galleries as well, and an almost equally large number of excited people crowding the halls in the hope of getting in, indicated to-day the pervading interest in the proceedings of Congress and the prevailing belief here, notwithstanding reported pacific assurances from the White House, that the country is on the verge of war.

Aneurin Jones was yesterday appointed Chief Engineer of Boulevards, Driveways, and Parkways in the Department of Highways by Commissioner Keating. The place was specially made for him, and its duties and salary have not been fixed as yet.

Incidents indicative of a deep concern for the National welfare and of readiness to support the President's policy punctuated the customarily calm deliberations of the annual New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which opened its ninety-ninth session yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Temple, Seventh Avenue, near Fourteenth Street.

It was reported yesterday that Mrs. John Wood would return to this country to act with Joseph Jefferson the role of Mrs. Malaprop in "The Rivals." It was known that Rose Coghlan had been offered this role by Mr. Jefferson, but declined it, as she intends to retain "on tour" her present character, Lady Janet in "The White Heather," which, by the way, was "created" by Mrs. Wood in London.

The condition of the battleship Texas is still troubling the Navy Department, and the advisability of docking that vessel is now being considered at Washington. It is thought that a decision will be reached today. The report of the diver who examined the hull of the vessel showed that the injury received through touching the coral reef is of a trifling character, and does not impair the efficiency of the warship.

A bold attempt at seizing a thoroughfare was made on the Coney Island Concourse last night, apparently by employes of the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad, otherwise known as the Smith Street line. At about 7:30 o'clock 100 Italians, with half a dozen section foremen, arrived in two trolley cars at the foot of West Second Street, which is the terminal of the Smith Street line.

It has been definitely decided that a ship will be chartered by the Central Cuban Relief Committee for the purpose of carrying provisions and other commodities to the sufferers in Cuba. Chairman Stephen A. Barton stated yesterday that, while supplies were being sent to Cuba with as much expedition as possible now, it was becoming impossible to transport the goods as fast as they arrive.

ALBANY, March 30. -- The canal question was forced to a final issue in the Senate to-day, and that body went on record by a vote of 23 to 22 against submitting the $7,000,000 loan for completing the pending improvements to the people this Fall. The incidents attending this vote were the most sensational of the session.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- It was stated by a Senator who called upon President McKinley to-day and discussed the Cuban question that the Administration was taking no part in the alleged purchase negotiations. He said that this may be talked of in New York and by New York men, but he did not think it was a part of the Administration's policy regarding Cuba.

The stock market had another violent advance yesterday. Closing quotations showed net gains for all of the active stocks, ranging from 1 to 7 points. The advance, like that of Monday, was sensational. Except for a short reactionary period in the afternoon the market was continuously strong.
It will be known Monday whether there will be peace or war between the United States and Spain. The outlook is for war.

MADRID, March 30, Midnight. -- At the Cabinet Council Senor Capdepon, Minister of the Interior, explained the results of the elections; and Senor Moret read a series of important documents relative to the situation of the reconcentrados in Cuba, and the results of the efforts hitherto made for their relief.

ADAIRSVILLE, Ga., March 30. -- A terrific collision occurred one mile south of here early this morning between north and south bound freight trains on the Western and Atlantic Railroad. The north-bound freight was in charge of Charles E. Elliott, as engineer, and his son as fireman.

WASHINGTON, March 30. -- War within forty-eight hours sums up the situation as it is reflected in the Navy and War Departments to-day. Officials, while thoroughly dissatisfied with the policy of the President, feel now as if the matter had been taken out of his hands and that Congress can be depended on for a vigorous and martial course.

PITTSBURG, March 30. -- Lieut. R.D. Tisdale, United States Navy, in charge of the manufacture of guns at Washington, arrived here this morning to attend the funeral of Lieut. Friend W. Jenkins, Speaking on the subject of war, he said:

The Rapid Transit Commission held a meeting yesterday, which was attended by all the Commissioners excepting Charles Stewart Smith, who is in Europe, and Mayor Van Wyck. Controller Coler arrived after Secretary Delafield had informed him by telephone that the board was in session and awaiting his pleasure.

John B. McGoldrick was removed yesterday from the Chief Clerkship of the City Court and Thomas F. Smith was appointed to the place. The removal and appointment were dictated by Mr. Croker at the request of John C. Sheehan. The Chief Clerk of the City Court holds office at the pleasure of the Judges. The pay is $4,000 a year.
VIENNA, March 31. -- The Austrian budget was submitted in the lower house of the Diet to-day. The estimated revenue is 722,271,982 florins and the expenditure is estimated at 717,946,604 florins.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Spanish Legation has received full reports from Captain General Blanco from the Governors of all the provinces of Cuba, and from the Alcaldes and Chiefs of Police of the principal cities, as to the condition of the reconcentrados. It is an elaborate treatment of this subject by the officers directly in charge, and gives the situation fully from their standpoint.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- In the minute study of Spain's military and naval resources that is now being made by this Government, one of the most important questions considered is the facilities that country has for supplying her naval forces in the Western Atlantic and Caribbean with a good quality of coal. In this respect it is ascertained that no country of her naval rank is so badly off as Spain.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Navy Department has at last determined to put the old monitors at League Island in fighting trim. It authorized to-day the expenditure by the Bureaus of Construction and Repair and of Steam Engineering of $500,000 for this purpose. This sum is to be spent at once in repairing the hulls of the monitors, sheathing their decks to prevent leaking, and in putting in serviceable boilers to fit them for sea-going.

The Mary Arden Club, an organization of women who named themselves after the mother of Shakespeare, the poet whose works they make it their business to study, held a luncheon at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday at 1 o'clock. The large round table at which they gathered bore a big circular mirror, representing a pond, which was hedged about with greens.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Adjutant General's office has just completed a report on the organized militia of the United States. It has been called forth by the present crisis, which has made it an interesting and important question as to how strong this militia is, and how well prepared for taking the field for the defense of the individual States, or as part of the Federal forces.

David C. Breckinridge of 214 West Fourteenth Street, who says that he is a cousin of ex-Congressman Breckinridge of Kentucky, was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday charged with passing a worthless check for $50, and was held for examination next Thursday. The complainant, Harry Crozier, a saloon keeper, says that on Feb. 1 Breckinridge handed him a check for $50, in payment for beer and whisky delivered at the defendant's house.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Superintendent of Insurance Payn to-day gave a hearing on the report of an examination made by his department of the condition and affairs of the Lincoln Fire Insurance Company of New York as of Feb. 28, 1898, which report bears the date March 25. The company was represented by counsel, and after the hearing the Superintendent filed the report.

" Cuba will be free and there will be no war." Thus spoke yesterday a down-town business man who has extensive connections with the countries of Europe. "I do not say this," he added, "because I am intrusted with inside secrets of matters of state, but only because I believe that such knowledge as I have enables me to judge of the situation and the probabilities.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- President McKinley may not have appreciated two days ago the depth of the war feeling that is animating both houses of the Congress. Undoubtedly he understands it fully now, and the Congress understands and confides in him more fully, since he supplied members with a more definite idea of his intentions.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Information received at the Navy Department from San Francisco shows that the yard at Mare Island suffered severely from last night's earthquake shock. The sawmill and paint shop of the Bureau of Construction and Repair was entirely destroyed and considerable other damage done.

Demonstrations of a patriotic character were freely interspersed with the routine work of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday in the second day of the ninety-ninth session, at the Metropolitan Temple. Nearly 400 ministers and about 100 women were present at the morning gathering, over which Bishop John F. Hurst presided.

HAVANA, March 31. -- Captain General Blanco has issued an important decree, dated March 30 and published this morning, in which he directs the end of the reconcentration in the four western provinces, Pinar del Rio, Havana, Matanzas, and Santa Clara.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31. -- This city and a portion of the State were shaken at 11:43 o'clock last night by the most severe earthquake experienced here since 1868, when several persons were killed. This time, however, no fatalities have been reported.
Following are topics which yesterday received Wall Street attention:
BOSTON, March 31. -- The Journal's Washington correspondent talked with Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt to-day, who said:

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The work of overhauling the dynamite cruiser Vesuvius, completing the work on her guns and fitting her up for active service, is now almost finished, and she probably will leave the Washington Navy Yard within the next few days. Her officers do not know as yet where she will be ordered, though it is thought that she will go first to Norfolk and then proceed to southern waters.
LIMA, (via Galveston, Texas,) March 31. -- The Chilean Government, it is asserted on good authority, will not sell any warships to the United States.

ALBANY, March 31. -- A material victory was won for the cause of civil service reform in the closing hours of the legislative session to-day by the passage of the Reform Association's bill, introduced by Senator Brush and amended by the Judiciary Committee of the Senate. Gov. Black gave the measure his approval before it was introduced, and it became law by his signature this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Committee of Eleven appointed by the conference of the Republicans of the House, who are insisting upon prompt and aggressive action for the complete independence of Cuba, called upon the President at 2:30 this afternoon and placed before him their views. The conference lasted until 3:50 o'clock.
ALBANY, March 31. -- Gov. Black to-day signed the following bills:

FORT MONRE, Va., March 31. -- The belated cruiser Columbia, for which Commodore Schley of the flying squadron looked in vain all day yesterday, anchored off Fort Monroe this morning just after daylight. She spent some extra time on her trip from Philadelphia here trying the speed of her engines. Everything was found in satisfactory condition.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Among the callers at the State Department, this being diplomatic day, were the German Ambassador, the Austrian Minister, the Venezuelan Minister, and Mr. McArthur, Secretary of the United States Legation at Madrid, who has just arrived from the Spanish capital.

Paul Bauer, better known as George W. Duval, was convicted for a third time within a week before Recorder Goff in General Sessions yesterday. He was on trial for robbing' Sadie Miller of several hundred dollars' worth of diamonds. The trial began yesterday morning and the case went to the jury at 6:30 o'clock in the evening. The jury was out only a few minutes.

CLEVELAND, March 31. -- Steve Brodie, the New York saloon keeper and sporting man, made famous by his jump from the Brooklyn Bridge, is dead. His death is reported by Lake Shore officials in this city. In the performance of the play in which he appeared at Chicago yesterday, he fell twice from sheer weakness, and was hissed because the audience thought him intoxicated.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The State of New York to-day appropriated $1,000,000 to defray the expenses of the National Guard and Naval Militia, and of volunteers furnished by the State. If called into service for the public defense on the request or requisition of the President. This State is the first to take action in this direction.

The appropriation of $1,000,000 by the Legislature of the State of New York to meet any necessary requirements if the military force of the State shall be called upon by the Federal Government is a wise and timely measure.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The President was questioned by every visitor to-day about the proposition which had been submitted to Spain yesterday through Minister Woodford, upon the discovery that Congress would not listen to the plans for "extended autonomy" or the adoption of the Egyptian plan in Cuba. The President gave almost everybody the same answer.
WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Spain has answered!

The public memorial services for Anton Seidl in the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, in the size and character of the assemblage that there honored the master, and in the number, variety, and beauty of the floral tokens of remembrance that surrounded his bier, testified amply to the place he had made for himself in the esteem of this community.

At a conference of marine insurance men, which was held yesterday to receive reports on rates and permanent organization from committees appointed at a conference one week previously, it was unanimously decided to form the Institute of American Marine Underwriters. President Charles Platt of the Insurance Company of North America presided.

MADRID, March 31. -- The feeling in Madrid to-day is pessimistic. Nothing definite has been revealed by the Government as to the nature of the negotiations being carried on with the United States. But the newspapers, although ignorant of the actual proposals of the United States, constantly urge no surrender. The Heraldo (Independent) and the Nacional (Conservative) oppose even the suggestion of an armistice, and the Correo (Liberal) makes a furious appeal to Don Carlos.

Duff Rusher have sold to an investor a plot of eight lots, having frontages of 100 feet on One Hundred and Twenty-third and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Streets, between Amsterdam Avenue and the Boulevard.

The present positions of the vessels of the United States Navy are of great interest just now to the public. The vessels have been collected by the Navy Department at various points around the coast, and are in readiness to attack the Spanish fleet and to defend the cities on the coast.

Dr. A.S. Lesser, surgeon in chief of the Red Cross Society, and his wife, Mrs. Bettina Lesser, known in Cuba as Sister Bettina, has arrived in this city from Cuba. They give a frightful picture of the suffering among the reconcentrados, but say that it is now greatly diminished owing to the relief work of the Red Cross Society.

CAIRO, March 31. -- It is announced in a dispatch from Atbara, on the Athara River, (Black River,) a branch of the Nile, above Berber, that an important reconnoisance was started by the Anglo-Egyptian troops on Wednesday.

HAVANA, March 31. -- It is announced that Lieut. Col. Benedicto, who commanded the Spanish forces which killed the insurgent leader Aranguren, has been wounded by a revolver shot in the back while visiting the house of Dr. Francisco Vidal, at Guanabacoa. A colored man who fired the shot succeeded in escaping.
Amid the varied discussion of the Cuban question at home and abroad there is one fact that may be taken as beyond dispute -- the Spanish Government must retire from Cuba.

The Hamilton Club of Brooklyn gave a dinner last night in the clubhouse in honor of Dr. William H. Maxwell, one of its members, who was lately elected City School Superintendent. Nearly all of the prominent members of the club and many invited guests prominent in educational circles were present.

A controversy of a novel character is now pending between the customs authorities and importers of carbons used for electric lighting. The points at issue were discussed at a special hearing before the Board of Classification of the General Appraisers yesterday forenoon. Ex-Judge Henderson M. Somerville presided, and General Appraisers Ham and Wilkinson sat with him.

ALBANY, March 31. -- The session of the Legislature of 1898 came to an end to-day, the Senate adjourning at 1:35 o'clock and the Assembly at 3:20. Aside from the emergency appropriation of $1,000,000 for the National Guard, the most important business transacted was the passage of the regular appropriation and supply bills and the tax rate bill.

It is customary for the press of the State to greet each annual adjournment of the Legislature with the observation that it has been the worst Legislature in years. That will not be said of the Legislature of 1898, and we must accord to Gov. BLACK much of the credit for the betterment in the morality and the record of the session.

All the writers who insist that we have no lawful ground for intervention in Cuba hold the curiously narrow view that the peace and safety of a nation can be threatened only by the assault of armed foes. External menace is the only menace, invasion by foreign legions the only calamity that can disturb domestic tranquillity.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31. -- The distinction of having attained the age of 126 years will fall to Noah Raby, an inmate of the Piscataway Township poorhouse, near here, to-morrow, if his story is correct.

CHICAGO, March 31. -- The appeal sent the Illinois Congressional delegation last night by fifty prominent business men and stock brokers requesting conservative action was not received in very good spirit judging by the replies returned. Senator Mason answered:

All Americans who have read it must have been touched by the personal appeal which the Queen Regent of Spain has made to several of the sovereigns of Europe to intercede for her at Washington. No American, we may be sure, has read it with more complete sympathy and appreciation than the President of the United States.
Permit me to venture a suggestion or two from the legal point of view upon the subject of your "earnest remarks on Christian Science."

BOSTON, March 31. -- At the Dean Library sale Capt. John Smith's "True Relation" was sold this afternoon to Dodd, Mead Co. of New York for $1,425. Efforts were made to secure the book for the Boston Public Library, but the New York firm outbid all competitors.
LONDON, April 1. -- The Times says editorially this morning:

KEY WEST, Fla., March 31. -- Every preparation for action was taken by the warships to-day. All woodwork was stripped off exposed spots and sent ashore. The wood pilot houses on the cruisers were taken down. To a certain extent interior woodwork also was removed and sent ashore. Even the sailors' wooden boxes were removed from some of the ships.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Frye, (Rep., Me.,) who reported yesterday from the Committee on Foreign Relations a resolution calling upon the President for the Cuban Consular reports, requested that the resolution lie on the table until the committee desired to call it up. He added that the committee was engaged constantly in work, and there were reasons why the resolution should not be considered in the absence of the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- For three hours to-day the packed galleries and excited members of the House listened to a passionate outburst of oratory on the Cuban question, during which the intensity of feeling was alternately manifested by cheers, jeers, and hisses. Time and again the excited throngs in the galleries were admonished to be silent, and once at least it seemed as if a motion would be made to clear them.

MADRID, April 1. -- The afternoon newspapers to-day devote much space to yesterday's function at the Royal Opera, where a subscription entertainment was held for the benefit of the Spanish Navy. They all claim to see in it an "exemplification of the patriotism which will sweep the country, and means 'Hands off Cuba!'"
LONDON, April 2. -- The Times says, editorially, this morning:

The Pocket Magazine for March contains the story of an episode which is vouched for as fact. It says that the editor of a well-known conservative American magazine was once traveling with a steamboat party up the Nile. All the men except himself were playing poker. "Mr. Smith" opened al eighty-dollar jackpot. At that moment the poetical editor rushed in and asked the party to come out to look at the sunset.

Li Hung Chang is believed to be the richest man in the world. This belief certainly gains credit from a glimpse at one portion of his invested capital, which has recently made its appearance in the City of London. Among other sources of income, the great Chinese satrap draws an annual tribute of precious furs from one of the northern provinces.

The very important statement which we published yesterday of the coal supply accessible to Spain in the West Indies is of course familiar already to our naval officers in those waters. As a matter of fact Havana contains the only store that amounts to much. All coal yards in the possession of neutrals are of course closed to belligerents from the day when hostilities are proclaimed.

The press and some of the members of the Government of Spain declare that the propositions of the United States cannot be accepted if they are, in form or substance, inconsistent with the "honor of Spain." The sentiment is entitled to respect to this extent, that our Government shall secure the independence of Cuba on terms that will require the least sacrifice of feeling on the part of the Government or the people of Spain.

About 3,500 persons, among whom was a large number of women, witnessed the eighteenth annual prize drill of the Berkeley School Corps at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night. The 360 young men in their white duck trousers, blue coats, and white shoulder and breast straps, made a fine appearance.

Eleven bouts were decided in the fifth annual competition for the intercollegiate fencing championship, which began at the Racquet and Tennis Club last night, and at the conclusion of the first night's programme Columbia was in the lead with five wins and Harvard was second with four. Cornell is the only other competitor, the Naval Academy men being ordered home early in the day.

Holdridge Ward have sold for Henry, Corn to Sonn Brothers the block, comprising twenty-eight lots, bounded by Amsterdam and Convent Avenues, One Hundred and Forty-first and One Hundred and Forty-second Streets. Mr. Corn acquired this property about two weeks ago in part payment for the Sohmer Building, at Twenty-second Street and Fifth Avenue.

President Clausen of the Park Department made his third move yesterday in his efforts to deprive the Aquarium of the services of its Superintendent, Dr. Tarleton H. Bean. Having first invited Dr. Bean's resignation, without success, he notified the Superintendent on Thursday that his office was abolished and his services were no longer required. He detailed Assistant Superintendent Spencer to care for the aquarium.

Stock Exchange dealings were erratic yesterday. "The pulse of the country" beat unsteadily. It was weak, rallied, became excited and feverish, almost stopped and throbbed again, all in rhythm to the news of the international situation, which, through public and private channels, found its way to the brokers and their customers.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 1. -- Francis Wilson, the actor, who had erected a miniature fort to surround the base of the soldiers' monument here, and who maintained silence when the fort was destroyed by order of the Grand Army Post, acting upon the suggestion of the Trustees of the First Presbyterian Church, who claimed the fort was inartistic and not in keeping with the monument, has written a letter to the public.

Unwelcome intelligence for the Selborne Society and others who concern themselves with the protection of birds comes from Paris. The last word of fashion there is the feather blouse. This is usually composed of the green and blue plumage of the lophophore bird but the flamingo and the peacock are also requisitioned; and the undeniable beauty of the body plumage of many other birds will drag them, too, into the net of ruthless fashion.
MADRID, April 1. -- According to the best information obtainable to-day Spain has resolved definitely not to make any further concessions to the United States.

The battleship Texas will not be docked during her stay at the navy yard. This decision has been reached by the authorities at Washington, and word to that effect was telegraphed yesterday to Admiral Bunce, the Commandant of the yard. This change in the department's plans concerning the battleship is taken to mean that her services may be needed in Southern waters within a very few days.

An important phase of William K. Vanderbilt's plan of concentration of the management of the railroad properties controlled by the Vanderbilts is the proposed abolition of the Third Vice Presidency of the New York Central Railroad. The resignation of H. Walter Webb, in consequence of ill-health, will leave the office vacant as soon as Mr. Webb puts his affairs in final shape for stopping work.
LONDON, April 2. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

The small New Haven freight boat Eleanor Peck, leaving her pier, No. 25 East River; the Fulton ferryboat Somerset, and the tugboat A. Young, with a canalboat in tow, got into a tangle at 8 o'clock yesterday morning. The ferryboat struck the Peck, frightening her own passengers, but while escaping injury herself, damaging the port bow of the Peck, which was in turn driven against the canalboat.

In answer to Mr. Raycroft's inquiry of last week, I can say that one of the most useful books on amateur carpentry is "Every Man His Own Mechanic," Ward, Lock Co., London and New York. It is an English book, but covers a wide range of amateur work, especially that about the house and farm.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 1. -- It is learned from reliable sources that Commodore Schley received an inquiry to-day from the Navy Department at Washington asking just when he could send his squadron to sea. It is understood that the Commodore replied that he could put out of Hampton Roads immediately if necessary. It is rumored here to-night that the Brooklyn and the Massachusetts may drop down to Hampton Roads at any time to-morrow.
CHICAGO, April 1. -- In an interview regarding the letter, Mrs. Henrotin said:

In a very interesting sketch of Rufford Abbey in England, famous for its historic associations since the middle of the twelfth century, which occurs in the April number of The Pall Mall Magazine, may be found the following remarkable statement, (Page 440:)

Ever since a recent interpellation in the French Chamber the journalists of the Boulevard have been waxing indignant, pathetic, or sarcastic, over the barbarity of the Dum-Dum bullet. Now, M. Octave Mirbeau, in the Journal, joins the chorus of denunciation. M. Mirbeau has a friend, "un officier Anglais," who tells him a little story of an experiment made by himself in India with the terrible projectile.

Will you or any of the readers of THE TIMES'S SATURDAY REVIEW kindly furnish me with some information as to the style, character, and worth of the writing of Marie Corelli? I have not as yet had occasion to become acquainted with her works, and do not know whether they are worth reading or not. Thanking you in advance for your courtesy, I am yours sincerely,

CAMDEN, N.J., April 1. -- The Methodist Episcopal Conference for the Southern District of New Jersey to-day voted in favor of the equal representation of laymen and clergymen in the General Conference. The vote was 110 to 65.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations appointed to draft a report and prepare a form of resolution outlining a course of action which this Government shall pursue toward Spain with reference to Cuba so far completed its work to-day that it will be able to report to the full committee at its meeting to-morrow.

M. Brunetiere's recent utterance, "at the bottom of every form of art there is a latent germ of immorality, and all it asks is further growth," is enigmatical. Perhaps it is just as well that there was a warning in M. Brunetiere's words, for he was then addressing a strictly French audience. Talented and refined as may be M. Brunetiere, this phrase is meaningless and impossible of application to great art.

The April Atlantic contains an article by Mr. Herbert Putnam of the Boston Public Library, entitled "The Romance of a Famous Library," describing in detail the extraordinary thefts to which the Ashburnham library owed its value, and giving some account of the thief's history. In 1841 William Brutus Timoleon Libri-Caruccio, known as Count Libri, obtained the post of Secretary to a commission formed to catalogue the manuscripts in the French communal libraries. Says Mr. Putnam:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- Supplementing the action taken yesterday by the Navy Department in requesting Governors of States to drill and equip the Naval Militia so as to be ready for any emergency. Assistant Secretary Roosevelt to-day sent letters to the Governors of those seacoast States not having such orders to take steps looking to the formation of naval militia so far as is possible under the State laws.

I cannot pass from FitzGerald's achievement without mention of Prof. Edward Byles Cowell, the inspirer alike of FitzGerald's study of Persian and of his love for 'Umar. Prof. Cowell's masterly essay on al Khayyam in The Calcutta Review in 1858 became the foundation of a more scholarly study and deeper appreciation of the poet.

J. Morris Brown, in charge of the United States Army Medical Supply Department, 39 Whitehall Street, will be one of the complainants in the West Side Court this morning in a case that has some novel features.
LONDON, April 1. -- Arthur Orton, the Tichborne claimant, died of syncope last evening.

BUFFALO, April 1. -- The meeting of General Passenger Agents to settle the rate war to the Northwest and Pacific Coast adjourned without being able to reach an agreement. Another meeting will be held in New York on or about April 15.
WASHINGTON, April 1. -- A member of the Cabinet, in talking of the meetings today, spoke substantially as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- After an exceedingly turbulent session of six hours, the House to-day passed the Naval Appropriation bill and then adjourned until Monday. The war spirit was manifested in all speeches, and overrode the Naval Committee itself by increasing the number of torpedo boats and torpedo boat destroyers to twenty-four, the bill as reported providing for but twelve.

The average speed per hour for the entire distance was 25.3 miles.

TACOMA, Washington, April 1. -- Travel to Alaska has fallen off tremendously during the last two weeks. Arrivals from Eastern States have been fewer than at any time since December. The steam.hip Australia ailed last night with only 100 passengers from Tacoma and Seattle, though she can carry 600. Her freight is likewise light. The falling off .in travel is attributed to discouraging reports from the trails.

When that ship was recently at Newport News the Quartermaster is said to have manifested unusual interest in the Spanish-American situation.

A member of the House of Commons cannot, aecqrdtng to the ancient law of Parliament, resign his seat. Once he is duly elected, he must retain the trust confided in him by his constituents till the dissolution of Parliament unless he is removed by death or becomes a bankrupt or a lunatic, or is expelled from the House or accepts an office of honor or profit under the Crown.

PITTSBURG, April 2. -- The coal miners of this district took a holiday yesterday to celebrate the inauguration of the eight-hour day, which, according to the Chicago agreement, went into effect Friday. Meetings were held throughout the district, and it was thought by those attending that all of the conditions would be complied with in the district without resort to extreme measures.

TRENTON, N.J., April 2. -- The National Guard of New Jersey and the Naval Militia are in readiness to respond to any call that may be made for their services. Quartermaster Gen. Donnelly has completed all his arrangements for the mobilizing of the militia at the Sea Girt camp, and it is expected that an hour after orders calling out the troops are issued the men will be on their way to Sea Girt.

VIENNA, March 19. -- The Gautsch Cabinet has fallen. PADUCAH, Ky., April 4. -- When death swept into ill-starred Shawneetown yesterday on the crest of a mighty flood, there were few who watched the progress of the monster that lived to tell the awful tale. But among the eye-witnesses who lived is Edward Walton, who has reached Paducah. Walton is a steamboat hand; he had left the packet at Shawneetown, and was spending an idle Sunday afternoon in that village when the levee broke.

The Democratic County Committee of Kings County met last night in the Jefferson Building, in Brooklyn, and organized for 1898. The intent of the meeting was to keep the organization officially intact until a new committee is organized under the new primary election law. James Moffatt, last year's Chairman, presided.

CASTILLO, Nicaragua, March 21. -- In spite of revolutions, abortive and otherwise, threats of war on the Costa Rican border and failure of supplies in various directions, the survey under the Nicaragua Canal Commission goes on. This is especially true of the hydrographic party under Lieut. G.C. Hanus, U.S.N., and the transit party working in connection with them under charge of Francis Lee Stuart.

Beach, Jr., whose marital troubles have been aired in the courts of Oklahoma and this city, and against whom an order of arrest, signed by Justice Daly of the Supreme Court, now stands, is in London. WASHINGTON, April 4. -- The work of increasing the efficient strength of the navy by purchasing ships abroad and at home, and by contracting for new ships from domestic yards, which had fallen behind the other interests of the Navy Department last week, to-day showed signs of renewed activity.

The "eminent Spaniard" is said to have spoken with some bitterness, expressing the belief that "nowadays it is hopeless for any weak State to expect help from Europe, and, therefore, Spain must rely on herself alone."

It is believed that the death list will not exceed 100, and may not run over 50. The lighting plant was destroyed, and in the flickering gaze of lanterns and electric lights from the steamers the search in the town for bodies is made.

The Jewish Passover, or the Feast of Unleavened Bread, will be ushered in at sundown to-day. It will be universally observed by orthodox Jews for eight days and by their reformed and Palestinian brethren for seven days. With the former, however, only the first and last two days are actual holidays, and with the latter only the first and last, the intervening days being only semi-festivals, on which all manner of work may be performed.

NANAIMO, B.C., April 5. -- George F. Tilton, third officer of the steam whaler Belvidere, who has just reached the outside world from the vessels imprisoned in the ice, says that the steam tender Jeanie, the steam whalers Orca and Belvidere, the schooner Rosario, and a bark are near Point Barrow.

WASHINGTON, April 5. -- The bill prepared for the reform of the currency and the protection of the Treasury by the sub-committee of the House Committee on Banking and Currency was introduced in the House to-day. BOSTON, April 5. -- Chester W. Kingsley of Cambridge, who is signalizing the closing years of his honorable career by munificent gifts to colleges and charities, having within a few months distributed $150,000 in this way said to a company of young men to-day: "I don't smoke, because I have always felt that every cigar was burning up the price of a loaf of bread."

MADRID, April 8. -- Yesterday's Cabinet Council is believed to have been occupied principally with a telegram from Cardinal Rampolla, Papal Secretary of State, relative to Papal action. The discussion was very animated between those favoring and those opposed to further attempts at mediation or negotiation. Senor Moret, Secretary for the Colonies, energetically sustained his conciliatory views, and was listened to with great attention.

NEWARK, April 8. -- There is much anxiety in this county among the friends of the park system over a clash of two laws passed by the last Legislature. The parks and parkways are now well under way, but to complete them and to provide for future extensions it is necessary to raise about $1,500,000 more by the sale of bonds.

There were dull times in the Exchanges district yesterday so far as business transactions were concerned. At the Stock Exchange much less than an average Saturday business was done. Less than 165,000 shares were dealt in, and the bond sales were little over $800,000. Only sixty-eight stocks were active, with Sugar in the lead with 48,000 shares, more than one-fourth of the entire list.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- Affairs about the Capitol to-day were in a state of suspended animation. Neither house of Congress was in session, and while a few Senators and Representatives lingered about the scene of their labors, the big building seemed as "a banquet hall deserted" compared with the state of perturbation in which it has been for weeks past. Swift of Fort Slocum addressed the meeting, and roused his hearers to cheers several times. The post, headed by a drum corps, both in uniform, and with the old flag that saw service through the war unfurled, attended the meeting and led the cheering.

Walter Damrosch yesterday announced his intention of retiring shortly, for some time at least, from the active leadership of the Symphony and Oratorio Societies of this city, and from his duties as an operatic impresario. Schofield, retired, as an adviser to the Executive, the Secretary of War, and the commanding General of the army in the event of hostilities. Gen. WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The committee representing the action-at-any-cost faction of the Republicans in the House of Representatives held a conference this morning with Senator Davis, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. The subject of discussion was the possibility of this country's incurring liability for the Spanish-Cuban bonds in case it should drive the Spanish Government out of Cuba without recognizing the Cuban Republic.
